name: Elite Event: Elements Massage San Mateo
text: This was my first Yelp Elite event and it was a great one! Candice and Donna did an awesome job preparing some healthy snacks to munch on while we waited for our massage. Huge kudos to them!The event was pretty low-key as there were only a handful of Yelpers around. It was nice to be able to chat in a quiet place with a small group of people. Naturally, we talked at length about our favorite places of eat; our bookmark lists grew quite a bit!The massage itself was great. My masseuse, Daisy, really put on a good amount of pressure when I asked her to really dig in. The team at Elements Massage were all kind and friendly. The premises were clean and well-maintained. If you're in downtown San Mateo and looking for a massage before eating some delicious food, check out Elements!

name: The Sandwich Spot
text: Sandwich Spot hits all the right spots so dang well! Everything about my first visit was beyond my expectations for an unassuming sandwich shop.They have FORTY signature sandwiches all at an extremely affordable price range (under 9 dollars)! Some are pretty standard like the #2 - Smokin' Sequoia with turkey, bacon, cheddar, and avocado. Others are wild like #30 - Burn in Heaven which is a meatball sandwich with jalapeños and Lava and Bomb sauce!The bread is freshly made. If you're asked if you mind waiting a few extra minutes for fresh-out-of-the-oven bread, the right answer is, "Of course I don't mind waiting for delicious fresh bread! Do you take me for a mad person!?"Pro tip! Bring a friend and get two sandwiches you're both into. Split the sandwiches and you'll get to sample two different bites of sandwich heaven. Don't forget: friends who eat delicious sandwiches together, stay together!During my first visit for lunch I had the Burn in Heaven and Hangover. Both we're absolutely on point! Not going to lie, I almost came back the same day for dinner. It was THAT good!

name: Apple Fritter
text: Awash in a sea of Bay Area brunch spots, the nondescript Apple Fritter (formerly a Taco Bell) delivers a unique and hot-and-heavy (not to mention heavenly) dining experience! Come hungry, leave absolutely stuffed and satisfied!Their menu is loaded with delicious variety of cleverly named dishes to fill you right up. The Instagrammablewich is sure to get you some likes on a popular social photo sharing network! My go-to is the simple Ham, Egg and Cheese breakfast sandwich with a side of tater tots. It looks pretty unassuming but it packs a lot of flavor and more than satisfies my morning hunger. And you can't forget the donuts! They have a nice variety - anyone in the mood for a Maple Bacon Bar? I highly recommend trying the Apple Fritter. It is - not surprisingly - a large and delicious fritter packing a large apple-flavored punch.

name: Pho Vi Hoa
text: Pho Vi Hoa got a sterling recommendation from a friend so we rolled by one evening to check it out. The Vegetarian Spring Rolls we got as an appetizer to share were monstrous and tasty. I loved my pho with Eye Round Steak and Meatballs. The pho here comes with A LOT of meat and A LOT of noodles. All in all, I was really happy with my first visit! This place gets quite busy, but it's pretty large and does a good job of getting people in, fed, and out the door. Teaspoon is also right next door so don't forget to grab some delicious boba on your way out!

name: Stella Alpina Osteria
text: A really great place to come for a date. It's got a cute, quaint, "mood lighting" ambiance. More importantly, the food is good too!A lot of reviewers talk about how the amazing Gnocchi in White Truffle Sauce. It's not overhyped! It is truly an amazing dish and definitely the most solid item on the menu. You can get an entree-worth of gnocchi but it is pretty heavy so we opted for the appetizer-sized version.Bread basket was on point. Yes - you can do a bread basket wrong! And Stella did it right. The bread was warm and the butter was not rock hard. It's easy to overlook these things so it's nice to see them get it right. Our entrees were good. The Rigatoni al Ragu di Maiale came with a very generous amount of smoked pork. The Scottadito di Agnello (lamb chops) were also good.We ended our meal with a Bread Pudding del Giorno. It was definitely a unique take on bread pudding. The pudding was covered in coconut flakes and served with a hot pineapple cream.All in all Stella provides a great ambiance, amazing gnocchi, good food, and - most importantly to a bread lover - warm bread and butter!

name: DAVIDs Tea
text: A beyond-super friendly staff, a large selection of teas, and a nice assortment of tea-related accessories makes DAVIDs Tea an awesome one-stop shop for anyone looking to get into tea or try new tea flavors.Everything about this place screams cool. They have cool tea containers that lets you get your nose and fingers in the tea. Don't worry; they won't sell you the tea that everyone rubs their nose and fingers in! These containers also have a plethora of information about the tea. They make tea with fizzy water, which is cool too.If I had bought all the tea that interested me and smelled delicious, I would have walked out with a much lighter wallet and lots of tea, but I'm taking it one at a time. See you soon, DAVIDs Tea!

name: Dana’s Flower Basket
text: I wanted a single red rose. I called this place and asked if they sold them; got an enthusiastic "everyday of the week" response and told the florist would swing by later in the day. Dropped by an hour later and my single red rose was already prepared. $5 later I was out the door.In short - quick, easy, and the rose was wonderfully presented. Thanks, Dana!

name: Rangoon Ruby
text: Rangoon Ruby is a classy establishment serving unique Burmese food.The menu is vast and the place runs smooth like butter. How smooth? We ordered a Mango Salad, Palata with Chicken, and Basil Beef. Each item came out as we were wrapping up the previously delivered item. The pacing was magical to say the least. Each item was pleasant to the palette offering unique twists on the Thai food I think it looks like. I particularly enjoyed the Palata. The entries are a little on the pricier side, but if you're looking for a classy meal don't hesitate to come here.

name: Sushi Sam’s Edomata
text: Top notch sushi, but you don't have to take my word for it. A coworker of mine from Japan says this is his favorite sushi place in the the Bay Area. He says the soba is awesome. Call me crazy, but I trust Japanese people when it comes to Japanese food.That said, I enjoyed the food as well. The fish tasted really good and the rice was out of this world! It reminded me of the awesome rice I ate when I visited Japan. I had a roll with sweet seaweed and mackerel which was so damn good! I ate a bunch of my dining partner's chirashi and that was also so damn good! In short, this place is damn good! The place is somewhat small and very, very popular so don't come unless you have some time to wait to be seated and some time to wait for your food to come out. All that said, it's definitely worth it if you're craving some delicious sushi!

name: Fat Dog
text: On a Saturday morning in LA, my friends and I were craving a solid brunch. Fat Dog delivered 100% with friendly service and great food.We got some Biscuits and Jam to share and they were on point: flavorful, moist, and with a crunchy crust. We ended up getting another order because they were too good and we needed more. The Short Rib Hash was a pleasant twist on the traditional Eggs Benedict.And of course we got the Fat Dog. The Fat Dog is indeed a nice, thick, fat sausage worthy of your appetite and the sexual innuendo needed to satisfy the sexual frustration your party brings to the table after a Friday night out in the city.

name: Chuck’s Donuts
text: I bribed my coworkers - with the promise of donuts - to vote for my team in our company Halloween competition. We won. I needed to get donuts.Enter Chuck's Donuts. I came in late morning and there was still a very nice selection to choose from. For a great price, I got a variety of amazing donuts and munchkins (donut holes for those who grew up with Dunkin' Donuts). Not surprisingly, the donuts were a hit with my coworkers!

name: Scoop Microcreamery
text: Ridiculously amazing ice cream! The Speculoos 'n' Cream and Brown Sugar Banana we had was chock full of flavor and the texture was spot on. Bonus points to the Speculoos for having cookies infused within; the flavor is actually named after these delicious Belgian wheat flour cookies.

name: Bacchanal Buffet
text: The only advice you really need to heed: Come hungry! Come hungry!! Come hungry!!!The best plan of attack is to have a light dinner the day before and come around 2 PM. Don't have breakfast. Don't have a snack. Around 2 PM, you'll miss the lunch rush and you'll still get the lunch price, which is almost half the dinner price. Don't expect to have an appetite by dinner either. I don't even think we were that hungry for lunch on the following day!We originally told ourselves we were going to walk around and look at everything they had to offer before digging in, but could not get past the first section which had an excellent selection of seafood items. They've got everything here! To name a few that come to mind: seafood, barbecue, pizza, burgers, soup, tacos, cheese and meat, sushi, chinese dim sum, gelato, egg tarts.It's a buffet, but all the items were definitely above the typical mediocre buffet quality you expect at buffets.

name: Everyday Beijing
text: After my first meal at Everyday Beijing, I was content after indulging in a delicious meal and happy that I finally discovered a fantastic dumpling place in downtown San Mateo!The dumplings were great and they even have Fish Dumplings which I don't see very often. The other things we ate like the Chinese Burger and Green Chives Pancake also hit the spot. Everything about Everyday Beijing is done right, which is even more amazing when you consider how large a menu they have. Service is also friendly to boot!Take a walk down B Street to Everyday Beijing and I can promise you won't regret it.

name: Vesta
text: Vesta has astounding appetizers and amazing pizza! My team rushes here for team lunches and we always saunter away very full and very happy. Definitely get the Mushroom Toast! It's so, so, so good! All the different types of pizza we've tried are good, but everyone has their favorite. My favorite is the Mushroom because it has mushrooms and strong, bold flavors courtesy of the truffle oil and goat cheese.To be honest, I don't think I've ever regretted a bite of anything Vesta has dished out. And many times those bites have brought me to the verge of pizza heaven.

name: B Street & Vine
text: I've walked past this FIVE-STAR establishment so many times. When I finally tried it, tears of joy streamed down my face.Definitely get the Bruschetta. Actually, that's probably all you need to get. You get to pick four different types per order, which is great because it gives you a ton of flexibility. You can go just with savory selections, or sweet, or a mix of both. My dining team enjoyed all the selections we sampled, but favorites included Mango, Tomato and Avocado and the Smoked Salmon, Cream Cheese, and Capers.

name: Seniore’s Pizza
text: Amazing, amazing, amazing, amazing, amazing pizza! My waistline hates it, but I come here almost once a week! My go-to is a plain Cheese Slice and a Seniore's Slice. Both are AMAZING. The Chicken Pesto Slice is also great. The crust is thick and soft and they don't skimp on the amount of cheese and toppings they put on these magnificent creations. Extra cheese on the slice: prices are also very reasonable! Thank you, Seniore's for bringing pizza happiness into my life so often!

name: Katana-Ya
text: I got the Katana-Ya Ramen with Rich Miso broth and it was great. Among many other things, the ramen comes with fried chicken karaage, dumplings and pork. The variety was certainly enjoyable and bumped up my feelings about the place. The ramen cost $13, but it's a super large bowl. I finished everything except the noodles. :)My fresh-off-the-boat Japanese friend (born and raised in Japan, only very recently came to the USA) said he really liked it. But knowing Japanese people it was probably just okay by his high Japanese-ramen-standards and he was just being super nice.Also, unlike most other places in San Francisco, it's open late. Last call is at 1:15 AM so don't show up right before closing time (2 AM) and except to eat some ramen!

name: Champagne Seafood Restaurant
text: The food is great. I think this place is related to the Champagne Restaurant in Millbrae - that I really like - because their menu seems identical. Super solid dim sum across the board. The Fried Pumpkin is great, the Shanghai Soup Dumplings are great, and the Steamed BBQ Pork Buns are great. Everything was spot on.Except the service. I was somewhat tempted to dock a star for the several service faux pas the waiters put my party through, but ultimately, I judge a restaurant's worth by the food that goes in my mouth.In short - good dim sum, but don't be surprised if service isn't stellar... or good... or decent... or mediocre.

name: Indian Bento
text: It's always a good day when Indian Bento is serving lunch at my company. The food is  spot on. The Chicken Tikka Masala is flavorful without the heavy cream laden heaviness you get elsewhere. My friend is a big fan of Saag Paneer and really enjoys their Saag Paneer.My only complaint is about the naan, which is more like pita bread than naan.

name: Naru Bento - CLOSED
text: I once saw a couple walk into Naru Bento, eye the humble menu containing 5 entrees, scoff at the "limited" selection, and then walk out. That day, I saw a couple of fools.Naru Bento is awesome. Seriously. The menu isn't huge, but it doesn't have to be. You'll likely get addicted to one item and then only want to eat that. Pork Katsu is my vice. My dining partner really likes their Minced Pork over Rice. Sometimes we share an order of Popcorn Chicken. It's great!I visit at least once a week. I always tell myself I'm going to try something new, but I always get the Pork Katsu. And I never regret it.My only complaint is the seasoning is off sometimes: it will be too powdery sometimes and other times the fried crust doesn't even stick to the meat. Also, their compostable eating utensils are super environmentally friendly, but they make eating difficult sometimes. BYOS - Bring Your Own Silverware!!!

name: Sushi 85 - CLOSED
text: YES! So it seems the way to a 5-star review from me is either amazing bubble tea or great deep-fried sushi. Sushi 85 delivers on the latter in so many amazing ways.They have a wide selection of regular, baked, and deep-fried rolls; some are okay, some are wonderful, and some take me to paradise!Here is my roll-by-roll breakdown:* Crazy Roll - Deep fried California roll - 4/5 - Simple, but great* Texas Roll - Salmon, avocado, cream cheese (deep fried) - 5/5 - PARADISE!* Bat Man - Unagi, cream cheese, crab, chef's sauce (deep fried) - 5/5 - SO CREAMY!* Cowboy Roll - Salmon, cream cheese, salmon and avocado on top - 4/5 - Good, but not amazing* Popcorn Shrimp Roll - Ebi, cucumber, popcorn shrimp on top - 2/5 - Popcorn shrimp is good, but the roll under is disappointingMore updates to come as I explore more of the menu!

name: US Post Office
text: I visit this post office a lot. The employees at the front desk are all really friendly and I've only had positive experiences interacting with them. Sometimes there can be a wait because a lot of people don't come with their packages 100% prepared. The manager could be a little more diplomatic though. Once, a USPS mail carrier picked up a package FedEx dropped off at my door. Later, I got an angry call from the manager who was blaming me for the situation. I tried to explain how unreasonable it was that I was being blamed for their mistake, but the manager didn't seem to even care about what I had to say. Oh wells...

name: Sozai Corner
text: As long as your expectations are properly set, Sozai Corner won't disappoint. You won't get mind-numbingly amazing food here, but if want some sushi rolls, inari, or beef curry really quickly, you can't go wrong with Sozai Corner.

name: Duke of Edinburgh
text: An English-style pub with a surprising lack of Scottish brews. My friend (who went to school in Edinburgh) and I shared some standard bar-comfort-food: Potato Skins and Chicken Tenders. Both were good. My pint of Fat Tire started tasting weird towards the end. My friend confirmed my finding. I made a remark to the bartender, but she kind of just shrugged off my observation, which kind of irked me.

name: Homma’s Brown Rice Sushi
text: A quirky little hole-in-the-wall sushi place that serves sushi prepared with brown rice. As with all quirky sushi places, sushi snobs should stay very far away!The brown rice is a pleasant twist; it tastes good and it doesn't feel like I'm sacrificing taste for a "healthier" rice. I usually order Inari and some rolls. The Una-Avo (eel and avocado) is my favorite roll. They get all the basics right: the fish is fresh and the rolls have a good blend of flavors and textures. The place is run by a chef and his twin sons. They look identical, but I think one is more boisterous than the other! The one down-side here is that with one chef, food can come out slow at times. Stay strong as your patience will be rewarded with interesting sushi.

name: Menlo BBQ
text: They should consider changing the name of this place to Menlo Korean BBQ - A Korean Twist on American Classics.Case in point: the Bulgogi Burger with Garlic Fries. The worst thing about a hamburger is when the meat is overcooked and dry. Fortunately, bulgogi - even when cooked thoroughly - is still juicy and tender. Problem solved! The burger was great: juicy and filled with flavor. The Garlic Fries also being amazing was frosting on the cake!

name: Fat Angel
text: If you're craving beer, wine, and comfort food, look no further than Fat Angel. It will more than deliver on your expectations. My dining partner and I shared some Maple Bacon Butter. It was great; I definitely want to come back to try other flavors like Garlic Chili and Honey. We also got Sliders, a Basil Pesto Flatbread, and a Spicy Mac n' Cheese. This sounds completely unexciting, but everything we tried was really superb. Thanks for the great meal, Fat Angel!

name: AJA Asian Cuisine & Lounge
text: Beware! Entering this restaurant is a hazard if you're already on Route 1. Basically, you need to merge into a lane where cars are entering and accelerating to get onto Route 1. If it was any other state where drivers aren't complete and total jerk-offs, this wouldn't be a problem, but what can I say? New Jersey drivers are cream of the crop when it comes to being "courteous." Check Aja's website for "safer" entrance directions.AJA pretty much hits a bunch of the Asian food groups: Japanese, Thai, Chinese. They also have a well-stocked bar and the decor is very, very appealing to the eyes. The food itself is okay. My dining party mostly focused on the Japanese menu; we had Gyoza, Shumai, a Sushi and Sashimi platter, and some rolls. Everything was okay. The one really sour point was the bone my dining partner found in his sashimi, which is inexcusable in any sushi place.

name: Na Ya Dessert House
text: Right next door to Sharetea -- my favorite bubble tea place ever. I was happy I wasn't griefed to death for bringing in an outside drink, but perhaps I was just very discreet. I know it's not exactly courteous, but in MY AMERIKA I should be able to have my favorite bubble tea and eat some desserts at the same time. We tried the Jumbo Thai Crepe and the Na Ya Toast with Chili Paste and Shredded Pork. The pork and turkey sausage in the crepe was a bit weird, but then again it is a pork and turkey sausage. The menu is extensive. As long as they don't mind me enjoying some outside bubble tea, I'll happily come back to try more of their stuff!

name: Brick House Tavern + Tap
text: Food was simply okay.I got the Southern Fried Chicken Sandwich. The promised "spicy buttermilk marinated fried chicken" tasted just like plain-old fried chicken. Nothing special. The brioche bun also didn't taste super fresh; perhaps toasting it would've enhanced my experience? All in all, probably a great place to come watch a game, but not a place I'd come again just to eat.

name: Cafe Caffe
text: Cafe Caffe is my go-to spot for Tosta Mistas. Basically, it's a ham-and-cheese panini on a Portuguese Roll. It's simply delicious.  They make Pasteis de Nata, but I'm a die-hard Teixeira's Bakery fan. They also started making Francesinhas -- one of my favorite Portuguese comfort dishes. Next time, I'm in town I'm definitely giving it a try.

name: Tataki
text: Rolls were good, but the appetizers were disappointing.The Fried Calamari tasted stale. The Gyoza had a "fresh out of the microwave" texture. The Crab Croquettes were a bit dry.Rolls fared a lot better in our book. We all enjoyed the seared filet mignon on the Early Bird and the spicy kick the Extinguisher packed. I love cream cheese so I tried their Philadelphia Roll, which deviates a bit from the standard formula and adds avocado. I'm a fan of this modification! The Golden State was an all-around enjoyable roll.

name: Wooden Charcoal Korean Village Barbecue House
text: My friend and I went with the $48 BBQ Charcoal Set for 2. Pretty pricey, but a ton of food came out. You get the standards: a bowl of rice, rice tea, and Korean Banchan. You get a hefty amount of Rib Eye and Chicken. And you even got some Soft Tofu Stew. As always, there is a helpful Korean lady to help you cook your meat. We were definitely not prepared for the amount of food, but thoroughly devoured and enjoyed everything that came our way. It's pricey and it probably will be even more expensive during my next visit. Prices are probably going up as often as rent is in San Francisco. Every price label seems to have been changed 4-5 times given the stack of small white labels displaying the price. Pro tip - if you really enjoy any of the Banchan dishes, don't hesitate to ask for some more.

name: Light Horse Tavern
text: Whitehorse Tavern is an all-around solid dining establishment. The service is friendly and professional, the rustic decor is beautiful without being too overbearing or obnoxious, and -- mostly importantly -- the food is delicious. My party shared some Fried Calamari and Jalapeño Polenta. The polenta was a hit. I had a Light Horse Tavern (LHT) Burger and it was top-notch. I'm always impressed when a restaurant heeds my request to cook my burger medium-rare. Yes, there is a small chance it might cause some gastrointestinal discomfort later on, but I'm willing to take the risk, especially when great flavor is on the line.

name: Lopes Sausage
text: The butcher of choice for my family for over 20 years. Even when we moved out of Newark, we still make the trek down when the meat freezer starts running low. Yes -- we have a freezer just for meat. They also have really good presunto. If you're a fan of cured meats (or just meat in general), I'd highly recommend you check this place out to satisfy your carnal desires.

name: Clay Oven
text: Okay, but not great. Let's take the Chicken Tikka Masala -- my benchmark of Indian buffet quality. The sauce is thick, creamy, and flavorful at Clay Oven. But the chicken itself is disappointingly dry and chewy.I probably won't come back; there doesn't appear to any great Indian options in San Mateo, but there are plenty in the Bay Area. I'll go to those instead.

name: Casa Do Pão De Queijo
text: Casa do Pão de Queijo (House of the Cheese-Infused Bread) is my go-to place for salgados (Brazilian snacks).My go-to items are the Coxinha and Pão de Queijo. Coxinha looks like a deep-fried pear, but it's filled with shredded chicken! Pão de Queijo is small cheese-infused pieces of bread. Cheap and absolutely tasty!

name: Red Pepper
text: Red Pepper provides a ridiculously inexpensive ($12) and wonderful lunch buffet.The Chicken Tikka Masala is so freaking creamy. Seriously -- I felt like I was eating pieces of chicken-flavored butter given how each piece just decadently melted in my mouth. Aside from the chicken, they had a bunch of my favorite dishes including Malai Kofta and Paneer Makhani.

name: Sharetea
text: Sharetea in SF!? Well, now I can stop caring about who makes the most mediocre bubble tea in SF because Sharetea makes the best bubble tea IN THE WORLD. I'm a huge fan of the Okinawa Milk Tea. And by big fan I mean that I have had it like 30 days in a row....

name: Levain Bakery
text: Perfection is sometimes muddled with subjective opinions, but Levain's cookies are perfect, and that's AN ABSOLUTE FACT.I don't like chocolate, which eliminates most of the cookie menu for me, but all I need is an Oatmeal Raisin Cookie and I'M IN HEAVEN. They are so large, so wonderfully delicious, so juicy, and quite frankly, so absolutely perfect. If I could marry a Levain's cookie, I would do it in a heartbeat!SERIOUSLY. PERFECT.

name: Luke’s Lobster
text: My visit to Luke's Lobster was spurred by the highest recommendation from a friend. Luke's did a great job of living up to my expectations.My friend and I had the Noah's Ark which let us try the lobster, crab, and shrimp rolls (and a bag of chips and a drink). There wasn't a biblical flood during our visit, but Noah's Ark guided us to some wonderful promised land of SANDWICH NIRVANA. We both agree they were all delicious, but the lobster definitely won us over the most.The sandwiches are a bit small. Even after eating the rolls, we were both still pretty hungry. That said, I know seafood is expensive so this isn't completely unreasonable. Also, looking on the positive side, Luke's leaves plenty of room for some delicious cookies from Levain Bakery which is only a quick walk away!From the name to Noah's Ark, there are a lot of biblical references being thrown around and I think that's for a good reason. Luke's Lobster is truly a gift from a higher place!

name: Perona Farms
text: My cousin had her wedding ceremony here. The grounds are beautiful. The reception was in the barn. Don't worry -- it's a very nicely furnished barn with stellar air conditioning.The hors d'oeuvre were served on the ground floor. Then we moved up a floor (right under the roof) for more food and dancing. It was a hot, steamy night in New Jersey, but great air conditioning and excellent circulation kept the climate of the entire evening extremely pleasant. Best part of the whole thing to a tech nerd? Terrible cell phone reception, but a WiFi network with more than tolerable speeds. Huzzah! So proud of my cousin for excellent discretion when it comes to wedding venues!

name: Golden Unicorn
text: Absurdly long line for weekend dim sum, but this restaurant spans multiple floors, so the wait wasn't that bad. The food was good; they got enough things right that I gave it a thumbs up at the end of the meal. In short, I'd come back here for dim sum again.Worth nothing:* They don't have Shanghai Soup Dumplings (xiaolongbao). Sadness!* They have a cart that is a mobile dumpling cart. You pick the dumplings you want and the lady cooks (more like reheats them) and serves them to you. Some dumplings from this magical cart were lukewarm though, which kind of ruins the whole point of the cart in my opinion.

name: Momofuku Milk Bar
text: MomFUKU YEAH! This place is awesome.I had the Milk Cereal Soft Serve with Crunch. The flavor of the soft serve was just perfect; it tasted just like milk after you finish all of your cereal. The added crunch toppings (corn flakes) enhanced this nostalgia trip back to my cereal-filled childhood.My only complaint was the consistency of the soft serve was a bit off. It tasted (and looked) icy at times. That said, I'll definitely visit again when I'm in the city.

name: Ramen Parlor
text: Run by the same team behind Ramen Dojo (up a block), but a tad bit bigger and with its own parking lot. The ramen is great; I had the Garlic Miso Lobster Pork Ramen. It's packed with flavor and the ingredients jive well. Get the Soft-Boiled Egg; it's a must!The lobster ramen gave the meat a fishy flavor, which sounds weird, but honestly it was pretty good! The Gyoza, Chicken Karaage, and Fried Oysters were also good. Not sure if Parlor is better than Dojo. I'll have to visit the two some more to properly assess these two siblings. Poor me!

name: The Pig & Whistle
text: The Pig & Whistle is a ridiculously awesome pub that serves British food. The staff is uber-friendly, the beer selection is great, and the food is superb. Among the things my party tried, we actually enjoyed everything, but we really digged the Fried Calamari and Fish and Chips.And a nice plus is that even though it's in the city, you shouldn't have a hard time finding parking in the area!

name: Lori’s Diner
text: It's a restaurant in an airport, so $15 got me an okay-sized NY Steak Sandwich and a good amount of fries. The fries were okay, and the steak sandwich featured a nice piece of juicy steak. I haven't sampled much of the other offerings at SFO, but I can imagine this is above average for airport food.

name: The Dutch Goose
text: The beer selection is good.A plate of Deviled Eggs costs about ten dollars and gets you NINE amazing deviled eggs. SO FREAKING GOOD! It definitely lived up to the all the hype you see on here.The Cheeseburger on sliced sourdough was okay. Definitely overcooked, but it wasn't bad. The Sweet Potato Fries were good; they are cut a little big and not crispy at all. My only complaints are the pitchers are pretty small (but the price is not), and they are super slow taking orders and super slow getting food out. All in all, definitely my go-to bar in the area!

name: Furagu Sushi
text: AWW HELL YISS!!!!Finally, a competitor that can go toe-to-toe with my favorite deep-fried sushi joint -- Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose -- has emerged: Furagu Sushi. Two visits in and I'm in love. Their fried rolls are amazing. The Lion King is great, the Dynamite Roll is amazing, and the Las Vegas Roll satisfies my deep-fried cream cheese cravings. The hand rolls and appetizers we've tried so far (gyoza, chicken karaage, fresh oysters) have also been spot on. My dining partner wasn't a fan of their sashimi, but I don't come here for sashimi; I come here for DEEP-FRIED AMAZING STUFF!Run, don't walk to Furagu Sushi and prepare yourself for a blissful experience!

name: Siam Palace
text: If you cross the San Mateo Bridge and just keeping going once you reach the other side, you'll eventually end up in downtown Hayward and there you will find Siam Palace, a quaint Thai restaurant that does a good job across the board. My dining party enjoyed Thai Roti (Thai equivalent of Indian naan), Chicken Satay, Tom Kha Soup, Beef Curry, and a Pumpkin Curry. The Fried Banana with Ice Cream topped off an excellent meal. My only complaint is about their soup pots and the spoons they come with. The spoon is a tad bit too big so getting the soup from pot to bowl is an exercise in frustration. That said, once you start eating, it's all good!

name: Ike’s Place
text: 6000+ reviews and a 4.5 star rating more than confirms that Ike's Place is serving up some amazing sandwiches. The only downside to this place is picking a single sandwich from the many, many sandwiches they offer. My friend and I split a Super Mario (meatball with mozzarella sticks) and a Hot Momma Huda (chicken with buffalo sauce). Both were amazing. Great bread and great ingredients resulting in great sandwich synergy. The Huda is named after Ike's mom. To raise such a maestro of sandwich-making, she must be one amazing lady!Now to live in the dilemma that is trying a new sandwich or continuing to eat the sandwiches I love. Life is truly difficult sometimes...

name: Restaurant Bay Watch
text: Enjoyed a nice Saturday brunch here. My friend was into her Smoked Salmon Eggs Benedict and I found the Breakfast Burrito -- with chunks of chorizo and topped with a creamy sauce -- delicious. We split a Blueberry Pancake and regretted only getting one! We'll definitely be back to try some of their other stuff.

name: The Cheese Steak Shop
text: Nothing amazing here, but if you're craving a cheese steak and some fries (or other fried goodies), this place will get the job done. The staff is friendly, but ultimately mediocre ingredients beget "just okay" cheesesteaks.

name: Umami Burger
text: Fancy-ish burgers for a fancy-ish price. The fries are great, especially if you get them with truffle oil or make them manly (cheddar and bacon). They have specials that change every few weeks which always sound very interesting, so you may be pleasantly surprised during a future visit.I really wish they would have the cheesy tater tots more often. So far, they're only 1 for 4 of my visits. That's not enough tater tots, Umami!!!

name: Tee Off Bar & Grill
text: Yep, it's a dive bar. And yes, the food is freaking AMAZING.They seemingly have it all on their menu and they do it all so freaking well. The Mac and Cheese is ridiculously amazing. Want a Pulled Pork in a Waffle Cone? Yes, it exists and it is wonderful. You want oysters? They got it. You want a hamburger or a pulled pork sandwich? They got it. You want Fish and Chips? You'll get one massive piece of fish with fries. My only complaint is they only have two people working the bar and taking orders so sometimes it's a bit slow to get your order in. That said, patience will be rewarded with an amazing culinary experience!

name: The Creamery
text: The Pesto Margarita crepe was pretty good. For $10, I was expecting more than 2 small crepes. But then again, I am in the SOMA neighborhood of San Francisco, so everything is magically more expensive. The chicken inside the crepe was surprisingly juicy. That said, this was more of a snack, and not a meal. If you want to pay $10 for a snack, come on by!Also, shouldn't a place called The Creamery really have ICE CREAM!?

name: Ajisen Ramen
text: Aside from one very, very important thing, this place is absolutely fantastic. Everything we had really, really knocked our socks off!We finally found a place that serves large, juicy chunks of Chicken Karaage. The Fried Pork Dumplings are just pan-fried pork shumai, but still great nonetheless. The Cream Crab Croquette are so decadent and delicious. The ramen was flavorful, had plenty of meat, and was very quickly taken care of. The only very important thing holding this place back from perfection? The noodles in the ramen are really not up to the par. And noodles are a pretty important part of ramen. They were super thin, and really unimpressive. I didn't even bother finishing them! If excellent noodles are a must-have, this place may not be up your alley.

name: China Bee
text: Okay Chinese food through and through; nothing spectacular here, but nothing bad either. I enjoyed my Sweet and Sour Pork, with a side of Pot Stickers, but I did not leave addicted to either. The Stinky Tofu is pretty popular, but I'm not man enough to order it yet.

name: Tres Tequila Lounge & Mexican Kitchen
text: My company is right across the street and we come to Tres every so often for some boozing. The place is large and has a massive tequila selection, so if you can hang with large amounts of tequila, this is the place to be.The food is pretty good too. I had a Hamburguesa con Queso Oaxaca the other day. Two burger patties with a bunch of string oaxaca cheese in between. The burger was juicy and had a little kick thanks to the jalapeños.

name: Nick’s Crispy Tacos
text: $6 for ONE Taco (Nick's Way) seems a bit excessive, but the taco's tortilla is barely able to contain everything inside. Ultimately, the taco is good, but didn't really blow me away. My coworker said Nick's Crispy Tacos is a "must try" in SF. I told him he better check himself before he wrecks himself.

name: Hong Kong Flower Lounge
text: Yay! Another good dim sum place in the Bay Area, and another point for Millbrae having the nicest selection of Chinese restaurants in the area.The Steamed BBQ Pork Buns had some wonderfully soft bread and were filled with a good amount of juicy pork. The Shanghai Soup Dumplings were also on point. The Shrimp and Pork Shumai were absolutely massive.We also tried the Baked Seafood over Fried Rice with Portuguese Sauce. As a Portuguese person, I give this dish my stamp of delicious approval!

name: CUCINA urbana
text: Cucina Urbana delivers an amazing Italian dining experience from start to finish. I'd highly recommend what my party had to eat because everything was superb. We had the Pepperoni and Fennel Sausage Pizza (pizza isn't authentically Italian but it was still great), the Lasagna al Forno (piping hot and delicious), and the Roasted Strawberry Fregolata (wonderful blend of custard and gelato).

name: Ramen Izakaya Ouan
text: DELISH! The flight of appetizers my group ordered to share were all thoroughly enjoyed. Then the ramen came out. My (extremely inebriated but cultured) friend proclaimed the ramen here is the best he's had outside of Japan. Not sure I can commit to such high praise, but the ramen was in fact pretty damn good. The one thing that was kind of disappointing was how little there was in the bowl of ramen because it was mostly JUST noodles. For $9.25 I don't expect to get a ton of meat and veggies, but I do expect at least more than ONE PIECE of pork chasu.

name: Richard Walker’s Pancake House
text: WOW, OW, YUM!!! That is the sequence of my reactions to the Apple Pancake. WOW -- this thing is massive. OW -- it's really hot. YUM -- it tastes absolutely delicious. What a wonderful experience; if I'm ever in the San Diego area again, I'll have to drop by this place again!

name: Shorehouse Kitchen
text: Shorehouse Kitchen has a lot of things going for it: it's right near the beach, the outdoor seating area is wonderful, the staff is super friendly, and the food is good... BUT not amazing. The Buttermilk Pancakes and Buttermilk Biscuits tasted a bit bland. The Classic Eggs Benedict was good, but again, didn't blow me away. Case in point -- when I asked my friend about our experience, he said he thought the servers were all very attractive, and he didn't even mention the food.

name: Asha Tea House
text: My Bubble Tea was good: the boba was soft and chewy, but I would've liked for the tea to be a bit sweeter. The pre-packaged Liège Waffle was disappointing; I definitely would pass on it next time. This place has a lot of charm so I can see why so many people love it, but it's not my cup of tea... Har har!

name: Fuji Sukiyaki
text: It's not my favorite comfort sushi place (Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose), but it's close in both quality and distance from home. Their fried rolls are pretty awesome. Give me a fried sushi roll with cream cheese in it, like their Jungle Roll, and I'm one happy camper. Funnily enough, like Cha Cha, their Chicken Karaage is nothing to brag about.

name: Bob’s Donut & Pastry Shop
text: WOW WOW WOW! These are some amazing donuts! My favorites are the Maple Cake Donut and the Buttermilk Maple Donut. They have a microwave near the register that you should use to up the deliciousness of your donuts if you're eating them there. Some friends and I attempted the donut challenge. You basically have 3 minutes to each one of their LARGE donuts. It's hard; only 2 out of the 5 of us succeeded, which is above the average 10% pass rate. If you want to take the challenge be sure to call in the day before to reserve a big donut because they sell out fast! I failed the challenge, but still enjoyed the rest of the large donut, AND a Buttermilk Maple Donut afterwards!

name: The Peacock Inn
text: A fancy establishment that doesn't make me feel like a peon. The service is really friendly and down-to-Earth. The food is also amazing. The Ricotta Gnocchi was delicious; the gnocchi was so soft. My main entrée, the Scottish Salmon "En Croute," was also amazing. The salmon was so tender. It melted in my mouth like butter. My old roommate has been wanting to bring me to Peacock Inn for the longest time. After a meal here, I can definitely understand why. It was a great time.

name: As You Like It
text: As You Like It offers a nice selection of hard serve ice cream, and soft serve ice cream flavors beyond the traditional vanilla and chocolate flavors. Drop by and give them a shot -- you won't regret it.

name: Halo Pub
text: I prefer Bent Spoon, but if you're looking for different flavors or for soft serve, go to Halo Pub, as they offer the most variety of flavors in town. It's not my favorite, but it's still pretty awesome.

name: Gabriel’s Fountain Restaurant
text: Gabriel's serves lunch and dinner, but I've only been there to get their ice cream. Because their ice cream offerings are totally LEGIT. Soft serve? Yes. Plenty of hard serve ice cream flavors? Yep. Waffle cones? Sure. Chocolate-covered waffle cones? They've got it. Sprinkles? Hell yes. When it comes to options, Gabriel's just CAN'T be beat.One day, I'll come in and give their lunch or dinner menu a shot. But that means there will be less room for ice cream, which I'm not sure is EVER an option.

name: Usagi
text: "OMG OMG OMG" was my reaction when I first looked at Usagi's menu because it's covered in tons of amazing things. I had the Usagi Burg with Fried Shrimp and Crab Cream Croquette. WOW! It was very good. All the sides were happily devoured. My friend had the Pork Kurobata Curry and it was SO GOOD too. Every time I come to Usagi, I know it's going to be an amazing time because they do Japanese comfort food so dang well. And they are not one-trick-ponies as their menu packs a wide variety of dishes that they prepare oh-so-well!

name: Tandoori Bite Indian Cuisine
text: My favorite Indian restaurant in Princeton. The chef used to work at Mehek, but then decided to open his own restaurant. The chef is an artist who dishes out amazing food. When I attended college, my friends and I visited the old restaurant he used to work at (Mehek) every week, and we NEVER got tired of the food. The lunch buffet is a ridiculously amazingly deal. My favorite dishes here include the creamy and decadent Chicken Makhani, the Vegetable Korma, and Malai Kofta. Some days were amazing and I got all three in the buffet line-up, but even when none made it on the list, I wouldn't even get mad because it's all so good.

name: Minado Restaurant
text: As is the norm with most sushi buffets, you'll be getting a lot of rice, and very little fish with your sushi. It's great if you just want to stuff your face with sushi and don't care much about quality. And guess what? Sometimes I just want to stuff my face with mediocre sushi. But actually, my favorite thing about Minado isn't the sushi, but the Green Tea and Vanilla Soft Serve. MORE PLEASE!

name: White Rose System
text: White Rose System is a 24-hour Jersey diner with a really weird name that serves up pretty good comfort food. The prices are modest, but so are the servings. The ingredients taste fresh, but this place isn't serving up food that will blow your mind. Come in hungry, satisfy your cravings, and leave happy.

name: Pao Quente D’Avenida
text: Sounds like a Portuguese bakery, looks like a Portuguese bakery, and pumps out pastries like a Portuguese bakery, but this place does something MORE than the usual Portuguese bakery: Pasteis de Nata (Custard Cups) infused with chocolate!Chocolate lovers (unfortunately, that does not include me) -- rejoice! You can bite into a tasty custard cup that has a layer of chocolate on the bottom. Even my friend who's not a huge fan of custard cups admitted she was quite taken by this confectionary twist. I'm not a fan of chocolate so I can only judge them on their regular Custard Cups: to be honest, I still prefer Teixeira's, but if you want to change it up, this is the place to try.

name: The Bent Spoon
text: Bent Spoon offers amazing ice cream, cookies, and cupcakes. You just can't go wrong here. Case in point -- while visiting Princeton for 3 days, I somehow ended up visiting Bent Spoon 6 times. It's that DAYUM good. My favorite thing is the Croissant Ice Cream Sandwich -- both innovative and wonderfully tasty.

name: Fruity Yogurt
text: Fruity Yogurt does some things really well. They have a nice selection of frozen yogurt, including some frozen greek yogurt and even soft serve. On the other hand, the mochi toppings my friend got were very stale and the Black Milk Tea I got had an unexpected cinnamon flavor to it. In short, get the froyo, but skip the toppings and bubble tea.

name: Italian Village Pizzeria & Ristorante
text: Popped in today to get some gluten-free pizza. The guy at the front isn't the most enthusiastic person you'll meet, but he took our order and got it going quickly enough.The pizza itself was good. It was hot, and all the ingredients jived well together. The only problem was that the crust was burnt here and there. I can imagine they don't use the gluten-free crusts often, so again, I don't hold this against them too much, but will dock a star for it!

name: Polar Cub
text: Amazing soft-serve for ridiculously low prices. Conveniently located right on Route 22. What more can I say?

name: Cups Frozen Yogurt - CLOSED
text: Cups offers a very, very, VERY nice selection of flavors. They had all my favorites -- NY Cheesecake, Dulce de Leche, Strawberry, Peanut Butter, Vanilla -- and then some! Some of the machines produced yogurt that was a little too runny though. That said, all the flavors still tasted great, not watered down as I feared.

name: Taste of Portugal
text: Pretty good, but too pricey in my opinion, especially in the Ironbound where great eats at better prices can be had. Some of the dishes also aren't authentically Portuguese, but I can't knock them because chicken drizzled in creamy sauce always make me happy.In short, Taste of Portugal is okay. For Portuguese food, I still prefer Portugalia on Ferry Street.

name: Carrabba’s Italian Grill
text: Yes, it's a chain restaurant, but I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Carrabba's. Everything was good and -- occasionally -- GREATNESS was achieved.The basket filled with soft, hot bread with a side of olive oil for dipping was great. I had a half of my mom's Chicken Parmesan (one serving has two HUGE pieces of chicken), and it was also great. I ALSO had a bite of the Rigatoni Martino - mm mm creamy and delicious. They even have a gluten-free menu so my sister could eat without too much worry. But it was the Apple Crostata desert that really sealed the deal. Man, was it freaking amazing! I'm tempted to come visit again (alright, probably more than once) JUST to have this desert again.

name: Palomino
text: Palomino delivers an excellent experience across the board. It's located on the Embarcadero with a nice view of the Bay Bridge. The all-day Happy Hour lets you order tapas all-day, so you can order a lot of different things without feeling disgustingly full.My coworker and I split a bunch of things -- and enjoyed everything! The Portabella Mushroom Soup was awesome: flavorful and thick with an interesting sweet red garnish. The Salsiccia Fresca Pizza had a super thin, super crunchy crust. The Sicilian Meatballs seemed a bit gooey, but I think it's because they inject them with cheesy goodness (ALWAYS a good thing in my book).We definitely enjoyed our visit. The food was great, the ambiance was great, and service was great. Thanks, Palomino!

name: Speederia Pizzeria
text: Awesome, awesome, awesome pizza! My friend and I shared a bunch of different slices and loved every one. The Garlic Chicken Pesto was the farthest from your idea of a "traditional" slice of pizza, but it was great. The Garlic Pizza looks like a Plain Pizza, but has a strong garlicky kick that I really enjoyed. I'm going to make a speedy (har har) return to Speederia!

name: BB Tea Station
text: BB Tea Station is a pretty solid choice for bubble tea in San Francisco. This place reminds me a lot of Tpumps. The boba is really soft and chewy. The tea is good: not too sweet, but not super bitter either. But unlike Tpumps, I got a good amount of boba! Huzzah!

name: Beard Papa’s Cream Puffs
text: Beard Papa's delivers some awesome, decadent treats. The Cream Puffs are amazing and come in many different flavors. I haven't been disappointed with a flavor choice yet, but you can't go wrong with just getting the original flavor. The Cheesecake Sticks are also good, but at times, I sometimes I felt like I was biting into moist pound cake and not rich cheesecake. My waistline isn't always happy when I come to Beard Papa's, but I sure am!

name: Ming Tasty
text: I came here with a bunch of my Asian friends after one mentioned this was his hang-out joint. This place did not disappoint. The food was stellar, the food came out quickly, the staff was friendly, and we even got complimentary dessert. I don't know the names of all the dishes we got, but everything was boss. The guy who frequents this place likes their Congee. Turns out I like it too.Like other Hong Kong-style cafes, this place has a huge menu, so if you come back, you can always try something new.Also, the chairs are purple, and there are shiny tiles on the wall. The design of this place is like a disco hall crossed with a baby girl's bedroom. Can't knock it because even though the interior makes my eyes hurt, it's a clean space, and -- most importantly -- they dish out awesome food.

name: What’s Up Dog
text: Decent hot dogs. I enjoyed a Heart Attack - hopefully the only time you'll hear me say that. It came with chili, extra meat, cheddar cheese, jalapeños, and some other cholesterol-laden stuff. Everything was okay - nothing terrible, yet nothing mind-blowing. If I'm craving a hot dog, I'll drop by again, but this place wasn't good enough to inspire cravings on its own.

name: Fat Wong’s Kitchen
text: I'm not really surprised anymore when I find an awesome Chinese restaurant in Millbrae; this town is PACKED with delicious Chinese food.Everything we ordered was great. I really liked the Barbecue Pork... And secretly wish I had some soft Chinese-style bread to stuff the pork into. The Fried Porkchop was also wonderful - better than a lot of pork katsu I've had at Japanese restaurants. The Braised Beef Brisket was also awesome, especially the broth that doubled as yummy soup. The menu is huge, and I'm an elated first-time customer, so I'll definitely be back!

name: Mayflower Seafood Restaurant
text: Mayflower in one sentence: AWESOME DIM SUM!A bunch of us dropped by at 10 AM (opening). The place was deserted, but the carts were coming out of the kitchen. Everything we tried was good. The Steamed and Baked BBQ Pork Buns (my personal measuring tool of dim sum quality) were both awesome. The Shumai was also on point - containing a massive amount of yummy pork. I'm not sure if it's because we came in super early and the place wasn't that busy, but everyone was really nice to us. One of the servers was so impressed one of us (who wasn't Asian) wanted Chicken Feet. She dropped off the Chicken Feet and then came back with some napkins for him because she knew he'd be needing them. Looking back, I was kind of disappointing to realize that we got no Shanghai Soup Dumplings. I suppose it's something to look forward to next time!

name: Boba Queen
text: You can take the Quickly out of the name, but you can't take the Quickly out of the food quality. It seems this used to formerly be a Quickly. I only tried the Bubble Tea, which was average - exactly what I'd expect out of Quickly. FYI - if this place is really, really like Quickly, then the Asian-style fried snacks are probably great.

name: Toto’s Pizzeria
text: Wow! Toto's is doing some great things. A few months back I popped in and got a Meatball Sandwich that I really enjoyed. I held off on writing a review because who writes a review of a pizzeria without trying the pizza? The time finally arrived, and our meal was great. The Meatball Sliders were good, except the meat was a little dry. Fortunately, we got a bowl of marinara sauce to complement our Cheesy Garlic Bread, which helped moisten up the dry meat. The pizza was great. We got a regular crust plain pizza and a thick crust Pizza a la Toto's No. 5.The one major downside is this place seems a bit lacking in the dining-in experience. There is no table service, so you go up to the register to order. They do bring out your food to you, but don't expect to get refills on your drinks, even when there are plenty of employees loitering behind the counter. That said, there's no table service, so the expectation for service was pretty low.

name: Bona Pizza
text: While waiting to get seated at Cha Cha Sushi, my friends and I popped in for a slice of pizza. We got a personal pizza - small enough to not fill us up, but big enough for us to each get a slice of pizza. It was piping hot and pretty good!I feel kind of bad for this place because it's right next door to the Cha Cha powerhouse. The "angry" signs outside saying people waiting for Cha Cha shouldn't stand in front of Bona Pizza are understandable, but it really seems like Bona Pizza missed a really great opportunity for fostering some interest. Serve pizza by the slice! Give out pizza samples to people waiting in front of your restaurant! Cha Cha doesn't do delivery, so give people a taste of what you have to offer, and maybe you'll be putting your delicious pizza in more people's mouths.

name: CoHo Cafe
text: Okay food at an okay price. I had the Romania Panini. It was good, but fell short of great. The pastrami was a little too chewy so one bite would take with it far too much pastrami. But honestly, the sandwich could've used a little more pastrami in general. My friend had some Vegetarian Chili which was good, and the Salmon Risotto was so creamy.  In short, decent, but could be better with just a few improvements here and there.

name: ETC Dessert Cafe
text: Irving Street is packed with Asian dessert places, but ETC Dessert Cafe is leagues above its neighbors. Not only does it have an awesomely weird name, it is open later than the competition, the service is very friendly, and the drinks and food are great. I enjoyed my smoothie and the Toast with Strawberry and Vanilla Ice Cream. Next time I'm craving some late-night dessert, I'm just going to skip the rest and head to the best: ETC Dessert Cafe.

name: Super Kyo-Po Plaza
text: My fixation with dumplings can NEVER be satisfied. I love all kinds of dumplings, so I decided to pop in and see if they had any Korean-style dumplings. This place DELIVERED with tons of dumplings, including Korean-style kimchi dumplings.The one downside: Compared to the 99 Ranch or Marina, the prices here are STEEP. I can get three bags of Chinese dumplings for less than the price of two here. That said, Korean-style dumplings will now be a permanent fixture in my freezer.

name: Sushirrito
text: The reviews are all over the place, so I was a bit hesitant when I saw a huge line out the door. Oh wells - let's go for it!It wasn't bad at all! My friend and I shared a Salmon Samba and a Sumo Crunch. Both were great, but I think I liked the Sumo Crunch more. It was packed with crab (fake, but good) and one piece of shrimp tempura. The sushirritos were pretty big, but I didn't feel disgustingly full after eating one, unlike a typical visit to its possible Western equivalent: Chipotle.I definitely want to come back and try the Geisha's Kiss; I had a bite of my friends and I NEED MORE!

name: Millbrae Pancake House
text: Pancakes all day!? HELL YEAH!We dropped by for dinner on a Saturday night and the place was pretty much deserted, so there wasn't any wait. But deserted doesn't mean this place doesn't DELIVER. We all enjoyed everything we ordered. The Buttermilk Pancakes were soft and moist. The Swedish Pancakes were also great, especially the lingonberry butter. Regardless of what pancakes I get next time, I'm definitely going to ask for a side of lingonberry butter. The only real disappointment here was the Biscuits and Gravy. An English Muffin is not a biscuit! A biscuit is a biscuit.

name: Ryoko’s
text: Every restaurant that bakes and fries sushi as if they invented it should cower in fear when they find out I love Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose, because NOBODY does it better. Yet I can't help but go into this type of restaurant every time expecting a Cha Cha-level experience.Unfortunately, this place just can't compare. The rolls are priced similarly, but that's where the similarities end. The rolls are much smaller, and the WOW factor just isn't there. My dining partner enjoyed the Kentucky Roll, which has fried chicken -- but I mean, how wrong can you go with fried chicken. I enjoyed the creamy Sexy Roll. The Fried Cheese appetizer was also decadent. The service was extremely friendly, and unlike most places in San Francisco, this place is open until 2 AM. If I'm hankering for untraditional sushi and in the city, I would probably go to Ryoko's again. But if I want a truly amazing dining experience, I'll make the trek down to Cha Cha in San Jose.

name: HRD
text: Sounds like an interesting idea - a Mexican and Korean comfort food fusion joint. Yet, the result isn't anything spectacular. Not bad, but also not great. My Kimchi Burrito with Bulgogi was exactly that - a burrito with kimchi and bulgogi beef. I was hoping for juicier bulgogi, and a more powerful mix of flavors that would make me reconsider how two countries separated by a vast ocean could have cuisines that could ever blend together. But I wasn't so divinely inspired during my meal. Oh wells...

name: CREAM
text: Not the greatest cookies or ice cream in the world, but for only $2.50 you can't help but feel like a total winner. The important thing here is I don't feel ripped off.I wouldn't mind paying $5+ for a more "gourmet" experience, but you know what? Sometimes, I like to get down, cheap, and dirty.

name: Nirvanaah
text: Nirvanaah serves Indian ice cream that HAS to be legit because my friends and I were the only non-Indian people when we dropped by. They have a ton of flavors, and everyone in line with us and the servers behind the counter were happy to help us navigate the flavor lineup.I went with the Paan because the server told me every bite "drives him absolutely crazy." The flavor was powerful, multi-faceted, and reminded me of those seeds you eat on your way out of an Indian restaurant. The Mango flavor tasted like they froze a Mango Lassi. The Apple Custard Pie flavor was pretty good too. I definitely need to come here again because I only covered a small portion of their flavors.

name: Marlowe
text: Marlowe offers up amazing food, with a side of amazing service.Did I mention? The food was AMAZING. We ordered a bunch of appetizers to share and a Marlowe Burger. Our server (also the bartender) told us what order our stuff would come out in; turns out everything we ordered roughly equated to a three-course meal. He even split up items like the soup so we could both gluttonously dive in without worrying about our dining partner's share.We thoroughly enjoyed everything we ordered: Warm Deviled Eggs, Baked Oysters, Roasted Bone Marrow, and the Marlowe Burger. The Marlowe Burger deserves a special shout-out for being one of the most amazing burgers I've ever had. And it was also cooked exactly as I requested. It's really amazing biting into a burger cooked rare! So, so, so juicy! Dessert impressed as well. The Upside Down Strawberry Crisp and the TCHO Chocolate Cream Pie closed out a wonderful meal. My dining partner and I were sitting at the end of the bar. A friend joined us halfway through our meal. I was worried we were going to get hassled for blocking the passage between the dining hall and the kitchen. Instead, we found the staff offering us another stool for the friend to sit next to us.

name: Ramen House Ryowa
text: An awesome little ramen joint that is worth checking out. My Yakisoba Ramen was on point. The soy-based broth was flavorful without being too salty, and the noodles were on point. The only thing that could've been done better were the other toppings: I felt like I was eating ONLY noodles in broth for 90% of my meal. That said, I'll come here again if I'm in the area and craving ramen. I love the hole-in-the-wall seating arrangement here. There are just a bunch of long tables, so it might not be great for large groups, as you will all be sitting in a straight line. That said, someone in my group mentioned wanting some fried rice and the stranger next to us offered to share his because the portion was too large for one person. Now that's MAGIC.Also, there's complimentary kimchi and awesome barley tea!

name: Icebee - CLOSED
text: Decent frozen yogurt with a nice selection of flavors. I sampled the Vanilla, Peanut Butter, Cheesecake, Blueberry, and Strawberry flavors and was all-around impressed with the texture and taste. As expected of things in San Francisco, you'll pay for more than you get, but if you check in on Yelp, you can get a 10% discount off your entire order!

name: Wonderful Dessert & Cafe
text: The Black Milk Bubble Tea was okay: a bit too tart (very coffee-like) for my tastes. I can see why some people might be put off by it. But if the bubble tea doesn't impress you, this place packs another one-two punch. Their fruit smoothies and candy selection is awesome. My Blueberry Smoothie (made with REAL blueberries) was awesome. My friend's Papaya Smoothie (made with REAL papaya) was equally awesome. And I was able to get some SWEDISH FISH!

name: Yogurtland
text: Yogurtland offers an interesting selection of flavors with your standard toppings. The froyo is also some of the creamiest I've had of late!

name: Three Twins Ice Cream
text: YES! Three Twins Ice Cream is amazing. The only difficult part is choosing which flavors you want because pretty much everything sounds and is amazing. I went with Vanilla and Strawberry in a Waffle Cone, and it was amazing. I can't recommend Three Twins enough. Luckily, they sell their ice cream at Whole Foods so I can, for better or worse, ALWAYS get my fix!

name: Cate & Co
text: A 100% gluten-free bakery. The Creme Brûlée Cheesecake is pricey ($6.25 a slice), but you'll need at least two people to even attempt to tackle this rich chunk of cheesecake. The cookies are nothing special. I asked my sister, the gluten-free aficionado in the family, what she thought about this place. She says Mariposa Bakery is way better than Cate & Co. Sorry Cate. For what it's worth, Mariposa doesn't make awesome slices of cheesecake yet!

name: Kara’s Cupcakes
text: The cupcakes can be great, or not so great, depending on the ones you pick. My friend was disappointed when the person behind the counter said the mini cupcake he was getting had filling in it, and then it didn't. Kara's Cupcakes does offer gluten-free cupcakes, which are always bound to please anyone with gluten sensitives. Choose wisely and you'll be happy with Kara's Cupcakes!

name: Pica Pica - CLOSED
text: Pica Pica is 100% gluten-free and reminds me of the iconic Pokémon: PIKACHU!!!The Arepas are delicious. I had Pulled Pork Pernil Arepa, and my sister and friend had the Grilled Chicken Arepas. We all agreed that the pork one was superior. The Yuca Fries are also good... all 6 of them in the order! The price isn't outrageous given this place is in a fancy downtown Napa food court, and the portion sizes are reasonable. Fortunately, there are plenty of places to get dessert within eyesight!

name: Minako Organic Japanese Restaurant - CLOSED
text: I'm really torn about Minako. So many things were great, but at the same time, there were some serious shortcomings.GREAT - The menu is amazing for people with gluten allergies or people who hate meat or animal-derived products. GOOD - The service is great; the staff is so friendly and willing to walk you through every question you have. OKAY - Unfortunately, the food is JUST okay. Nothing really stood out and blew us away. Among everything we had, the Corn Tempura and Chicken Katsu stood out as better than the rest. BAD - The price for our meal was pretty steep. Our wallets left a lot lighter and our stomachs not much fuller (read: we were still hungry). I don't mind dropping money when the food is great. Yet, I felt somewhat jipped as we left Minako.In short, wonderful service and great for people with special dietary concerns, but the food won't be amazing and you will pay dearly.

name: Three Bees Coffee House
text: A quaint little coffee shop in downtown San Mateo. My sister enjoyed her Cappuccino, and I was really into the pre-packaged muffin-cookie hybrids. They also have gluten-free cookies and brownies.

name: Jane on Fillmore
text: The guy behind the counter didn't have a tie. He didn't have a bow tie. He had a small padlock on his collar. LATFH! Jokes aside, this place is dope. They have plenty of delicious baked goods, including a nice selection of gluten-free options, that are in their own gluten-free display case! The gluten-free Banana Bread was large, moist, and packed with flavor. The Peanut Butter Cookie would've been better if it didn't have quinoa, but it wouldn't be very hip without it.

name: Glaze Teriyaki
text: Simple, but well-executed teriyaki dishes. They make all their teriyaki glazes from scratch, and even offer a gluten-free glaze. My only complaint is that you pay nearly $10 for a salad, two scoops of rice, and a meager amount of meat. Yes, it's San Francisco, so I never expect my dollar to go very far.

name: Radish
text: Radish is a really awesome brunch joint. Make a reservation because this isn't a hidden gem; if you show up without a reservation, you will probably need to wait.My dining party enjoyed everything we ordered. I was stuck between the Shrimp Po' boy and the Pancakes, and ended up going with the po' boy. It was good, but in retrospect, I should've gone with the pancakes because they looked REAL GOOD. They also offer gluten-free options for most of their items. And to compliment your amazing meal, you probably will be able to scope out some SF-bros pounding bottomless mimosas. And I can't forget to mention that you'll be dining in the BEST city in the universe with the BEST people in the universe!

name: Hobee’s Restaurant
text: Nothing mind-blowing at Hobee's Restaurant; it's a quaint, diner-esque brunch joint that provides a decent and comfortable meal. The staff is very friendly and accommodating. They also provide gluten-free pancakes, french toast, tacos, and burgers; my sister really enjoyed her gluten-free pancakes.In short, the food isn't amazing, but I never regret the occasional stop at Hobee's.

name: Boba Guys
text: The tea is okay. The bubbles are pretty good. My friend really didn't enjoy the grass jelly. In short -- not amazing, just okay.

name: Blossom Bee
text: Wow! I'm so disappointed Blossom Bee is so far away from where I live because they make some AMAZING crepes. Aside from the traditional savory and sweet crepes most other creperies offer, Blossom Bee also makes crepes stuffed with Thai curries! My Massaman Crepe was off the freaking hook! The side of Potato Soup was also delicious. This place is so good, I might just make the occasional pilgrimage to Dublin for some DELICIOUS and unique crepes.

name: Brasserie S&P
text: Fancy in price, with fancy (small) portions, Brasserie serves pretty good food. Even though there was a lot of "fancy" in that last sentence, they didn't seem to mind me dining there in a tracksuit. My sister enjoyed her Steak Frites and my Chicken Breast dish (with creamy mashed potatoes) was pretty awesome too. The dishes themselves may be considered a tad overpriced, but we were both fully satisfied with our dining experience. For those with gluten sensitivities, they can prepare most items on their menu without gluten!

name: New England Lobster Market & Eatery
text: WOAH! Who knew sitting on the "lesser known" side of 101 was this wonderful lobster-dishing gem? It's pricey, but so very, very solid.The Dressed Lobster Roll was tasty and classy (Read: not drenched in mayonnaise). The lobster was good, but the bread was also awesome. My only complaint is that for $17.50, I was hoping for a little more lobster. It's high-quality lobster, but it would've been nice to get a little more. That said, I'm DEFINITELY coming back here. Up next -- their Dungeness Crab Roll!

name: The Iron Gate
text: My dining partner and I came here to celebrate an anniversary. What a treat it was! We really enjoyed our visit.The Crab Cake and Cream of Broccoli and Chicken Soup got things started off on a high note, although the Crab Cake would eventually be the low point of an otherwise wonderful evening. The Steak Diane Flambe, which is cooked right in front of you, is covered in some DELICIOUS sauce. The massive and juicy Ribeye Steak kept my dining partner (and eventually me) occupied for a while. For dessert, the Soufflé (chocolate for her, mixed berries for me), was awesome. Our server, Carlos, was awesome. He was always around when we needed him, kindly answered any questions we had, and was the cherry on top of our awesome time at The Iron Gate.

name: In-N-Out Burger
text: I can get a Double Double Animal Style and Animal-Style fries at 1 in the morning? HELL. YEAH.

name: Smitten Ice Cream
text: They do some Harry Potter-esque magic with liquid nitrogen to make the smoothest ice cream I've ever had. That said, besides the novelty of ice cream made in your face, there are plenty of downsides, which makes me hesitant to come back. It takes time to make, they are slow, the flavor selection isn't extensive, it's expensive, and you can't get more than one flavor.Worst of all, their waffle cones have holes in the bottom. I'm paying an arm and a leg to have ice cream dripping all over the floor. Such sadness!

name: Quickly
text: The bubbles in the bubble tea are pretty good, but the tea itself is pretty mediocre.But where Quickly truly shines is with their amazing line-up of Asian-style snacks. Everything I've tried, I've liked. The Popcorn Chicken rocks, the Potstickers are crispy, the Cheese Spam Musubi is awesome, and the Pop Dogs are ridiculously and ingeniously amazing. Even though I always consume a ton of fried food when I visit Quickly, I still feel like a champ afterwards.

name: ABC Bakery & Cafe
text: ABC Bakery Cafe is good, but it's like a lesser version of Cafe Salina in Millbrae. The menu is large, but not as large as Salina's. The food is good, but not as good as Salina's. The waiters are cool, but not as cool as Salina's. It's got one thing going for it: it's open later than Cafe Salina.But if you held a gun to my head and told me to point you to the best Hong Kong style cuisine place in the area, ABC is not it.

name: Sharetea - MOVED
text: It's come to the point where every time I get bubble tea at some place other than Sharetea, I REGRET IT. Sharetea is the bomb, and it has definitely earned 5 star recognition.The tea is consistently great, plenty of boba is given, and the staff is friendly. I love, love, LOVE the Okinawa Bubble Tea. The Hokkaido Milk Tea is great, as is the QQ Family Special if you're into all sorts of toppings. Sorry Tpumps -- Sharetea is the BEST bubble tea place in town!

name: Five Guys Burgers and Fries
text: Great burger, hot dogs, and fries. I went with the Mini (only one burger patty instead of two) Bacon Cheeseburger and a Bacon Cheese Hot Dog. Both were great. I tried both the Cajun and Regular Fries and definitely enjoyed the slightly spicy Cajun ones more.In the eternal duel, I prefer In-N-Out, but my friend likes Five Guys more. Today, we can all be winners -- they both serve great burgers.

name: Tmix - MOVED
text: 3 star bubble tea + 1 star for very friendly staff. The tea wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. If you're in the area, there aren't many options -- beggars can't be choosers!

name: East Ocean Seafood Restaurant
text: I was excited when I finally made it over to the Easy Bay to check this place out. While everything was okay, nothing really impressed anyone in my party. When I asked what everyone's favorite item was, no one felt anything was deserving of the honor of being "a favorite."Case in point -- the Pork Buns. The steamed ones were good, but could have used a little more meat. The baked ones were cold. I love Pork Buns, but not these.

name: Jang Mo Jip
text: Great Korean food across the board once you can find it. It's in Seoul Plaza - a little complex that you can drive into. Jang Mo Jip is in suite 100 which is right inside the arch you drive through to get to all the other stores inside the plaza.The Mandu (fried potstickers) was exceptionally crispy. The Seafood Pancake was one of the best I've had. The Fried Chicken was juicy and drenched in that bright-red-yet-not-super-spicy red sauce. Would definitely come here again if I were craving more than Korean Fried Chicken. If I just want chicken, 99 Chicken across the street still serves the best damn fried chicken in town.

name: BN Chicken
text: The menu here is small, and quite frankly, unimpressive. The Korean Fried Chicken Wings were good, but given all the other amazing Korean restaurants within walking distance, good just doesn't cut it.

name: So Gong Dong Tofu House
text: My friends and I got some take-out from here. The Banchan (set of appetizers) was good; I really enjoyed the rice noodles and kimchi. The Mandu (fried dumplings) were also good. The Seafood Pancake was more eggy than usual and reminded me of a frittata. The BBQ Pork Bibimbap was good, but had a very meager amount of meat.

name: Jin’s Bakery & Coffee - MOVED
text: Korean bakeries are awesome and Jin's Bakery is the bomb. Everything we tried was fresh, soft, and filled our hearts with unadulterated joy. Just go in, grab anything that looks good to you, and you'll walk out with a good-time-in-a-bag.The lady working here is also very sweet. She happily talked about all the items we were interested in. She even gave us a sample of the Red Bean Donut because she wanted us to experience its awesomeness. She was right - it was great!

name: 99 Chicken
text: After visiting a bunch of other Korean fried chicken joints, I've realized that 99 Chicken isn't deserving of 4 stars. Because it's really the best of the best. I can't get enough of 99 Chicken, and I haven't even tried all their flavors yet. Friends I bring along to this wonderful place also agree - 99 Chicken is ridiculously awesome.

name: Tous Les Jours
text: YES! Tous Les Jours in the Bay Area! God bless the soul who made this happen. Now, whenever I want, I can get my fix for the original Milk Bread and Strawberry Milk Bread. The bread is so light, fluffy, and filled with cream. Every bite is a bite of heaven!In addition to their wonderful milk bread, they also do a bunch of other amazing things. Anything with a sausage in it is likely to blow your mind. Their Blueberry Cream Cheese Bread is also amazing. They also make decent bubble tea.AHHHHH!!!! I LOVE IT! I WANT IT! I NEED IT NOW!

name: Sheng Kee Bakery
text: Sheng Kee offers a decent selection of baked goods. In general, things range from mediocre to pretty good. Here are some highlights: - Baked BBQ Pork Bun - In my humble opinion, the true test of a Chinese bakery. The ones at Sheng Kee are good: soft bread, lots of juicy meat, and large. I ate three in one day and that made my day pretty awesome.- Portuguese Custard Tart - I grew up eating the best Portuguese Custard Cups in the world at Teixeira's Bakery in Newark, NJ. The ones at Sheng Kee are good, but I wouldn't cry tears of joy at the sight of them. Yes, I'm a snob. Yes, I'm Portuguese. So take my word for it.- Cream Cheese Toast - I love cream cheese, so I bought some sliced cream cheese toast bread. The cream cheese isn't evenly spread throughout the entire loaf, so some bites are awesome, but most are just average.- Blueberry Cream Cheese Pastry - Awesome! Soft, flaky crust filled with a good amount of blueberry jam and cream cheese.

name: Good Bites Cafe
text: A cute, quaint, mom-and-pop, hole-in-the-wall Filipino brunch joint. The food isn't fancy, but it definitely hits the spot. The breakfast combos get you meat, garlic fried rice, and  two eggs prepared however you like them. I enjoyed my Hotsilog (hot dog) and my dining partner enjoyed the Longsilog (sweet sausage). My only complaint is the garlic fried rice didn't really taste as garlicky as I was hoping for.

name: Saffron Indian Bistro
text: Woah! This place is awesome! Start to finish, my dining party was impressed. We all left happy, although a little uncomfortably full of the delicious food that we weren't able to resist.The Shubnum Curry (Vegetable/Navaratan Korma) was some of the best I've had. The Saag Panner and Malai Kofta were also spot on. The Cheese Naan, served with some tikki masala sauce, was to die for. In short, this is some seriously good Indian food.On top of all this, the service was fast and friendly. Once again, San Carlos is proving to be a real hotbed of great cuisine in the Bay Area.

name: Super Duper Burgers
text: The burger was good, the Fresh Strawberries Super Shake was great, and the Garlic Fries were awesome. But the Strauss Soft-Serve Ice Cream is what really won me over. It's kind of weird how hard it is to find soft-serve ice cream these days, so when a place can do burgers, fries, shakes, and soft-serve ice cream, we've got a REAL winner on our hands.

name: Marina Food
text: I'm addicted to dumplings and dim sum. To satisfy my cravings at odd hours of the day, I have to rely on restaurants being open late at night. Many nights, tears of addiction were shed when no one around town was willing to serve me dumplings.But then I found Marina - specifically, the aisle filled with dumplings and frozen dim sum. Now, I rely on no one. I am my own supplier. I AM THE ONE WHO KNOCKS when I crave dumplings.

name: Quickly
text: I always expect everything at Quickly to be just average, but this place makes great Asian-style desserts. There bubble tea definitely doesn't impress me, but I really like their Takoyaki, Fried Popcorn Chicken, and Potstickers.

name: Ocha Tea Café
text: The Tapioca Bubble Tea was good (not great), but the Corn Dog was pretty awesome. I'll be coming back because, from the looks of it, their other snacks are also pretty dang good.

name: Lahore Karahi
text: This place is DOPE! From start to finish, absolute greatness was delivered to our table. The Lamb Samosa appetizer was great. The Vegetable Korma and Chicken Makhani were hits. In general, the food had a bit of kick to it, but it was never too spicy. The Mango and Cashew Indian Ice Cream sealed the deal on our great meal. I can't believe I'm saying this, given the somewhat shady neighborhood, but I actually want to come back!

name: Jersey Joe’s Hoagies & Cheesesteaks
text: This Jersey boy is far from home, but Jersey Joe's took me back to my hoagie-pounding days in Dirty Jersey. Let's start with appetizers. The Chili Cheese Fries were totally on point. The Mozzarella Sticks were good. Next time, I'll pass on the Jalapeño Poppers. I was hoping for them to be filled with cream cheese, but was disappointed to find them filled cheese whiz instead.The star of the show did not disappoint. My Cheesesteak with peppers, onions, and mushrooms was awesome. I was worried about the amount of cheese given some of the reviews here. When I got my hoagie, I really couldn't see any cheese.
