But every bite had a magical infusion of cheese, so my worries quickly disappeared.Also, they have a ton of cool Jersey, Philly signs and swags. There is some San Francisco stuff too, but we all know San Francisco can't ever roll EAST COAST STYLE.

name: Eggettes
text: Came in on a Friday night and this place was packed with loud (and somewhat obnoxious) high schoolers. Can't knock them too much because I thought being loud and obnoxious was cool too, back in the day.The bubble tea was okay, and the regular eggette was pretty good.

name: Hard Water
text: My company had a small party here to celebrate the new year. I'm no connoisseur of alcohol, but the amount and variety of whiskey here was impressive; shelves upon shelves of whiskey with a sliding ladder to access even higher shelves.The hors d'oeuvre were awesome. The Pork Belly Cracklings, Fried Chicken Bites with Waffle and Pepper Jelly, and Andouille Sausage Grits with Spicy Slaw were my favorites. I'd come back for some more of these tasty dishes.Caveat - no bathroom in the actual establishment. You need to use the public restroom that's outside and around the corner. It's clean, so I won't knock it too much.

name: Sushi Monster
text: For deep-fried and baked sushi goodness, Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose is the best and Yokohama in Redwood City sits comfortably in second. After a visit to Monster Sushi, the line-up hasn't changed because Monster Sushi gets the Bronze Medal of Deep-Fried Sushi Goodness.The deep-fried North and South (eel, crab, green onion) was pretty good, but then again - when isn't a ball of fried rice awesome? The two baked rolls we tried - the Lion King and Victoria's Secret - were very underwhelming. The fish didn't taste fresh and the most prominent flavor in each was plain old rice. The Jalapeño Bombs were good, but not nearly as good as the ones at Cha Cha Sushi. In short, it's JUST OKAY, but you can DEFINITELY do better if you're willing to drive a bit.

name: New York Pizza
text: +1 for a RIDICULOUSLY AWESOME Crab Melt sandwich that is supposedly made with REAL crab. I say supposedly because it's large, yet cheap ($8.99) given how expensive crab is. +1 for serving large slices of pizza. One of their slices is like two slices anywhere else. If you don't plan accordingly, don't worry - pizza reheats really well. +1 for offering whole wheat and gluten-free crusts. +1 for being open late (11 PM) relative to all the other restaurants in the area.-1 for calling itself New York Pizza but being no where near the quality of pizza you can get in NYC. It's not terrible, but it doesn't really stand out either.

name: Alexander’s Steakhouse
text: Alexander's serves up pricey food, but it's worth the price and you won't have to deal with unneeded snobbery that oftentimes accompanies pricey restaurants. Their steaks are awesome. My medium-rare 10 oz. Filet Mignon was bloody amazing. The Butternut Squash Soup appetizer was also wonderful. To top off your expensive meal, and to make sure you never think this place is TOO FANCY, you'll be served some complimentary cotton candy at the end!

name: Yoppi Frozen Yogurt
text: Decent frozen yogurt with some sorbet options, and a good variety of toppings. You'll need to spend at least $5 to use your credit card so fill that cup past the brim if you don't have any cash on you!

name: I Dumpling
text: This hole-in-the-wall restaurant sports a gimmicky name, but dishes out some seriously good dim sum cuisine. The Shanghai Steamed Dumplings were filled with a ridiculous amount of juicy broth. The Pork and Chive Dumplings and Pork Pot Stickers were also great. The Beef Pancake was also one of the best I've tasted. Unfortunately, the Green Onion Pancake was really bland, and ended up being the only disappointing item.+1 for having only one lady working the entire front end, who still manages to have a friendly disposition!

name: Red Hot Wok
text: Not going to lie - Taiwanese cuisine just isn't my favorite style of Chinese cuisine. I really prefer Cantonese-style food above all others. While the authentic Taiwanese cuisine served here isn't my cup of tea, all the food was fresh and impressed my friends who are more familiar with the cuisine (i.e. my Asian friends). What I did enjoy was the Shaved Ice. We tried the Milk, Taro, and Mango-flavored shaved ice. All of them were awesome. I couldn't decide whether I liked the Taro or Mango flavor better.

name: Attic
text: My friend was so excited to bring me here; she had Garlic Noodles during her first visit and loved them. After our most recent visit, her enthusiasm for Attic has diminished quite significantly. The Sweet Potato Fries with Banana Ketchup were pretty good and my friend enjoyed the Bone Marrow dish. The Sizzling Sisig was a major disappointment. The meat was too chewy and tasted old. We got it with an egg and our waiter told us to flip it over to let it cook on the "really hot" serving plate. We waited for a while, but our egg was never close to cooking itself. The Kimchee Fried Rice was okay, but nothing mind-blowing.Looks like the menu is filled with great items and not-so-great items. Tread carefully, friends!

name: BAMBU
text: A welcome change to bubble-tea-inundated San Mateo. My friend got a #10 and really digged it. I got the special Hot Coconut Milk with Taro and loved it. The coconut milk was great and when I finished it, I had a bunch of soft taro at the bottom of my cup to gobble up.

name: Gangnam Chicken
text: Not quite at the level of 99 Chicken in Santa Clara, but the food here is awesome. The Soy and Garlic Fried Chicken was juicy, flavorful, and packed a little kick. The Seafood Pancake was great: super crispy and loaded with tons of varied sea critters.Also - OPPA GANGNAM CHICKEN!

name: Great Eastern Restaurant
text: A SUPER SOLID dim sum place in Chinatown. We tried 18 things and were generally impressed with everything that came out. Some things worth noting:* Pan-Fried Pork Buns - This was actually the only thing that really disappointed everyone. It was just blah - the bread didn't really feel pan-fried and the meat inside was bland.* Golden Pumpkin Fries - Not as good as the ones at Champagne Restaurant (Millbrae), but still stand-out and pretty damn amazing. Parking is also surprisingly easy for San Francisco. Park in the Portsmouth Square Garage on Kearny Street. Bring your parking ticket with you as most restaurants, including this one, will validate it (gives you two free hours). At $3 an hour, even if you spend some additional time in Chinatown, you won't be getting ripped off.

name: Town of Dumpling
text: A nice little hole-in-the-wall Chinese place that dishes out good dumplings and dim sum dishes. In general, we enjoyed everything we ordered. The Shanghai Soup Dumplings were really, really good. So good that they are competing for the top position in my soup dumpling book. On the other hand, the Green Onion Pancake was really flavorless, and tasted like cardboard. Yuck!I buy frozen dumplings from here and cook them at home in a vegetable steamer. It's a great system as I get to have amazing dumplings at any time!

name: Masa Sushi and Grill
text: This place is awesome. It does authentic Japanese stuff well and even does some more Americanized stuff, which I'm a big fan of. The 81 Allendale (salmon, crab, avocado, CREAM CHEESE, asparagus, katsu crunch) is far from authentic, but it's DAMN EPIC. On the other end of authenticity, the Nabeyaki Udon (with a side of delicious Inari Sushi) was also amazing. Every time I come here, regardless of what I try, I'm impressed. GG Masa.

name: Teixeira Bakery
text: Texeira's makes the best pasteis de nata I've had in the world -- Portugal included! Not only are they delicious, they are also ridiculously affordable. I've always got pasteis de nata on my mind. Fun fact: This bakery, located on Ferry Street, makes the pasteis de nata. The one on Kossuth makes the bread. The bakeries each stock one another's goods, so you'll have no problem at either. But if you want to "pick'em while they're fresh," pick the right bakery!

name: Tous Les Jours
text: I first fell in love with Tous Les Jours during a summer in South Korea; the Pure Milk Cream Bread had me at first bite. There were Tous Les Jours in the USA, but unfortunately none in the Bay Area where I live. Fortunately, this love story has a happy ending -- I discovered recently with great joy that there's a Tous Les Jours near my parent's house!The one true gem is the Pure Milk Bread. It's everything I want in a bun: soft, sweet bread filled with a good amount of light, and evenly distributed cream. The Pink Milk Bread puts a strawberry twist on this delightful bun. The Blueberry Cream Cheese Bread is another winner: a bit more rigid than the soft bun of the Milk Bread, but filled with some awesome blueberry cream cheese that has whole blueberries in it!I can't lie, I can't hide it, and I can't deny it... I love you, Tous Les Jours. Now please come to the Bay Area so I can have you ALL THE TIME!

name: Chantal Guillon Macarons & Teas
text: Awesome macarons. Friendly staff. Gluten-free, yet still delicious.I learned during a recent visit that the Speculos-Raspberry flavor contains gluten. Earlier in the month, I purchased some of these at the San Francisco store unaware that they contained gluten. Fortunately, my sister is allergic -- but not deathly allergic -- to gluten.

name: Paris Baguette
text: During a recent visit to South Korea (the less cool one), I fell in love with Tous Les Jours: a Korean Bakery dishing out some wonderfully decadent baked goods. In particular, I fell in love with the delicious Milk Cream Bread. There aren't any Tous Les Jours in the Bay Area, but there are Paris Baguettes (also a Korean bakery) so I dropped by looking for the cream bread.I was hoping Paris Baguette would stock it, but every time I come in, they never seem to have them. The closest I've gotten is Chocolate Cream Bread, but I despise chocolate. I still enjoy my visits because they have a bunch of different items that are enjoyable, but nothing ever really wows me like that bread at Tous Les Jours did. Here's to hoping one day I can hit the jackpot and Tous Les Jours opens a bakery nearby!

name: MaMa Ji’s
text: After one visit, MaMa Ji's has made a really great first impression. Everything we got was good. Out of the feast we ordered, I really enjoyed the Fried Pumpkin with Egg Yolk, the Seafood Shumai, and the massive Pan-Fried Pot Stickers. My dining partner loved their Crispy Eggplant. If you want something green, try the Stir Fried Pea Leaves in Garlic Sauce.As always, I got some Steamed BBQ Pork Buns; the bread was soft, but there could've been more pork inside. The Shanghai Dumplings were good, but not the best I've had in the Bay Area (that prize goes to Panda Dumpling in San Carlos). Dessert was awesome. My dining party really enjoyed their Seared Pumpkin Cake. They also serve cookies from Black Jet Bakery: my friend was into their Oreo Cookies and I devoured a delicious Peanut Butter cookie and a Granola with Cream cookie. In short, tons of enjoyment from start to finish. Thanks, MaMa Ji's!

name: Pampas
text: This place is awesome...a bit TOO AWESOME in fact.You'll get the urge to dig into their wonderful cheesy bread, fried plantains, and everything the sidebar has to offer, but that's all just filler for the real prize: MEAT. LOTS OF IT. I'm never disappointed with the selection of meats Pampas offers; during my most recent visit, I was QUITE taken with the coriander-laced Pork Loin and marinated Beef Tenderloin Filet Tips. Also, during the holiday season, you can get rodizio FOR LUNCH! Save some room for dessert because it comes with the meal, and my Coconut Flan wasn't half bad!

name: The Ice Cream Bar
text: I like the idea behind the Ice Cream Bar: a retro place where you can get sundaes, floats, alcoholic ice cream drinks, and traditional ice cream in a cone. But at the end of the day, the entire experience falls short of amazing.I got a Keller's Farm Sundae (cornmeal shortbread, creme fraiche ice cream, morello cherry ice cream, cherry sauce and rosemary syrup) and it was awesome. I'm not normally a big fan of cherry-flavored ice cream, but their Morello Cherry ice cream had me hooked. Then I tried their Brioche Bread Pudding. Yuck! The thing was too freaking sweet. The bread pudding itself was squishy and didn't really have any flavor that I could pick out from the suffocating wave of sugar.I give them three stars because they are walking off the beaten path when it comes to ice cream. If you can dodge their duds, this place isn't half bad!

name: Seiya Japanese Restaurant
text: We ordered mostly cooked food and were not disappointed. The Great Balls of Fire was good. The decadent Kobe Beef Roll melted in my mouth, although my dining partner didn't really care for the ginger garnish. The Hanabi Roll (California Roll topped with baked salmon) was also awesome. The Butabara (Pork Belly) Skewer was juicy and tender. The Kani Korokke (crab croquettes) were super creamy -- a GREAT thing in my book.  The food definitely earned four stars; we enjoyed everything we ordered. Yet at the end of the day, the price-to-wow ratio was too low. Everything was really pricey, the portions were rather small, and the food was good, but didn't blow us away -- so minus a star.

name: Sweet Inspiration
text: $6.50 for a slice of cake? Yes, but this place does not serve you mere slices of cake; the portions are MASSIVE. Like, 1/6th of a cake per slice. Like, bring friends because you don't want all the guilt that comes with eating even ONE of their servings.My Banana Fresh cake was good: three layers of Banana Bread Cake with whipped cream in between each layer. The whipped cream was awesome and the banana bread was good, but nothing spectacular. Same goes for my friend who got the Black Forest Chocolate Cake; good, but nothing amazing. I got a Peanut Butter Cookie too and that was pretty good. Shout-out to the guy behind the counter - Davin - who was friendly, funny, and helped us navigate the myriad of cakes we had to pick from.

name: Bierhaus
text: The Euphoria burger was aptly named as it provided an absolutely euphoric experience. Every bite just melted in my mouth. The horseradish aioli contributed a lot to the creamy texture and rich flavor. The grass-fed beef patty itself was juicy and flavorful. The side of fries were pretty decent too.I'll definitely be coming back to Bierhaus to try their other burgers.

name: Izakaya Roku
text: Butter Corn - This dish made me feel like I was at some Japanese temple training to be a samurai because eating corn with chopsticks is an EXERCISE IN PATIENCE. But you can't really complain when what you're working for happens to be corn lathered in butter, sprinkled with chunks of bacon.Takoyaki - Your standard piping hot, fried octopus balls.Sausage with Cheese Sauce - This dish was cool: four spicy sausages lathered in mozzarella cheese.  I thought the fun was over once we ate all the sausages, but the cheese stuck to the bottom of the pan began to crisp, yielding delicious results. Roku's Okonomiyaki - We came here because my dining partner was craving this exact dish. It was good, but it would have been nice to get some more sauce on it because towards the end, I was just eating the cabbage plain. Tonpei Yaki - An omelette with pork, cabbage, and topped with mustard and mayonnaise? YES, PLEASE. Really delicious dish!Deep-Fried Swimming Crab Legs - Gah! I was hoping this dish didn't come with the shell still on the crab legs because I hate working for my food. Even though the shell was soft enough after frying to just eat, I wasn't feeling it. Fortunately, my dining partner is a hard-working eater and took care of all the legs.

name: Yokohama
text: Yokohama isn't quite on the level of Cha Cha in San Jose, but it's much closer to where I live and they do a pretty good job with their cooked rolls.Pork Gyoza - This gyoza has the most crispy shell I've ever had... And I didn't mind at all!Special California Roll (real crab, avocado) - A California Roll with REAL crab. The real, shredded crab gives this roll a unique texture, but aside from that it's just the Plain Jane of sushi rolls. Overall, the roll could do with a little more crab. T.N.T. Roll (spicy tuna, cream cheese, jalapeño, deep fried) - PARTY'S HERE! One DAMN GOOD deep-fried roll that was on par with what I expect of Cha Cha!Volcano Roll (spicy scallop, with more scallop) - I was expecting something cooked, but what we got was a mountain of scallop (the volcano) surrounded by a simple fresh roll with some spicy red sauce. It wasn't bad, but definitely didn't blow me away.Lion King (crab meat, avocado, baked salmon, tobiko, spicy mayo sauce) - This roll just melts in your mouth. Comparable with Cha Cha's except you get less baked salmon on top; I wouldn't mind paying for more salmon to do this roll some TRUE JUSTICE.Mochi Ice Cream - We got all four flavors they had that evening: Chocolate, Green Tea, Strawberry, and Mango. My favorite was Strawberry, hers was Chocolate. Neither of us cared much for the Green Tea which, oddly enough, tasted kind of soapy. Green Tea Ice Cream - Unlike the Green Tea Mochi Ice Cream, this ice cream was a much better at executing on its green tea flavor. Not too sweet and a bit bitter, but that's what you expect of Green Tea Ice Cream.In short - I'll be back and I'm going to focus on their cooked and fried rolls because there's a lot of potential for an amazing meal here.

name: HF Sandwich Shop
text: - Decent gluten-free sandwiches. My sister and I shared a Meatball Sandwich and a Church Square Chicken Parm. We enjoyed them both, and the gluten-free bread didn't fall apart!- The Church Square Chicken Parm Sandwich isn't really chicken parmesan since the chicken isn't fried; it's just a piece of grilled chicken with tomato sauce. - $2.50 surcharge for gluten-free sandwiches. This shop was established because the owner's son is super sensitive to gluten and he wanted a place where his son could eat without worrying. Not sure if he wants his son to live in a world where there is a 25% fee for having an allergy.- No seating inside. They used to have it, but fire regulations did away with it. Kind of disappointing for those who drive into town for a gluten-free sandwich in the winter, but have to wait until they get home to enjoy it.

name: 28 BBQ
text: When moving out of Newark, one thing my family and I were all going to miss was the amazing churrasqueiras: BBQ joints known for pumping out amazing barbecue chicken. Fortunately, Somerset County has a Churrasqueira Champion in 28 BBQ.It's the trifecta of amazing: the food is great, the servings are large, and the price is reasonable. My family digs their BBQ Chicken, Pork Cutlets, and BBQ Short Ribs. These all come with a side of yellow rice (with a few veggies here and there), and fries or beans. While everything mentioned above is awesome, my favorite dish is their Cheesesteak Sandwich. It's not Philly-style where the meat is minced into small pieces. Here, you'll get a thin, whole piece of steak that packs a lot of wonderful smoky BBQ flavor. The cheese, onions, peppers, and soft bread make every bite decadent. The only thing that could make this bad boy better is if they served it on a Portuguese Roll instead of the generic bun they use. Thanks, 28 BBQ, for delivering some DELICIOUS Portuguese food.

name: Thomas Sweet Ice Cream & Chocolate
text: T-Sweets has a energetic and friendly staff ready to serve you all sorts of ice cream concoctions. I ordered the Vanilla and Pumpkin Pie Soft Serve, which might've been a mistake. The Vanilla was bland and the Pumpkin Pie flavor wasn't as strong as I had hoped.Next time I visit, I'll try their regular ice cream and blend-ins; I have faith this place can earn a solid 4 stars if I order the right stuff!

name: I’s Cafe
text: Decent bubble tea: not too sweet, comes with a good amount of super chewy boba, and they don't pack it with tons of ice.They have macarons too, but these were disappointing. They keep them chilled so you can't enjoy them then and there because they are best eaten at room temperature. Even after waiting for them to warm up, the macarons were like Oreos: two crunchy cookies with filling in between. In short - go for the bubble tea, skip the macarons.

name: Bridgewater Commons
text: When we moved from Newark to Bridgewater, I was dreading having to drive longer distances to go shopping. Fortunately, Bridgewater has an awesome mall right in town, and it has everything I need: a movie theatre, a food court, a Gamestop to satisfy my gaming addiction, an Express when I need a new wardrobe, and an Apple Store for when my gadgets kick the bucket. Just outside the mall is a Chipotle and a Best Buy in case you are a true American, and need a massive burrito or an even more massive electronics store.

name: Whole Foods Market
text: I've never been to such a large Whole Foods Market: you can fit more than 2 carts side by side in each aisle! This place has a huge bakery and plenty of gluten-free items too. As usual with Whole Foods, everything is fresh, the store is clean and well-organized, and the staff is friendly and helpful.

name: Portugalia Bar & Restaurant
text: Whenever I visit home, Portugalia is the restaurant my family goes to for our meal out. The food is authentically Portuguese and delicious. If you dine at the bar or restaurant while there's a soccer game, you'll even get a side of Portuguese guys yelling at the TV.I love the Mini Prego: a thin slice of beef on a mini bun. With such soft bread, and juicy, tender meat, it's my go-to appetizer. You can't go wrong with the daily specials. If you're coming with a bunch of people, you can order a bunch of entrees and share. There will likely still be leftovers because their portions are MASSIVE.Dessert leaves something to be desired. They prepare everything in the morning and then keep it all refrigerated. It's not bad, but it won't blow you away. I'd skip dessert here and just grab a Pastel de Nata at Teixeira's around the corner.

name: Hamburgao
text: You add the "ão" suffix to Portuguese words to describe huge things. The burger here could just be called a "hamburga," but that doesn't quite do these burgers justice. Because Hamburgão's burgers are, quite simply, incredibly large and in charge. Whenever I'm back home, I always make a point to stop by Hamburgão for my "large burger" fix.I always go with the trusty Cheese Tudo: burger patty, mozzarella, ham, bacon, fried egg, potato sticks, lettuce, tomatoes, mayo, and corn. This thing is massive, and costs under seven bucks to boot! The meat is cooked well-done so it can be a little dry, but the burger itself is still decadent. If I want to punish my stomach, I also get a Coxinha. Imagine a pear, but filled with chicken and deep-fried.

name: Chantal Guillon Macarons
text: Who has two thumbs and wins the Big Brother of the Year Award for trucking a 24-pack of Chantal Guillon's awesome macarons across the country for his sister? *points at self with both thumbs* THIS GUY.Aside from tasting awesome, they're 100% gluten-free too. My sister's favorites are Hazelnut, Dark Chocolate, Red Velvet, Coffee, and Salted Caramel. She really didn't like the Almond Amaretto and Italian Pistachio. If you're getting these for someone else, ask them for the plastic cases. The case did a great job keeping everything in immaculate form, even when I put it in my carry-on luggage.

name: Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous
text: Ice cream, and cookies, and licorice! Oh my!The ice cream here is top notch. My triple scoop of Malted Milk, Vanilla Bean, and Pumpkin was an adventure in pleasantly subdued flavors. I particularly enjoyed the Malted Milk flavor. While the Peanut Brittle and Brown Sugar Cookie didn't provide the flavor I was hoping, my cookie-eating partner says Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous makes some of the best Chocolate Chip Cookies he has EVER had. She also really enjoyed the Sour Cherry licorice stick.In short - this place is a TRIPLE THREAT ice cream joint! Come prepared to enjoy ice cream and many of the other goodies they offer.

name: Mission Pie
text: Mission Pie does one thing, and does it great. I sampled a bunch of different pies during Smule Thanksgiving celebrations. Everything I tried was amazing, but I was very fond of the Pumpkin and Banana Cream Pies; I had way too many "one-last-bites" of each pie... AND REGRET NOTHING!

name: Homeroom
text: We order Mac and Cheese from Homeroom in Oakland for Smule Thanksgiving celebrations in San Francisco. Even though the food travels across the Bay, it doesn't lose much of its magic: this is some DAYUM GOOD mac and cheese. I never regret filling my plate with ONLY mac and cheese, and skipping everything else on the table.My favorite flavors include the extremely creamy Vermont White Cheddar, the garlicky Gilroy Garlic, and the spicy Jalapeño Popper Mac. One day, I'll make it to Homeroom and have some fresh-out-of-the-oven mac and cheese. Tears of happiness will be shed that day.

name: The Grove Yerba Buena
text: An OKAY brunch place. They brag about their home-made cookies on their menu, but my oily, flat, dry Oatmeal Raisin Cookie wasn't anything to brag about. On the other hand, they didn't brag about their Eggs Florentine; it was good and hearty. All in all, the Grove isn't bad, but you can do better.

name: Tart To Tart
text: Pretty good bubble tea...in SoMa? Count me in!

name: Ramen Dojo
text: Pretty awesome ramen joint. The Potstickers and Deep-Fried Wheat Ball with Octopus pleasantly kicked off our meal. I got a Spicy Garlic Pork broth with extra Roasted Pork and Kimchi. The "Regular" spicy is pretty spicy, but I managed with only a few tears. The bowls are huge and pack a good amount of noodles. The broth was awesome, as was pretty much everything else in this magnificent creation. For dessert, my dining partner and I shared some super FRESH Green Tea and Strawberry Mochi. Can't deny it, I'll be back to the dojo soon.

name: Pizza My Heart
text: Good: 1. Open late until 12 AM, which is SUPER LATE by Palo Alto standards.2. Service is friendly, the interior is clean, and there are plenty of comfy booths.3. Their HAL 5000 Learning Computer Drink Dispenser pumps out water in a powerfully thick stream. Truly MESMERIZING.4. The pizza is okay.Bad:1. Pizza crust is a bit too thin for my liking.2. At $3.00+ a slice, I expect my pizza to wow me a bit more.3. Can't seem to get a slice that isn't slightly burnt.

name: Park Chow
text: The food at Park Chow was average. My dining partner and I shared an order of Bruscetta and Wontons for our appetizers. Nothing special here. My Lamb Burger - a gyro disguised as a burger - was a unique concept, but again, nothing remarkable. My dining partner said her Veggie Burger was okay. The Pumpkin Pie and Huckleberry Cobbler for dessert was again, just okay. To beat a dead horse, everything was JUST OKAY. The big plus to Park Chow is you can bring your dog and eat out front. They have heaters so even in the cool San Francisco evenings, you'll be warm. They even brought out a bowl of water and some doggie treats for my dog. Thanks, Park Chow!

name: Umami Burger
text: Umami does things right. They make their awesome burgers and fries in their own kitchen, and outsource their dessert to professionals in the neighborhood. Everyone is a winner!Irish Truffle Fries - Thin fries lathered in a truffle fondue is a great start. Then add some shiitake mushrooms and large, juicy chunks of bacon and you've got some AMAZING fries.Truffle Shiitake Royale Burger - Cooked medium rare, it was oozing with juice and flavor. The onions, shiitake, and truffle glaze took this burger to next level to make this a DAYUM GOOD BURGER.Maple Pecan Bacon Pie - They get their pies from Butter Love Bakeshop. I need to visit that bakery ASAP because this pie was off the hook! To top it off, it came with a scoop of Pumpkin Spice ice cream from Humphry Slocombe.Ice Cream Sandwich - Got some Secret Breakfast from Humphry Slocombe in between two home-made White Chocolate Macadamia Nut Cookies. Funnily enough: the one thing Umami did themselves - the cookies - were a bit underwhelming. They definitely have the right idea relying on the local dessert professionals, so here's to hoping they  find a great cookie shop and use their cookies moving forward!

name: Vault 164
text: Vault 164 in a nutshell: great food, average desserts, and poor execution.Warm Lump Crab & Artichoke Dip with Taro Chips - Awesome appetizer. The creamy dip was piping hot and came with chunky morsels of crab meat. V164 BBQ Burger with White Cheddar - A great burger where every ingredient - chile peppers, onions, white cheddar, BBQ sauce - came together harmoniously. Also, the grilled brioche was a pleasant departure from the traditional burger bun.Mac & Cheese with Pancetta - The noodles seemed undercooked, but that might've been because the kitchen sent my order to the wrong table... TWICE. What was supposed to be a side to my burger ended up being an appetizer served right before dessert came out. Big no-no.Curious George - I mentioned that I don't like chocolate, and wanted the Chocolate Mousse on the side. The mousse came out on the side, but this desert was still drizzled in chocolate syrup. They ended up making the dessert again, but it would've been nice to enjoy dessert with my dining party - not after them. On top of that, the dessert itself wasn't anything amazing.Baked Alaska - The Yelp hive-mind amazes me again. My dining partner got this dessert and wished she hadn't ordered it. Yes, they light it on fire. COOL. Once you get over that, you're left with an uninspiring, flat, cold brownie topped with a scoop of Safeway ice cream.Fresh Baked Apple Pie - I had a bite of this and loved it; probably the only dish that didn't make me regret ordering dessert.

name: Quickly - CLOSED
text: When you're hankering for bubble tea at 1 AM, you can count on this Quickly (open until 2 AM) to satisfy your desires. Quickly doesn't make the best bubble tea, but it's good enough to get the job done. I always make a point to stop here after visiting one of the many Chinese restaurants that is open late in the area.

name: China Palace Restaurant
text: San Francisco will take all your money and go to bed at 10 PM. Randomly enough, Milpitas has a plethora of open-late-restaurants like China Palace (open until 3 AM) that serve up awesome food that won't break the bank.Pan Fried Onion Cake - Their version of a Green Onion Pancake. Very mediocre, so I'll pass on this next time.Lamb Kabob - Tender pieces of lamb covered in spicy (very manageable) seasoning.Pot Stickers - Large, thick-skinned, packed with meat, and filled with broth. I order these every time I visit and NEVER regret it. The only thing I regret is an order ONLY has ten of these delicious morsels.Sautéed Beef and Pumpkin - Yes, I'm addicted to Chinese dishes with pumpkin. Juicy pieces of beef and slices of the ever-so versatile pumpkin go very well together.Sesame Chicken - Tender chicken on the inside, yet crispy on the outside, drenched in some delicious sauce. Even though it's an "American dish," it was pretty great. Cumin Lamb with Onions - So delicious. The lamb is tender, well-seasoned and goes great with the stir-fried pieces of onion.Also, this place is cash only - I hear it makes taxes a lot easier!

name: HoneyBerry
text: Exactly what I expect out of HoneyBerry. Decent bubble tea - a bit too tart for my tastes, too much ice, and not the best boba in the world. The Yogurt Chip Cream Cheese Roti Bun tastes great when you can find the cream cheese inside: it isn't evenly distributed inside the bun. I wish the HoneyBerry overlords would work on their roti bun recipe, because I feel it has a lot of potential. And as always with HoneyBerry, there is a very friendly staff dishing out smiles for everyone.

name: Menchie’s Frozen Yogurt
text: Oh my goodness, Menchie's is awesome! There are many flavors to choose from, a good selection of toppings, and even Peanut Butter syrup! They also have little cups out so you can sample flavors before making that ever-so-important decision about what flavors you'll be getting. My favorite flavor from my first visit was the Spicy Pumpkin, which tasted just like pumpkin pie!Can't lie -- I'll DEFINITELY be coming back here.

name: Godfather’s Burger Lounge
text: Things started off great at Godfather's Burger Lounge. The Chicken Crisps were absolutely mind-blowing: so tender and juicy. My dining partner is a bonafide Chicken Tenders guru and says these are some of the best she's ever had. The super chewy Calamari was equally impressive.Then the burgers came out. My Soprano's Ultimate Burger promised to be "mouth-watering," but it was just so, so bland. The sautéed mushrooms, onions and bacon just didn't come through at all, and the burger patty itself didn't taste like it was seasoned. Even the server-recommended pepper jack cheese didn't add any flavor. Even worse, it came with a scant amount of the homemade Godfather's Sauce. For all this burger packed, it disappointingly tasted just like a piece of meat between two pieces of bread. My dining partner was equally disappointed with his burgers (the Director's Cut Mushroom Burger and the Philly Cheese Steak Burger respectively).Maybe I'll come back, but ONLY because those Chicken Crisps are SO DAYUM GOOD.

name: Arang Restaurant
text: The search for decent Korean food in the Bay Area hit a positive note with Arang Restaurant. The banchan (assorted appetizers) was awesome. The Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap was large, packed with meat, and provided a pleasant mix of different flavors. And to top it all off, prices are reasonable, service is friendly, it's open until 2 AM (in SF - the city that goes to sleep at 10 PM), and parking is easy since you can park in the Safeway parking lot.

name: Bio Cafe
text: A gem for those who adhere to vegan or gluten-free diets. Here's the run-down of what my friend and I sampled:Candied Blood Orange - Great! My friend really enjoyed the large slice of blood orange dipped in delectable chocolate. Butternut Squash Cake - My favorite item. So soft and juicy I had a hard time believing this was actually gluten free.Dark Chocolate Brownie - Not really a brownie -- more like a solid chunk of fudge chocolate. We put this in the toaster for 30 seconds and the entire thing started melting immediately. It paired great with the aforementioned Butternut Squash Cake -- although once melted, it served as chocolate dip instead of chocolate cake.Dried Fig Cake - Meh -- not really good. Definitely pass on this one. Agave Banana Pudding - Large and flavorful. The agave provides a cool, although somewhat dry, glue that keeps this entire thing together.

name: The Crème Brûlée Cart - MOVED
text: When I try something at a hole-in-the-wall place that does ONE thing, I expect that thing to be amazing. Yet, my Vanilla Bean Crème Brûlée was just "good"; can't really say anything bad about it, but can't rave about it either.

name: Brickhouse Cafe
text: The Food - My Honey Chipotle Pulled Pork was pretty awesome. The artisanal bread was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. There was a good amount of pulled pork inside. The pork had a pleasant spicy kick to it that was offset by coleslaw. That said, I was expecting my $10 to go a little farther than a modestly-sized sandwich and a small salad of mixed greens. The Wait - A bunch of coworkers and I ordered to-go. Now I don't mind waiting for food to be prepared, but when 6 out of 7 orders come out and we sit there waiting 10 minutes for the last to come out, it's kind of annoying. Especially when I'm hungry and need to sit there ogling that temptress of a sandwich.

name: Cafe Salina
text: Visit after visit, dish after dish, expectations have been met, exceeded, and I can't deny it anymore -- Cafe Salina is more than worthy of 5 STARS. I have NO complaints. They do NOTHING wrong. Trust me -- we've tried to find weaknesses in their massive menu, but there's something truly magical happening in that kitchen. "Let's order a milkshake. There's no way this Chinese joint can make those well." WRONG."This lo mein dish with pork looks kind of weird; it's probably not going to be very good. Let's test'em." WRONG AGAIN."Wow this dish looks amazing. If it tastes amazing, I'm definitely coming back every week for the rest of my life." YES, it's amazing. YES, I'm coming back next week AGAIN AND FOREVER. I always roll in after 8 PM to avoid the crowds and the supposed bad service that everyone on Yelp QQs about. My homegirl Cindy always take good care of my entourage. Thank you, Cafe Salina. See you next week! FOREVER.

name: Fantasia Coffee & Tea
text: Good bubble tea. I'm not sure what side I take in the Ten Ren vs. Fantasia bubble tea feud. They're both pretty solid in my opinion.I'm docking a star because I got an Oatmeal Raisin cookie and it had chocolate chips in it. Granted, I'm one of those weird people that doesn't like chocolate and I should've asked to be sure, but I was disappointed to pay $2.50 for a cookie that not only had chocolate in it, but was dry and somewhat stale. Will definitely not get anything besides the bubble tea next time.

name: TOWN San Carlos
text: Town is SOLID -- like one of your bros that's there when you need some legit backup.1. Benedict a Trois - If you're having trouble choosing between the 3 Eggs Benedict options (steak, crab-cake, classic ham), just go with the ménage à trois. My dining partner really enjoyed the crab-cake one, but I found the steak to be the best.  2. Mom's Meat Loaf Sandwich - My big mouth finally came in handy as I tackled this massive sandwich. This sandwich is a party of wonderful flavors and textures. Those bites where I got fried egg, a bit of crispy onion ring, and some spicy meatloaf coated in gruyere cheese had me hankering for another visit to Town. 3. Chicken and Waffle - I'm not a huge fan of fried chicken, but the juicy chicken served on peppery waffle totally won me over.4. Warm Bread Pudding - While The Refuge down the street still has the best bread pudding, Town put up a solid fight with its piping hot bread pudding served in a lavish Maple-Brandy sauce. Ask for it a la mode to up the ante!And now the sad truth about Town: everything was so damn good, but the menu was filled with tons of other (likely amazing) things. When I return, will I have the COURAGE to order something different? I'm not sure...

name: Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream
text: When you walk into an ice cream shop and are greeted with a "Hello! Would you like to try any flavors?" you know you're going to have a good time. The server here was friendly and didn't mind handing out sample after sample to eager customers. Picking which ice cream flavors I want is the most important decision I make each week; thanks for helping to make it easier! I ended up going with:1. Secret Breakfast (Bourbon and Corn Flakes) - The Bourbon is strong with this one. Also, because of alcohol's melting point, this flavor was pleasantly softer than the other flavors. At times, the taste was so strong I felt like I was eating solid Bourbon. My last bite also had one of those large fused chunks of Corn Flakes -- WINNING!2. Pumpkin 5 Spice - A pleasant blend of savory and sweet flavors of my favorite fruit.3. Harvey Milk and Honey Graham - This was my favorite flavor of the three. It tasted like a cup of milk with crushed graham crackers in it -- absolutely awesome. It took me back to my graham-cracker-crushing childhood days.Thank you, Humphry Slocombe. To say you are one of the greatest things to happen to happen to my taste buds may not quite cover how I feel about you.

name: Butler & The Chef Bistro
text: I got the Croque Monsieur and was unimpressed at first glance given the meager amount of meat and cheese inside. But it's not all about quantity sometimes and I learned an important lesson that day: crème fraiche can take an unassuming sandwich and make it absolutely delicious. This sandwich, which was so massive I ate it with a fork and knife, was thoroughly awesome. I'm giving myself 24 hours before I'm craving another one of these bad boys. Then the Pumpkin Galette came out and that took this experience to another level. I love any dish featuring pumpkin and words cannot describe the awesomeness of this savory dessert. The creamy pumpkin purée, the flaky crust wrapping it, and the side of heavenly whipped cream truly moved me in all the right ways.

name: Yasukochi’s Sweet Stop
text: The Green Tea Roll, a creamy, rich cake that melted in my mouth, absolutely blew my mind. I definitely want to try the Strawberry Roll now. I had a bite of the Coffee Crunch and Lemon Crunch. I'm not a huge fan of either flavors, but it might be an understatement to call them crunchy as those chunks are rock solid!

name: Fang
text: My company came to Fang for a company lunch. The dishes we had ranged from mediocre to great. Steamed Shanghai Soup Dumplings - 2/5 - Really thick skin and barely any broth inside these sad dumplings.Pork Steamed Bun - 5/5 - So freaking awesome! The bread was like a cloud: soft, airy, and delicious. Some of the meat inside was chewy, while other pieces were crispy. This was definitely my favorite dish. Fried Shrimp Potstickers - 1/5 - Very sad excuse for potstickers. The skin was super thin and was already falling apart as the dish was brought to our table. The shrimp inside was uninspiring and didn't do this dish any favors.Fried Shishito Peppers - 2/5 - The peppers were too damn salty!Honey Apple Shrimp - 3/5 - Like Honey Walnut Shrimp sans walnut plus fried apple pieces: fried shrimp and apple lathered in a decadent mayo sauce. This dish could've been awesome, but some pieces of shrimp still had the tail (while others didn't), which was pretty annoying. Also, I'm not quite sure what all the hype is about the owner ordering for you. We went this route and the dishes brought to the table were exactly what I'd expect of a standard visit to a Chinese restaurant. Perhaps the really large party (50+ people) made him play it a bit safer?

name: Waraku
text: Shrimp Cracker with Spicy Chashu Pork-Mayo Dipping Sauce - A really great appetizer that my party of three shared. The shrimp cracker was crunchy and airy, with a subtle shrimp flavor. The dipping sauce was more like pâté in consistency and had a little spicy kick. Tonkotsu Ramen - A hearty bowl of ramen featuring a large serving of noodles in a rich broth. It comes with Chasu Pork, but I also asked for Braised Pork Belly to up the awesomeness. I noticed there was barely any smoked egg in the ramen, which was disappointing. House-Made Green Tea Creme Brûlée - Thick, creamy, and absolutely decadent. The green seared top made the dish look a bit unappetizing. But one bite later I knew I couldn't judge this creme brûlée by its burnt cover. Service - Super friendly and attentive service. Our server, Ubi, was talkative and very personable.

name: Stacks
text: Stacks efficiently delivers heaping stacks of happiness. The wait can appear to be long, but Stacks quickly gets people in and out the door with massive smiles on their faces.The weekend special Eggs Blackstone a.k.a. Eggs Benedict a la Bacon was absolutely awesome. The dish was overflowing with crispy bacon bits and drenched in creamy hollandaise sauce. My dining party shared a short stack of Banana Macadamia Nut & Coconut Pancakes. There is nothing short about the two giant pancakes that arrived at our table. The warm chunks of banana infused into the soft, yet crispy pancakes made every bite an ABSOLUTE DELIGHT.

name: Yan’s Garden
text: Pot Stickers - 4/5 - These pot stickers were absolutely THICK - packed with meat and cabbage. Unlike other pot stickers, I was able to distinguish the flavors of the meat and  cabbage. These were some of the best pot stickers I've had.Fried Crab Meat Cheese Won Tons - 3/5 - Rich and creamy goodness. But then again, it's pretty tough to go wrong with deep-fried cheese and crab. Fried Chicken Wings - 2/5 - Extremely disappointing. You get six small wings that are the size of frog legs. The flavor of the seasoning and meat also didn't help this disappointing appetizer.Hong Kong Pan-Fried Noodles - 4/5 - A great entree. The beef was my favorite meat in this eclectic mix, and the bok choy was my favorite veggie. The noodles were also crispy (pan-fried), and if you let them wade in the sauce at the bottom of the plate, you got softer, more flavorful noodles!

name: Tutti Frutti
text: Tutti Frutti is an above average froyo joint. The froyo is creamy, thick, and the flavors are true to their name. I tried Vanilla, Watermelon, Cotton Candy, and Fine-Apple. My favorite flavor -- Fine-Apple -- tasted like a pineapple. I thought the name was kind of gimmicky, but after a bite of this FINE specimen, everything made sense. The other flavors were great too -- no duds here.

name: Cologne Auto Body
text: Someone gave my car an unwanted love-tap in a parking lot. Cologne is one of State Farm's approved body shops, is located right down the block from where I live, and has great Yelp reviews -- so I went with them.Expectations? Absolutely met and exceeded. Dieter and Bill were courteous, professional, and had all the work done on the promised date. I even asked how much it would cost to touch up an unrelated scratch, and they kindly offered to do it for free. Every interaction I had with them was great and I highly recommend them if you ever need to get your vehicle serviced.

name: Belmont Sports Complex
text: I love jogging around the Bel-Mateo Sports Complex. Here's a quick rundown!Pros:1. Even though it's right next to 101, it's easily accessible via a pedestrian bridge.2. Three times around the soccer field is about a mile so it's easy to keep track of the distance you've covered.3. Easy access to the Bay Trail: a wonderful trail that runs along the Bay. I've only made it up to the San Mateo Bridge (4 miles away) so far and it's gorgeous.4. The complex is frequently in use in the evening so even if you come after sunset, the stadium lighting will keep everything nice and bright.  Cons:1. Geese hang out here, and they just looove to poop everywhere. Watch your step!

name: Ariake Japanese Restaurant
text: My friend and I dropped by Ariake after we got a good beating at kendo practice. Excitement overtook my weary body as my eyes spied cooked and fried sushi rolls: my favorites. Could they be as good as the ones at my favorite sushi place: Cha Cha in San Jose?The rolls we got were a mixed bag. I really enjoyed their Lion King Roll (crab, avocado, wrapped in salmon and baked with special sauce). The roll had a little tangy kick towards the end of each bite that I couldn't really put my finger on, so I figured the special sauce was just doing its thing. On the other hand, the Godzilla Roll (fried yellowtail topped with sweet and spicy sauce) was totally disappointing. Some pieces of this roll had barely any fish in them. Dessert was again a mixed bag. The Green Tea Cheese Cake should actually be called Green Tea Ice Cream Shaped Like a Cake. It looked like what I'd imagine green tea cheese cake looks like, but it was FROZEN. I want my cheesecake to be soft and creamy, not hard. The Strawberry Mochi Ice Cream was good, but nothing mind-blowing. Service was friendly, yet we had to repeatedly ask for refills. We had just spent 2 hours in heavy armor beating each other with wooden swords so we were pretty parched. Even after we kindly asked, explaining to the waitress that we were pretty thirsty, it still took a while to get our refills.

name: Tea Era
text: I felt like the luckiest princess in the world dining at Tea Era. Tea Era.. Tiara.. Get it?! ...Anyway, I liked this place. The tea wasn't too sweet. The bubbles were chewy and smaller than what I'm used to. And while I forgot to ask for less ice, Tea Era doesn't stuff your cup with ice by default. My knight in shining armor (my bro) enjoyed a Green Bean Smoothie which -- true to its name -- tasted very strongly of green bean.

name: Dim Sum King
text: Dim Sum King is my dream come true: all my favorite dim sum dishes, all prepared well, and available all day, every day! I dropped by with two friends and we ordered a massive feast that came out to only $40. My go-to dim sum item, the Steamed BBQ Pork Bun, was impressive. The bread was soft. Inside were large, juicy chunks of pork. The fried Crispy Shrimp Pocket, featuring two (not one!) pieces of shrimp, was awesome. The Taro Puffs were packed with pork. Their Potstickers were made with chicken, which is outside of the norm, but I liked them. The Spinach and Shrimp Dumplings also had an interesting smoky flavor; I'm not sure if this was on purpose or by mistake, but, hey, I liked it.You can order most items in a set of 3 or even just a single item, so you don't have to come with friends to maximize the number of menu items you can sample. But good food is always better with good friends, so grab them and head on over to Dim Sum King!

name: Yoogl - MOVED
text: When getting my frozen yogurt at Yoogl, two things immediately left a sour taste in my mouth: they had two yogurt stations completely empty (fewer flavors to choose from) and the yogurt had a runny, watery consistency. That said, it was still tasty. My favorite flavor was the Oatmeal Cookie; it tasted like someone froze an oatmeal cookie and then pureed it. I hope the empty stations were a one off event because it tainted an otherwise pleasant froyo stop at Yoogl.

name: Eiji
text: A truly magical Eiji experience is composed of two periods: before dessert and after dessert. Make sure you enjoy both, so pre-order dessert when you arrive, as they do run of out of desserts. Before dessert, you can feast on many delicious things. The Oboro Tofu features a large bowl of hot tofu in a light broth, with a set of accompanying toppings. While I enjoyed the spicy radish and minced ginger, I ended up eating most of the soft, creamy tofu without any toppings. The Eggplant with Walnut Miso was out of this world. The Walnut Miso was hot, creamy, and had walnut slivers layered throughout. Eiji offers mostly traditional rolls, but their Ceviche Roll (hamachi with homemade salsa) is non-traditional and tastes like a sushi taco!You pre-ordered dessert, so now things are going to the next level. The Strawberry Mochi has an actual strawberry inside it, wrapped in a layer of red bean paste and soft sticky rice cake. The Purple Sweet Potato Yokan features a subdued sweet purple yam cake topped with some rich vanilla ice cream on top. Every bite was wonderful; the cake was firm, yet melted in your mouth along with the ice cream.You really can't go wrong at Eiji. Everything we tried was fresh, prepared well, and thoroughly enjoyable. To boot, unlike other great sushi restaurants that sometimes have snobby service, Eiji has a friendly staff that is always helpful if you need some recommendations or don't know what a particular item is.

name: Ten Ren Tea
text: My coworker is a self-confessed bubble tea snob and this Ten Ren Tea is her favorite bubble tea place in the Bay Area. My bubble tea acuity isn't particularly high, but this place makes great bubble tea. I always go with the #4: black milk tea with bubbles. The tea hits the right level of sweetness every time, and the tapioca is chewy. The staff here is always friendly, even when they get busy. Every time I'm down in Cupertino, I drop by Ten Ren, and it's always worth it.

name: Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot
text: The food here is great, and the staff is friendly. The Cupertino location is pretty much the same as the San Mateo one except:1. It's a lot smaller, but just as popular, so expect to wait a good amount of time if you don't arrive when they open. 2. The people at the front are terrible at giving you an estimate of how long you'll wait; our 30 minute wait time ended up being over an hour.3. Tall booths and mood lighting provide a little more privacy and a more chill atmosphere, which is different from the more open and bright San Mateo location.4. Parking in downtown San Mateo isn't a cakewalk, but this location has a very small parking lot and there are a few other Chinese restaurants in the complex, so be prepared to look for parking elsewhere.

name: Chiro-Medical Group
text: I was referred to Chiro-Medical Group for physical therapy to alleviate tendonitis in my arm. I worked with Tim King, who was a fantastic physical therapist. During the first, hour-long appointment Tim did a bunch of manual muscle testing to figure out exactly what was triggering the pain in my arm. During the next four half-hour appointments Tim massaged my arm, continued to do manual muscle tests to gauge progress, and taught me some exercises to prevent future injury. Pain dissipated and with Tim's recommended exercises, I'm hoping to avoid dealing with this issue again. The only bad thing I have to say about Chiro is their billing department. After my second appointment, I met with their Patient Rights Advocate a.k.a. Bill Collector in disguise. He couldn't tell me how much I owed Chiro, but he insisted I put a payment down right there and then. When I asked him how much each appointment was going to cost me, he couldn't give me a straight answer, even though he had already spoken to my insurance company. I can understand that they might've gotten duped in the past by patients who couldn't or didn't pay their bill, but that's no reason to treat everyone like a miscreant who is trying to nickel and dime you.In short, Tim was absolutely awesome, but their Patient Rights Advocate could stand to learn a thing or two about treating patients like people instead of thieves.

name: Joy Restaurant
text: Average is the best word that describes Joy Restaurant. My party sampled several dishes. While most things were okay, nothing impressed us. Each bite just got us thinking about another restaurant that prepared that item better.I tried my two goto Chinese dishes: Xiao Long Bao and Chives Pancake. The Xiao Long Bao ended up being our least favorite dish. The skin was too thick, most dumplings had no broth in them, and the meat tasted odd. The Chives Pancake was okay, but was certainly not the best I've had.There are plenty of restaurants in the area that do Chinese cuisine really well, and unfortunately Joy restaurant just couldn't stand out.

name: Jack’s Prime
text: Unassumingly sitting on El Camino near the Hillsdale Caltrain Station is Jack's Prime: a classy shake and burger joint. My Jack's Prime Classic Cheeseburger with Sautéed Mushrooms and Onions was flavorful. The patty itself was supposedly a third of a pound, but it looked a lot smaller than that. I also requested the burger be cooked medium, but was disappointed to find it was well-done.The fries really shine. My dining partner and I shared an order of Irish Nacho Fries (melted cheddar, crispy bacon bits, green onions, tabasco mayo). It was difficult to get all the ingredients in one bite, but when you did, it was a faaabulous party in your mouth. The Garlic Fries are truly garlicky: loaded with pungent garlic. The Sweet Potato Fries were also good; the mayo served with these fries was awesome.Our meal up to this point was great, but then we ordered dessert. The New York Cheesecake was absolutely disappointing. There was no difference in texture between the crust and the cake filling. The filling itself wasn't even soft; it was kind of chewy. It tasted like something you'd buy in the frozen foods section of a grocery store. There were a few hiccups along the way, but overall our visit to Jack's Prime was good. The food was good, came out fast, and the service was extremely friendly. Next time I visit, I'll skip dessert and walk down to Yumi Yogurt to satisfy my sweet tooth.

name: Whispers Cafe & Creperie
text: My dining partner and I came to Whispers Cafe to satisfy our cravings for some great breakfast, and we left happy. Everything about my Huevos Rancheros dish was awesome. The potatoes were flavorful, the beans were good and hearty, and the eggs on thick corn tortillas smothered in cheese and salsa were to die for. My dining partner enjoyed his Eggs Benedict with Avocado and Bacon, although it would've been nice for them to provide more Hollandaise sauce so the potatoes could get some loving too. All in all, Whispers Cafe got our day off to a great start and we are eager to grab breakfast here again.

name: Yi Yuan Szechuan
text: Some say this restaurant is in Millbrae, while others say San Bruno. All I know is, Yi Yuan dishes out some seriously good Chinese food. Offering many spicy Szechuan dishes, I found the menu's claim that the food will be "spicy but not numbing" to be spot on. My dining partner and I shared two noodle bowls. The Szechuan Dan Dan Noodles reminded me of an Italian spaghetti dish as it featured a heaping serving of spaghetti topped with ground meat. The noodles were thick and hearty, and once the spicy sauce sitting at the bottom of this dish was mixed in, the dish packed quite a punch. The Lanzhou Beef Ramen was good, but a bit too spicy for me. Featuring thin-cut slices of beef with noodles in a spicy-looking broth, I enjoyed a few bites before tears of joy and spiciness overwhelmed me.We also ordered some dim sum style dishes. The Green Onion and Beef Roll featured layers of dough, beef, and green onion, and was like a mixture between a fried and fresh roll. The Beef Pancakes were packed with beef and a ridiculous amount of broth: so much so that I got a fair amount on my shirt! The Leek Pancakes featured a soft dough shell, and were filled with tasty chives. While the noodle dishes were a bit spicy, these dim sum style items were not spicy at all.I was pleased with everything we ordered. The staff here is incredibly friendly, which was a pleasant surprise given the usual service one gets at Chinese restaurants. The decor, aiming to mimic joints in the rural Chinese countryside, was also awesome. The menu is large, and there are plenty of non-spicy items; so don't let the Szechuan label scare you away from a great experience.

name: Delizie
text: I'm always hesitant to visit Italian restaurants. If a place can put spaghetti and tomato sauce together, they seem to consider themselves qualified to serve Italian. When I walked into Delizie, I was expecting mediocre pasta with mediocre sauce. But halfway through our meal when our server asked us, "Tutto bene?" I almost told him, "It's not okay... It's amazing!"I had Pappardelle Al Cinghiale (egg pasta, wild boar tomato meat sauce, celery, carrots, red onions). I'm not a huge fan of pasta, but the egg pasta in this dish was so fresh and amazing, I couldn't help but devour it all. The meat sauce was flavorful, and the small chunks of boar meat sprinkled throughout made this dish a real winner.My sister got the gluten-free Penne Piccantine (Pomodoro sauce, chili peppers, garlic, fresh ricotta cheese and champignon mushroom). It wasn't a big mush of pasta like you normally get with gluten-free pasta, so if you hadn't told me it was gluten-free, I wouldn't have figured it out. The sauce in this dish was out of this world: thick, creamy, cheesy, with a little spicy kick. When my sister was done eating, I grabbed some bread and wiped every last drop of sauce off the plate! The restaurant boasts a great ambiance, and the staff is extremely personable and friendly. Aside from their gluten-free pasta, which is imported from Italy, all their pasta is homemade and it shows. I didn't get a chance to try any appetizers or desserts, but I'll definitely be coming back to Delizie. The place does Italian food true justice -- vera giustizia.

name: Tava Indian Kitchen - MOVED
text: Tucked away in the back of Town and Country Village sits Tava Indian Kitchen: Chipotle's Indian counterpart. Like Chipotle, you'll enter and go through a station as you build your burrito, rice bowl, or salad. If you get a burrito -- or Burroti as they call it -- you'll get to watch them take a ball of dough and instantly turn it into a wrap with a magical, super-powered roti baking machine!I tried to go a bit healthier, so I went with Whole Wheat Roti and Brown Rice for my Burroti. I couldn't decide between Chicken or Paneer (Farmer's Cheese), so I asked for both and the server happily obliged. The Burroti was flavorful, and every bite that had some paneer in it was absolutely delightful. Flavor might've not always been there, but with an extra side of Tikka Sauce at my side, that problem became no problem at all. The Burroti is a bit smaller than a Chipotle Burrito, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing.Tava is gluten-free friendly, but you won't be able to get their Burroti since they do not offer gluten-free wraps. I enjoyed my visit and will definitely visit Tava when I get a hankering for Indian Chipotle.

name: The Plant Café Organic
text: If you're vegan or gluten-free, Plant Café Organic serves up okay dessert items. The items won't blow your mind and some are downright disappointing. Then again, you probably won't find many places attempting to make a cake that is both gluten-free and vegan.Surprisingly, the gluten-free and vegan Chocolate Hazelnut Cake was my dining partner's favorite dish. The cake was moist, flavorful, and the serving was absolutely massive. On the other hand, the Spicy Chewy Chocolate Cookie (gluten-free) tasted like it had almost no chocolate in it. My Peanut Butter Cookie (vegan) lacked a strong peanut flavor. The Strawberry Smoothie (strawberries, dates, vanilla, soymilk) was uninspiring at best.I would normally give a place like Plant Café two stars, but I applaud their effort to cater to people on restricted diets. At the end of the day, they didn't execute well on the majority of the items we sampled. Given we had some extraordinary vegan and gluten-free desserts at Zadin in the Mission earlier in the week, the bar might've been too high from the get-go.

name: Vik’s Chaat
text: Vik's is my favorite Indian restaurant in a grocery store, with the quirkiest ordering system. You order food at a register, then wait for your name to be called as the dishes come out from the kitchen, and you then go retrieve your food. If you order a few different items, you'll have everything only after a few trips to the serving area. My dining party ordered a bunch of items off the menu and we shared them family-style. I love bread so I wasn't surprised to find the big puffy thing -- Cholle Bhature -- was one of my favorite items. The fried bread by itself was awesome, but adding some spicy chickpeas upped the ante. I also enjoyed the Lamb Baida Roti, which is what I imagined an Indian quesadilla with lamb would taste like. I wasn't a fan of some other dishes we ordered. This was not because they were prepared poorly: our Indian dining partner assured me every dish met his expectations. I just personally wasn't a fan of the flavors and textures. The Dahi Pakori featured lentil dumplings that seemed a bit too dry, and the yogurt they were served in was a bit too tart for my tastes. I found a similar tartness in the yogurt-lathered Dahi Batata Puri.While every dish didn't appeal to my tastes, Vik's seems to be the place to go for Indian food in Berkeley. During my visit, I ran into two coworkers -- one dropping his daughter off at school and another driving down from Tahoe. It's not a coincidence -- it's just people choosing to eat at good restaurants!

name: Cream
text: With lines far out the door, CREAM must have something going for it. I was hoping it would be delicious ice cream, but it seems CREAM is just a great value proposition: you're going to get a lot of okay ice cream for a great price.I had scoops of French Vanilla, Strawberry Cheesecake, and Matcha Green Tea in a cup. The Strawberry Cheesecake -- which is made with gluten-free cheesecake -- was the best of the three, but didn't really blow me away.Their ice cream sandwiches seemed popular, so I'll have to give CREAM another shot when I run into one. Perhaps the cookies will complement the ice cream to create a product that is greater than the sum of its parts!

name: Quince Cafe & Grill
text: Quince Cafe and Grill serves up some great brunch-oriented dishes. Delicious food (including plenty of gluten-free options) and friendly service make Quince Cafe a real winner.My dining partner and I shared three dishes: Eggs Benedict, Chicken Hash, and Fresh Blueberry Buckwheat Pancakes. The Eggs Benedict, covered in a delicious house-made hollandaise sauce, were delicious. The accompanying eastern spiced Hash Browns were crispy, but didn't pack the flavor I was expecting. The Chicken Hash was a medley of crispy chicken, potatoes, onion, and garlic, topped with two sunny side up eggs. While the dish as a whole was great, the chicken was a bit dry. The Blueberry Pancakes were moist and packed with whole blueberries. There were so many other dishes at Quince that we wanted to try. While two of our three dishes weren't absolutely perfect, we enjoyed them all. Next time I'm in Berkeley, I'll definitely be coming to Quince again.

name: Kara’s Cupcakes
text: A visit to Kara's Cupcakes is akin to visiting a casino. You're going to put down a bit of money, and either win big or lose big. Some cupcakes at Kara's are absolutely amazing, while others make me deeply regret my cupcake choices.My dining party sampled a selection of cupcakes. The Chocolate Velvet was popular; incredibly chocolately, really moist, and had incredibly soft frosting. On the other hand, the Sweet Vanilla was bland and had frosting that was too hard and thick. The Banana Caramel was okay, and the Fleur de Sel was underwhelming. I love and hate Kara's Cupcakes. Go with a group so you can share cupcakes, and figure out what you like and don't like. If you find you love everything, congratulations -- you've won big!

name: LYFE Kitchen
text: LYFE (Love Your Food Everyday) Kitchen is like a fast-food restaurant focused on healthy food: you're going to get something tasty that could be considered healthy food. The dishes are marketed as healthy, but contain far too much sodium. The low calorie count on every dish seems awesome, until you realize the portions are tiny. Given this, the price of dishes at LYFE makes me feel like a sucker.My dining party shared a BBQ Chicken Flatbread, a Classic Burger, and an order of Art's Unfried Chicken. These dishes were good, but really didn't satisfy our hunger. While I can understand why they added a ton of lime to the Kale and Banana Smoothie (to offset the bitterness of the kale), doing the same for the Strawberry Yogurt Smoothie just didn't work. I was expecting a sweet smoothie, but instead got a sour one. LYFE is worth checking out if you don't mind paying a lot for a little. But if you truly want to eat healthy, this place is not it.

name: Zadin - CLOSED
text: People sensitive to gluten, have no fear! Zadin provides a wonderful menu packed with gluten-free options that'll have you eating things you never thought you would ever eat again!My dining party shared an order of the Salt and Pepper Calamari and Imperial Rolls -- both gluten-free. Gluten-free items often get a bad reputation for being drier than their gluten-infused counterparts, but both of these items were juicy and delicious. Our gluten-sensitive dining partner was able to eat great calamari; something she hadn't done in years!For the main course, two of us had the Pho Bo (Beef Noodle Soup), which was a large bowl filled with flavorful broth, hearty rice noodles, lean cuts of meat, and beef meatballs. Our other dining partner enjoyed a bowl of Tiger Prawns with Garlic Noodles. The noodles -- tossed in soy garlic sauce, egg, butter -- were pleasantly dense and packed with flavor.For dessert, we ordered the Brownie with Mitchell's Coconut Ice Cream -- the gluten-free and regular version. Both were delicious and moist; my dining partner tried both and could barely tell the difference between the two. I got the Coconut Lime Cake, which was BOTH gluten-free and vegan. I'm not sure how you make cake delicious under these circumstances, but Zadin somehow made the cake enjoyable and moist. From start to finish, Zadin was extremely impressive. The menu is a long list of delicious dishes, most of which are gluten-free. The staff is friendly and knowledgable about gluten sensitivities. If you know anyone who is on a gluten-free diet or just craving awesome Vietnamese food, bring them here -- you won't regret it!

name: Mariposa Baking Co
text: I visited Mariposa at the Ferry Building with my sister who is sensitive to gluten. Faced with a vast amount of cookies, bread, muffins, sandwiches, quiches, we had an incredibly hard time deciding what to get.I had an amazing Cheese Danish. Even though it was gluten-free, the danish was moist, not overly chewy, and a pleasure to eat. My sister enjoyed her Chocolate Chip Cookie and Chocolate Pumpkin Muffin, citing them as some of the absolute best gluten-free pastries she's ever had.There was so much that caught both our eyes. I know where I'll stop by for some food gifts before I make any trips home!

name: Blue Line Pizza
text: Blue Line Pizza dishes out stellar pizza, but beware as the desserts will quickly ruin what could have been a pleasant dining experience.The Pesto Chicken Pizza (pesto, roasted chicken, mushrooms, roasted red peppers, onions) was piled high with fresh, flavorful ingredients and tender chicken. Our custom made pizza (bacon, mozzarella, mushrooms, tomato sauce) was good, but not nearly as impressive as the suggested pies on the menu. A member of our party had a gluten sensitivity so we went with gluten-free thin crusts for both our pies. The gluten-free crust was great: thin, moist, and didn't fall apart -- as most gluten-free products normally do. Blue Line Pizza had earned a solid 4 stars, but then we ordered the two dessert items they offer: Caramel Apple Breading Pudding and a Open-Faced Gelato Sandwich. Even though our server told us both were great, both were incredibly underwhelming and disappointing, especially compared to the pizza. The bread pudding was totally uniform; it was not crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, like I've come to expect of good bread pudding. It was also too chewy and had an undesired rubbery texture to it. The Gelato Sandwich featured an uninspiring (perhaps even flat-out bland) cookie on a bed of mediocre ice cream. At least, microwave the cookie!I wish we could forget about dessert so I could give this place a higher rating because the pizza was really top notch. That said, I highly recommend Blue Line Pizza, but only if you skip over dessert.

name: The Counter Palo Alto
text: Come to the Counter to create -- from an impressive list of options -- your own gourmet burger. Order a side of some amazing Sweet Potato Fries, with even more amazing Chipotle Aioli Mayonnaise sauce, and prepare yourself for a unique experience. Even with a plethora of combinations for a burger, I always go with a Turkey Burger with Swiss, Sautéed Mushrooms, Grilled Onions, on a Ciabatta Roll with Sweet BBQ Sauce. The ciabatta roll is soft, the onions and mushroom are large and plentiful, and the Swiss cheese adds a light, cheesy flavor and creamy texture. Spread the Sweet BBQ Sauce on the bun, and you've got my favorite right there. The Turkey patty is a bit drier than a Beef patty, but I try to be a bit healthier when I come here. You can go wrong at The Counter because with great power to build your own burger comes power to build a complete disaster. Keep it simple and don't add everything you like. Not only will it be massive and impossible to keep together, it probably won't taste good.The Counter is also gluten-free friendly. Ask and they'll provide a menu with all the burger ingredients that are gluten-free -- although most of the ingredients are gluten-free so you won't be missing out. Our server even told us the gluten-free stuff is prepared separately in the kitchen, which is the way to go to avoid gluten cross-contamination. This place is popular and gets really busy. Consequently, service can be slow at times as there never seems to be enough servers to comfortably handle the crowd this place draws. That said, even with slow service, the servers are always friendly and helpful, and the food is worth it.

name: Curry Up Now
text: Curry Up Now offers good Indian food with a Mexican twist, lightning fast service, great prices, and plenty of gluten-free options. My dining party shared an order of Cross Cut Sweet Potato Fries with Maggi Ketchup. The fries were good, but dipping too far into the ketchup added too much spice, which overpowered the taste of the fries. My flavorful Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito hit the spot. It was packed with rice, chickpeas, onions, and chicken in a spicy tomato and cream sauce. It's not massive like a Chipotle burrito, but at least you won't feel like a terrible glutton after eating the whole thing. My dining partner got the gluten-free version of the same burrito: the burrito's contents were served on a plate, with an accompanying gluten-free tortilla. For dessert, I got the Fried Cheese Cake Bites. These are concisely described as dangerously decadent. Each of the six bites was a small piece of cheesecake with a graham cracker crust. Already delicious, deep frying these pieces of cake took amazing to the next level!Curry Up Now isn't my favorite Indian restaurant -- my favorite is Amber India in Mountain View -- but it certainly is my favorite Indian restaurant "with a cool twist."e

name: Cooking Papa Restaurant
text: Nestled on a pier in the back of the Edgewater Shopping Complex is Cooking Papa: a restaurant that offers great waterfront views, a diverse menu of good food, and spunky, borderline rude service. The Deep Fried Pumpkin and Eggplant with Spicy Salt featured large cubes of fried eggplant and pumpkin. While the pieces of eggplant were soft, the large pieces of pumpkin were much harder. I was hoping for softer pumpkin pieces like those served at Champagne Restaurant in Millbrae. Being Portuguese, the Portuguese Baked Seafood Rice piqued my interest. With that familiar yellow coloring, a variety of seafood, and a serving size my grandmother would be proud of, this dish was one of my favorites. The yellow curry on top was quite a lot thicker than the more runny traditional Portuguese dish I'm used to, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. The Watercress and Tender Pork Ribs Soup was packed with pieces of pork that infused the broth with flavor. The Steamed Pork Dumplings with Soup, with thin skin and filled with a rich broth, were better than most others I've had. We enjoyed the juicy Roasted Peking Duck; I enjoyed the accompanying steamed buns that helped me wipe the curry sauce off my plate. The large, light, and fluffy Hong Kong Style Egg Puffs pleasantly ended our meal.

name: Tutti Frutti Frozen Yogurt - CLOSED
text: I came into Tutti Frutti to grab some frozen yogurt, but ended up also leaving with some bubble tea and a half-dozen of Roti Buns. The Milk Bubble Tea wasn't too impressive. The tapioca was too chewy, and the tea tasted like flavored water. I did enjoy the whipped cream they topped the tea off with. I sampled two flavors of their frozen yogurt: Mango and Vanilla. The Mango was flavorful, light, and true to its name. I'm not sure what the Vanilla tasted like. It definitely wasn't vanilla, but it was enjoyable regardless.  Tutti Frutti was on course for mediocrity, but then I dug into the box of their Roti Buns. When I came in they had two types of Roti Buns, butter and cream cheese, with two types of "frosting" on top: vanilla and coffee. Unlike the insubstantial buns at Honey Berry, the buns here are packed top to bottom with light, juicy bread filling. The distribution of cream cheese in the buns was uneven, but I still thoroughly enjoyed it, even the parts without cream cheese.

name: Kahoo Ramen
text: Some friends and I dropped by Kahoo Ramen for a late lunch. I had the Kotteri Miso Ramen: rich, garlicky miso broth with cha-shu pork, menma, egg, bean sprouts, spinach, and onion. The broth was rich, but I couldn't pick out the taste of garlic because the rest was so salty. The noodles were a bit too firm. The dish featured a meager amount of pork. It would've been nice to get more, even if I had to pay more, but that wasn't an option. Overall, the dish was okay, but there was a lot of room for improvement. The service here isn't bad, but it's nothing to brag about either. The salty ramen made me thirsty, but no one ever came around to refill our glasses of water. We actually only saw our server twice: when she took our order and when she brought the bill over.I'm no ramen buff, but I'm pretty sure you can do better.

name: Shuei-Do Manju Shop
text: I grabbed a box of 10 pieces of mochi from Shuei-Do Manju for my friend. I don't know much about mochi, but I know Peanut Butter Mochi can't be bad so I got one of those to reward myself for being such an awesome friend. I enjoyed it thoroughly. It was chewy, elastic, sticky, and had a dollop of the peanut butter flavor I love.My friend was a tougher critic. She thought the red bean paste was too sweet, and also lacked the distinct red bean fragrance. The mini red bean buns had tough breading, and didn't taste fresh. Funnily enough, like me, she enjoyed the Peanut Butter Mochi most!

name: Peter’s Cafe
text: Peter's Cafe is a diner at heart. Huge overhead sign outside, plenty of booth-seating, friendly service, fast turn-around on orders, huge portions of decent comfort food, and a menu that made me feel like I was back home in NJ.My dining partner was a bit intimidated by the size of his order of Corn Beef Hash and Eggs with Hash Browns, yet ended up scarfing it down. I ordered one of the daily specials: a Bacon, Egg, and Cheese Croissant Sandwich. Expecting a modest sandwich, I was awestruck to find that it was raised on the Texan Croissant Farm -- where croissants are large and in charge. The sandwich packed a lot of egg, a little bit of cheese, and as always, never enough bacon. Even with a lacking amount of cheese and bacon, the sandwich was pleasant and pretty cheap; next time I'll offer to pay extra to get more cheese and bacon.The food didn't blow me away, but I enjoyed my visit to Peter's Cafe. The menu is large and diverse, so I know where I'm coming next time I need to satisfy a NJ diner nostalgia trip. The Oven Baked Puff Pancake sounded great, especially the German Baby flavor. I've never tasted German babies! Unfortunately, we were in a rush and the dish takes 30 minutes to prepare. I'll call ahead next time!

name: Sweet Indulgence
text: There is sure to be something in Sweet Indulgence's 20-page menu to satisfy every facet of your sweet tooth. The service here is friendly, the atmosphere is homey, and the food is decent.My dining partner and I shared a bunch of different items. The Milk Bubble Tea was good: it wasn't overly sweet, had chewy tapioca, and the tea had a pleasant, thick consistency. My dining partner was disappointed to find the Honey Jelly with Watermelon Juice was mostly slush and not much juice; it should have been listed under Slushies but was not. I found the Mango Pudding with Mango Delight refreshing and mangotastic, but my friend thought the mango was pretty sour. The Egg Puffs were plentiful, light, fluffy; my friend  was even overcome with a swell of nostalgia for Taiwan eating these puffs. The Toasted Bun with Butter and Condensed Milk was crunchy and sweet, and the hot Steamed Milk Pudding was great.
