We didn't eat anything mind-blowing, yet we appreciated the diverse offerings at Sweet Indulgence. Perhaps there are hidden gems on the menu we missed; if we were to search them out ourselves, it would take a pretty long time!

name: Massage Fitness
text: I came in for a sports massage with Ania: a kind, professional, and knowledgeable masseuse. The massage itself was great. Ania warned me before starting that she was going to dig in deep. If I ever felt like the pressure was too great (for example, if I found myself holding my breath), she told me to give her a heads up. That said, she definitely dug deep, yet the entire time never applied an uncomfortable amount of pressure. Two days after the massage, the soreness subsided and I felt totally refreshed. I have no complaints about Ania and her work, but do think the office environment could improve on a few things that blemished an otherwise great experience. During my massage there was music playing from a therapeutic radio station on Sirius XM. I knew this because every so often, an announcer interrupted the music (and my calmed mind) to announce the station we were listening to. Massage Fitness must have Comcast internet because towards the middle of my massage, the music started stuttering. There was also a ticking clock in the room; I would have preferred it not be there.

name: El Sur
text: El Sur serves up excellent empanadas. Inside the crispy, golden crust are fresh ingredients that go together quite well. When I stopped by their rustic food truck, I grabbed -- fresh out of the oven -- a Pollo Saltado (chicken, onions, tomatoes, serranos, olive, egg) and a Champiñones (sliced mushroom, shallots, crème fraîche, provolone, chives). I love mushrooms, cheese, chives, and creamy textures, so it didn't surprise me when the Champiñones was my favorite of the two. I half-expected the sour crème fraîche to be the most distinct flavor in each bite, but was pleasantly surprised to find the taste of mushrooms come through clearly.You might feel like you're getting gypped paying ~$4 for their small empanadas. Savor each bite and your taste buds will prove they are worth their cost. They were out of their other empanadas as well as their churros when we stopped by; I'm looking forward to catching El Sur when they're in town again to try out their other items.

name: Hiyaaa!
text: Hiyaaa! serves up delicious Asian-fusion grub out of a food truck. You pick a protein (lemongrass chicken, bulkogi, spicy pork, lemongrass mushrooms) and then pick a bed for it (rice, roll, fries, salad).During our visit, we tried Bulkogi on a Stuffed Roll. Paying the extra $2 for double meat was definitely worth it because the meat was tender, juicy, and flavorful. The Korean Seasoning on the sandwich was great, although I felt it overpowered the meat's flavor. My last bite was just the roll with some meat, and it was absolutely great because I was able to really taste just how awesome the beef was.The Salt and Pepper Fried Chicken Bites were crispy and seasoned well, but could have been slightly better with some sauce. I'm not sure if they had sauce hidden in their truck, but we didn't bother to go ask because the chicken bites were addictive even in our sauceless situation.They take credit cards with a Square reader, but they did one thing -- that no other Off the Grid vendors did -- that irked me. Every other truck there took your card, swiped it, selected 0% for the tip, and then returned your card. When the lady at Hiyaaa! taking my order handed me her iPad displaying options for tips, I was confused. Why ask me to pay 20% gratuity for a takeout order -- at a food truck? While waiting for our food, I saw people split between 0% and the topmost option: 15%. Customers' impulse decisions might earn them a bit more money, but it just seemed really shady that they were the only ones at Off the Grid doing this.

name: We Sushi
text: We Sushi is as close to my favorite sushi restaurant -- Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose -- as I've found, and it's a freaking food truck! I'll admit I was a bit skeptical as I walked up to a truck to order sushi rolls, but after the first bite, my concerns were put to rest.  The Wheel of Fire (Spicy California Roll topped with tuna, jalapeño slices, chef's special sauce) was a good roll that provided a manageable spicy twist on the tried and true California Roll. But it was the Lobster Crunch (Lobster salad in a light wasabi dressing, cucumber, avocado in soy wrap) that made my mouth water for more. The lobster salad was spot on: hot, flavorful, with a spicy tease. The fried soy wrap gave the entire dish a crunchy texture, which complemented the gooey lobster salad.I was seriously considering getting back in line to order some more food after enjoying these two rolls, but opted to sample some of the other food trucks during our visit to Off the Grid. Next time We Sushi rolls into town, you can be sure I'm going to sample their other offerings.

name: Kara’s Cupcake Van
text: My cupcake-eating party shared four cupcakes: Red Velvet, Strawberry Cream, Key Lime Pie, and Kara's Karrot. The cupcakes come with a good amount of frosting, but it never felt like an overwhelming amount. The frosting is airy, too: soft, light, and just melts in your mouth.Of the four we sampled, the Strawberry Cream was our favorite. Inside the soft, juicy cake was some delicious strawberry cream filling. The blend of the simple cake, frosting, and cream filling made this cupcake a real winner. On the other hand, the Red Velvet was disappointingly dry. That said, for cupcakes coming out of a van, we were highly impressed with Kara's Cupcakes.

name: Off The Grid: Belmont
text: Finally! The Belmont Caltrain parking lot is unnecessarily huge, but Off the Grid's food truck posse is doing its best to put the massive lot to work.During our visit, we had eight trucks to choose from, serving up Mediterranean, empanadas, sushi, Asian fusion, Peruvian, gua bao, and even cupcakes. My friend and I visited half of the food trucks and were very happy with each stop during our nontraditional dining experience. There was even a talented musician, Steven Norman Long, who put on an amazing show featuring covers and original content.Even though Belmont is a small town, Off the Grid draws quite a crowd so expect a wait, especially at popular trucks like the Chairman Truck. Come early too, because the food trucks run out of items.

name: Taqueria El Metate
text: El Metate offers huge portions... of lackluster food.My dining partner and I shared an order of Super Nachos. The nachos were good, but came with a meager amount of meat. Our Super Burritos were absolutely massive, but the flavor profile was uninspiring. An inspection of a cross section of the burrito reveals that it was packed with a good amount of meat, rice, beans, cheese, guacamole, and sour cream. But even with all of these flavor-filled ingredients, each bite was bland and boring. When I picked out just some carnitas meat, I found the meat to be disappointingly dry and overly chewy.For the price, I was expecting large, flavorful portions. El Metate rocked one of my expectations, but fell short on the other.

name: New Hwong Kok
text: New Hwong Kok offers a good variety of dim sum items to different levels of success. The items I enjoyed included the chive-packed, thick-skinned Chive Dumplings, as well as the Shrimp Dumplings. The Steamed BBQ Pork Buns featured soft, moist bread packed with a decent amount of pork filling. The Coconut Buns were soft with plenty of sweet coconut filling. The Taro Puff weren't the best I've had, but they were good.The Sausage Bun was a bit disappointing. The short sausage only filled half the bun. The Baked BBQ Pork Bun was coated in a strangely sticky glaze, and all the pork was packed into one half of the bun. The Fried Meat Dumplings were also a bit too greasy for me.This restaurant definitely offered a mix of hits and misses. We came in near closing time, so they were out of some items I was interested in trying like the Chives Pancake. The restaurant is kind of grungy-looking, but the area the food was displayed in was clean.

name: Amor Cafe and Tea
text: Amor Cafe has a friendly staff that serves good tea. Parking on a Friday night in the area was a huge pain, so we ended up just parking in the Passenger Loading zone directly outside, and quickly ran inside.My Bubble Milk Tea was good: not too sweet with plenty of chewy tapioca. My friend enjoyed her Green Tea. We also tried their Red Velvet Candy Pops. Each consisted of a ball of red velvet cake coated with white chocolate that both of us thoroughly enjoyed.

name: Passionfish
text: My dining partner and I wanted to go somewhere special for my 100th review. We were expecting Passionfish to be good, but everything we ordered turned out to be absolutely amazing. The service was top notch, the ambiance was refined without any snobbery, and the food was beyond words.We shared three appetizers. The Dungeness Crab Cake was very juicy and came with a good amount of lime and pepper relish. However, it turned out to be the weakest dish. The Seafood Caldo was a spicy tomato-cilantro broth featuring different soft pieces of fish that just melted in your mouth. The Burrata provided a great mixture of sweet (roasted heirloom tomatoes), savory (arugula) flavors, and soft (burrata), crunchy (toast) textures.Our entrées were top notch. My dining partner loved the Sea Scallops dish, featuring three huge, fresh, tender scallops, a tomato-truffle butter sauce, and a mound of delicious savory rice custard. Tasting all three in one bite was astounding. I ordered Spätzle, a hearty dish that came with small, thick flour-based noodles, delicious pieces of braised wagyu sugo, burnt chard, and aged asiago to give the entire dish a smooth, creamy texture. Again, delicious!Dessert topped off our amazing experience. My dining partner enjoyed a Straus Organic Mint and Espresso Mud Pie with Chocolate Sauce, featuring ice cream with pieces of espresso beans and a crunchy and chewy chocolate cookie base. Our waitress hyped up the Strawberry Peach Cobbler with Vanilla Ice Cream, so I ordered that. Even with the hype, the cobbler absolutely blew my mind! It was just a perfect blend of flavors and textures. The cobbler was warm, soft, chewy and moist. The ice cream was cool and flavorful. The peaches and strawberries were warm and sweet. In short, the dish was perfection.

name: Lopez Restaurante Y Cantina
text: Lopez Restaurante Y Cantina easily and happily accommodated a large group when we stopped by on a Saturday evening. But the food wasn't anything special. My dining partner got the Pork Tamales de Mama Chela. Even though the menu says the tamales were soaked in mole sauce, the dough ended up being a bit dry. I had the Manchamantel: small chunks of pork lathered in red mole michoacano sauce. The pork wasn't particularly special and while the sauce was interesting, the dish was just average.The staff is friendly, and the restaurant is clean and well-maintained. The restaurant is located a couple of miles away from Monterey's touristy downtown area, so it's conveniently close, but far away enough that parking isn't a pain.

name: Toro Park
text: If you're looking for a challenging hike with great views, drop by Toro Park. I ran the Spartan Beast here -- a grueling 13 mile journey up and down its many hills, with obstacles sprinkled throughout. The park offered great terrain and views for the journey. The starting area was on a flat, grass-filled area that would be great for picnics and lounging. The trails wound up and down large hills, exposing drier terrain and providing excellent views. It can get pretty warm here, and there isn't much shade up on the hills, so be sure to pack water and wear sunscreen.

name: Cafe La Strada
text: Cafe La Strada offers decent baked goods, but consider yourself warned! Do NOT be stupid like us and bring your baked goods outside... and tempt the vicious sea gulls.I was enjoying a moist, berry-filled Blueberry Muffin when an audacious seagull jumped onto our table and snatched my Strawberry Cheese Danish right from my hand. We proceeded to watch the thief uncomfortably swallow the danish in one gulp, and spent a few minutes wondering if it was going to choke and die in front of us. When it seemed to be okay (although with a huge bulging throat), we went inside to get another danish. We made sure to stay inside this time. The danish was filled with cream cheese and a thin layer of strawberry filling that surprisingly provided just the right amount of strawberry flavor. I'm sure the sea gull enjoyed it as much as I did.Be careful out there everyone!

name: Monterey Bay Aquarium
text: The Monterey Bay Aquarium does an excellent job of covering amazing and diverse aquatic wildlife. The aquarium is packed with awesome exhibits including areas dedicated just to jelly fish and seahorses. There are also two massive tanks: the Kelp Forest -- one of the tallest aquarium exhibits in the world -- and the Open Sea, which features a mind-boggling 90-foot viewing window. Prepare to spend a couple of hours exploring every nook and cranny of this aquarium because it is totally worth it. The bay and ocean is home to some interesting forms of life that truly boggle the mind. The aquarium is wildly popular, and right in the tourist trap of Cannery Row, so expect the place to be packed with visitors. You'll have to wait a few minutes at each exhibit for a chance to look at the wildlife up close. Also, expect to pay an arm and a leg for parking. Not a huge deal, but prepare to endure a frustrated search.And now, time for an educational rant. For some mind-boggling reason, it seems visitors love watching the "cute" sea otters. I know the aquarium is supposed to be family friendly, but I wish there would was some education about the uglier side of otters. They are intelligent enough (like humans, monkeys, and dolphins) to get a twisted joy out of doing messed up stuff. Just between 2000 and 2002 there were fifteen documented cases of sadistic otters raping, and during the process killing, baby harbor seals right in the Monterey Bay!

name: Candy Baron
text: My liver cried out in pain as I entered Candy Baron and saw tubs and tubs filled with candy. I've outgrown my childhood love of candy (that is, my addiction), but enjoyed revisiting some old classics like sour belts, gummi bears, and Swedish fish. Candy Baron offers eight different flavors of sour belts! The crème brûlée and pumpkin pie fudge was so rich I had trouble taking a second bite. Unlike my seven year old former self, I didn't dare try to finish it.

name: YoghArt
text: I tried four of the eight flavors YoghArt offered and was generally unimpressed. The Country Vanilla flavor was disappointingly bland, and a bit tart, which I don't particularly like. Cheesecake wasn't true to its name, yet it still tasted good so I didn't mind. That said, it wasn't all bad. The Birthday Cake actually tasted like a birthday cake, and the Sweet Coconut was light and may have had a few chunks of actual coconut in it. The people working here were extremely friendly, yet the frozen yogurt left something to be desired.

name: Garlic City Cafe
text: Garlic City Cafe does great justice to Gilroy's claim to fame: garlic.The Garlic City Burger (half pound of angus ground chuck, sweet roasted garlic, and Gorgonzola mayonnaise) was the highlight of our meal. It came loaded with about 20 cloves of garlic, yet the flavor of this burger was the powerful Gorgonzola mayonnaise. Each bite of this burger just melted in your mouth, with a little hint of garlic, and a wave of strong, creamy Gorgonzola Mayonnaise.The bowl of Signature Soup Cream of Garlic was great. It offered a thick texture with satisfying garlicky flavor that wasn't too overpowering. The Garlic Chicken and Eggplant Panini (grilled chicken, eggplant, tomatoes, garlic, smoked mozzarella, pesto spread) was also good. It was an enjoyable sandwich, but paled in comparison to the amazing burger.Garlic City Cafe reminded me of the diners from back home in New Jersey, with a garlicky twist. If you ever find yourself in Gilroy, stop by this gem of a restaurant.

name: Volvo Palo Alto
text: The service staff here is friendly, helpful, and professional. Getting an appointment is easy, and they work fast. Anytime something was found during the factory-scheduled maintenance, I would get a call explaining the issue, and an estimate of the damage to my wallet before they would proceed with fixing any issues. A few days after my service appointment, they usually follow up with a quick call to make sure everything was done to my satisfaction.Spending money getting your car serviced doesn't make many people happy and this place is definitely a bit more expensive than some general auto repair shops. That said, aside from my visits for factory-scheduled maintenance, I've had zero problems with my car -- probably a testament to their competency.

name: Happy Donuts
text: If I was craving awesome donuts, Happy Donuts would not be destination. But if I wanted a place to hang out with friends, surf the interwebs, and eat some fattening fried dough, Happy Donuts is the place to be. Happy Donuts offers fast, free, wireless internet that is actually fast. No passwords, no dumb web forms that make you agree to sell your soul, and no traffic shaping. With a decent ping and fast download and upload speeds, you can bring friends to play some StarCraft 2, or get some less serious work done. The donuts are okay. During my last visit I tried a Glazed Donut Hole, a Raspberry Filled Donut Hole, and a Blueberry Cream Cheese Fritter. The donut holes were soft, and covered in a thin, sugary glaze. The raspberry filled donut hole should've been called Raspberry-Stuffed Donut Hole because it was absolutely packed with sweet raspberry jam. The fritter was filled with a light cream cheese, and provided a nice mix of soft pastry, blueberry filling, and creamy flavor.

name: Whole Foods Market SoMa
text: Unlike the Whole Foods in San Mateo, this store doesn't suffer from annoying inventory issues. Every time I stop by for things I couldn't pick up in San Mateo, I am pleasantly surprised to find a healthy supply of everything I want.The checkout area is a bit odd. There are two separate lines that combine into a single lane that has multiple registers. When the lanes merge, people alternate hopping into the checkout area. In general, aim for the shorter of the two lines to get out faster. I can imagine this would cause mini world wars in an angry, merge-incompetent place like New Jersey, but it seems to work okay with the friendly people in San Francisco.

name: Street Food - CLOSED
text: Street Food offers a la carte Beijing-style skewers and other small dishes. For about $1 you can pick from about 70 different skewers! Because of the economical price, there is no need to bring a large party to sample their menu.My favorite item was the BBQ Eggplant. For only $2, we got a large serving of creamy, well-seasoned eggplant. The eggplant was so rich and creamy I had a hard time believing I was actually eating a vegetable. The Shredded Dried Bean Curd provided an excellent reprieve from the onslaught of spicy skewers. My dining partner was blown away by the BBQ Oyster. Not only was the oyster absolutely massive, the spicy broth complemented the taste of the oyster, rather than overpowering it.The Wontons in Chili Sauce, with a scant amount of bland meat, was very underwhelming, and was actually the most expensive item on our tab. This seemed like the only disappointing dish.We were pleased with our visit here. We got to sample a ton of different skewers, yet we only explored a fraction of their offerings. If we're ever craving skewers, or delicious eggplant, we'll stop by Street Food again.

name: Golden Island Cafe - CLOSED
text: My friend and I dropped by for an afternoon snack at Golden Island Cafe, and were pleasantly surprised by things we ordered. My hot Hong Kong Style Tea wasn't sweet. In fact, it was a bit bitter, but I enjoyed it. My friend got a Papaya Milk Smoothie with Tapioca, which was cool and creamy. We're not sure if it's actually made with real papaya, but it certainly tasted like they had just blended one just for this smoothie. The Sago with Coconut Milk is a traditional Asian dessert featuring coconut milk, small sago pearls, and small cubes of grass jelly. To be honest, I haven't yet acquired a taste Asian-style desserts, but I actually really liked this item. The cool, smooth, sweet coconut milk complemented the grass jelly by masking the jelly's slight bitterness. The bounty of sago pearls added to the mixture of textures in this dish.We also tried a Hot Dessert Sampler. This comes with some Sweet Peanut Dumpling (mochi with ground peanuts), Dun Dan (steamed egg custard), Dun Lai (steamed milk custard), and Sesame Paste. The Dun Dan was a bit too eggy for me, but I enjoyed the Dun Lai. My friend really enjoyed the gooey mochi and crunchy peanuts of the Peanut Dumplings.My friend went on a serious nostalgia trip of his time in Asia while we were here. On our way out, we looked at the menu near the entrance, which features pictures of the entrées and snacks Golden Island offers. So many things looked mouth-watering, so we're planning on coming back with empty stomachs!

name: Quickly
text: Quickly's tea won't blow your mind, but it isn't bad. I asked for a standard Milk Bubble Tea that I enjoyed, with my preferred level of sweetness. They seem to have tapioca supply-chain issues: I stopped by after lunch and they were already out of regular-size tapioca, so I got smaller boba. The wait wasn't long, although I felt bad for the girl who had to both man the register and make the teas. This Quickly has a massive menu. I was already full when I visited, so I skipped out on trying their Peanut Butter Piggy Bun. It sounds interesting, so I'm planning to try it during my next visit.

name: J&J Bakery - CLOSED
text: J&J Bakery serves up Hong Kong style entrées, and Chinese baked goods, including my favorite item: BBQ Pork Buns. The Baked BBQ Pork Bun is huge. I was expecting to get a small amount of pork inside the sweet, fluffy, chewy bread of this bun. But I was pleasantly surprised to find it packed with a mixture of pork chunks and shredded pork. The meat wasn't swimming in sauce, but that didn't take away from this awesome bun.Aside from the pork bun, I tried a few of their other baked goods and got mixed results. The Sausage Bun features a decent savory sausage (not a traditionally sweet one) wrapped in a sweet, soft bun. The lightly sweet Sponge Cake was so airy, it melted in my mouth. The Pineapple Bread was sweet and light in texture, but didn't pack any discernible taste. The Walnut Cookie was a bit too hard. When I bit into it, I was surprised by my cookie-dwelling archenemy: chocolate chips.

name: Champagne Soup
text: The quirkily named Champagne Restaurant serves great dim sum and Cantonese dishes. I came here with three friends for lunch on a Saturday. We ordered a small feast, and this restaurant delivered a number of impressive items. My favorite dish here is the Deep-Fried Pumpkin with Salted Egg Yolk -- which is basically like pumpkin fries. The pumpkin is so juicy and soft. The breading has small pieces of egg yolk that complement the pumpkin extremely well. The Fried Salt and Pepper Diced Tofu is magical and paradoxical in nature. Even though it's fried, the small tofu bites are so lightly fried, they almost seem baked. Fried goods are usually kept moist by covering them in a layer of breading. The tofu in this dish had a minimal coat of breading, yet the inside was somehow incredibly moist and creamy. I was impressed just eating the tofu, but then I ate the tofu with the pepper, garlic, and scallion seasoning, and was absolutely floored by the bonanza of flavors and textures. The Shanghai Soup Dumplings are great, and packed with hot broth. The Steamed BBQ Pork Buns feature soft, fluffy bread enclosing juicy chunks of pork. The fried Crispy Taro Puffs come with a heaping amount of melt-in-your-mouth taro, blowing away my expectations for the dish.It's a shame Champagne Restaurant doesn't serve champagne, because by the end of our meal, we were ready to celebrate the successful, delicious meal.

name: White Dove Jewelry - CLOSED
text: When the springring clasp on my necklace broke, I brought it in to White Dove to get it fixed. John was extremely helpful and gave me his recommendation: replace it with a lobster clasp, which is much stronger than the original clasp. He charged me for the new lobster clasp -- but made the repairs and even cleaned my entire necklace for free. My experience was painless and enjoyable; anytime I need jewelry fixed or cleaned, White Dove will be my destination and I wholly recommend it.

name: The Crepe Stop - CLOSED
text: If you want your pick from a variety of well-made crepes and awesome gelato, stop at the cozy Crepe Stop. My dining partner ordered a Wake Up Call (Cheese, Egg, Bacon, Sour Cream) and it looked too good, so I stole a bite... or two! It was superb: the cheese, egg, and bacon were all complemented by a light layer of sour cream, making this crepe an absolute winner.I ordered a Philly Cheese Crepe (Mozzarella, Tri-Tip, Bell Pepper, Onion). I like my Philly Cheesesteaks with mushrooms. Fortunately, they let you customize your crepe so I got my crepe exactly as I desired. The crepe was enjoyable: a nice mix of the sweet pancake and savory stuff inside. But it was a bit dry, so next time I'll ask for some tomato or sour cream.The crepes were great and the gelato didn't disappoint. The Strawberry Cheesecake was rich, smooth, and flavorful. Compared to this, the Crème Brûlée had a more subdued taste. My dining partner thoroughly enjoyed the Tiramisu gelato. The crepes aren't huge, so you can comfortably enjoy one with some gelato; or, if you are dining with a partner, order three crepes to share! With 30 crepes (plus the option to build your own) and 20 flavors of gelato, we'll definitely be dropping by The Crepe Stop again!

name: Amami Sushi
text: Amami provides okay late-night sushi; nothing blew me away, but at the same time, nothing was disappointing.The Gyoza (pan-fried pot stickers) seemed to only get pan fried on one side, and the other side was soft, or if judged more harshly: soggy. The Chicken Kara-age (Japanese style fried chicken) was spot on: full of flavor and crispy.The Seared Baby Lobster looked great, but it came with a hidden mountain of wasabi that gave me "surprise wasabi flairs" while eating it. The Crab Lover Roll (soft shell crab topped with avocado, snow crab) was mediocre. The mix of the warm crab inside and cold avocado on top just didn't work well. Topping the entire roll with an overly sweet sauce also didn't help. The Wild Boy Roll (spicy tuna, avocado, topped with scallop, tobiko, and creamy wasabi sauce) fared a bit better, but the large amount of spicy tuna in this roll overpowered the other flavors. The uninspiring Green Tea and Sesame Ice Cream solidified Amami as an okay sushi place. If it's late in the evening, and you're craving sushi, give Amami a try. Otherwise, you can do better.

name: Thai House 530 - CLOSED
text: Thai House provides excellent service, an awesome atmosphere, but the most critical element -- the food -- is a mixed bag.My dining party shared a few appetizers. The Fried Calamari was my favorite; it was nicely seasoned with that Thai spicy kick. The Crispy Taro Fries was what I expected out of fried taro: something akin to a tasteless potato chip. The Crispy Tofu was really disappointing. The outside wasn't very crispy, and the inside was very soggy.My Pumpkin Curry was okay: the chicken was a bit too dry, but the pieces of pumpkin were cooked just right. The Salmon Fillet Wrapped in Banana Leaves came with salmon that was completely overpowered by peppery spices. My dining partner got the Crispy Pork Belly special. She thought the meat seemed overcooked and was hard to chew, but I thought it was just right.Thai House has got everything else figured out, so it stands to benefit greatly from improvements to its food offerings.

name: Anthony’s Cookies
text: I'm a total weirdo and don't like chocolate, so my options at Anthony's Cookies were severely limited, especially since they were out of Oatmeal Raisin Cookies when I visited.So, I had the Cinnamon Spice, Walnut Chip, and White Chocolate Chip cookies. My favorite was the Walnut Chip cookie, which was was small, chunky, and packed with walnuts. The White Chocolate Chip cookie was a bit too sweet, even for me. Generally, the cookies were good: soft and moist on the inside. I was expecting them to be served warm, which would have been great given how chilly it was outside. This definitely may be a case of "it's me, not you, Anthony." Although it didn't blow me away, if you're looking for good cookies, give Anthony's a shot.

name: Bi-Rite Creamery
text: Bi-Rite serves up top notch ice cream. My triple scoop of Vanilla Bean, Balsamic Strawberry, and Cheesecake with Blueberry Swirl was expeditiously consumed. The Balsamic Strawberry, my favorite flavor, was shockingly true to its name; the holy union of tart and sweet flavors was well-executed. If you stop at the window shop next to the main store, you can get soft serve. They do two different flavors each day of the week. I had a soft serve bowl of Honey and it was delicious. The consistency was perfect: soft and fluid, but not runny. I'll definitely have to come back on a Wednesday, when they'll be serving Peanut Butter and Roasted Banana!

name: Mona Ezzat-Velinov, MD
text: Dr. Ezzat-Velinov or Mona -- as she casually introduced herself -- is a great doctor.Fortunately, I am in good health, so doctors usually send me on my way after checking my vitals. But during my checkup, we had a thorough discussion, and made a list of lifestyle changes to improve my health. Mona didn't take me on a guilt trip when I told her I don't eat many leafy greens, but encouraged me to try eating them once or twice a week; something I can definitely aim to do. Hopefully, I won't have to see Mona until my next checkup, but I'm certainly looking forward to talking to her again.If you're considering checking out One Medical, do it. If you want a great doctor, schedule an appointment with Mona.

name: Teaven
text: Teaven offers a varied selection of items: milk tea, tea, shaved ice, yogurt, and even fried snacks. Their Milk Tea is a bit on the sweet side, but that didn't stop me from thoroughly enjoying mine.Beware of ordering during their Happy Hour (Sunday - Thursday, 7 PM onwards) as you will get a free size upgrade for your drink. Wait... How could this be bad? I assumed they would give me the drink size I pointed at -- except it would be discounted to the price of a smaller size. Instead, I picked one size and they served me with a larger size. And these sizes are extremely awkward -- I ordered a Prince size and they gave me a Queen. The Queen size looks more like a bowl than a cup, and was even more awkward to hold. It's not the worst surprise, but if you're trying to manage your intake of tea, it might be good to check the exact size you're going to end up with.

name: Garaje
text: Garaje offers American and Mexican dishes in a wonderful harmony.The Crazy Dave's Double Cheeseburger is massive: two quarter pounds of angus beef topped with cheddar cheese and optionally, but certainly recommended, bacon. The meat in this cheeseburger was juicy, tender, and in charge.Order the Carne Asada Fries and you'll get a heaping serving of fries topped with grilled beef, jack cheese, avocado, and pico. I advise against thinking of this dish as a mere appetizer, so bring people to share with. The star here is the carne asada; normally, the beef is finely chopped, but at Garaje, you'll get large, juicy chunks of beef. The menu features a plethora of tempting items. On my next visit, I'm looking forward to trying the Carnitas Zapato (Burrito).

name: One Medical Group
text: One Medical is what I expect out of a doctor's visit in the 21st century. I signed up online, created a profile, filled out my medical history questionnaire, and booked an appointment, all within half an hour. The day before my appointment, I got a friendly email reminder.My appointment started exactly on time. My check-up with Dr. Ezzat-Velinov (who introduced herself as Mona) was picture perfect: she was kind, professional, and we talked about things I could do to improve my health. I also got blood work done here. Again, I didn't have to wait, and even got some bandage that didn't painfully rip hair off of my arm when removed! A copy of the blood work results arrived a week later via email, with interpretation by my doctor.There is a yearly $149 membership fee, but it's totally worth the convenience of fast, on-time, same-day appointments at any of their 14 offices in the Bay Area. To illustrate this point: I'm writing this at 5:30 PM on a Friday. I just checked appointment availability, and could actually see a doctor TODAY in San Francisco, Burlingame, or Sunnyvale!

name: Nubi Yogurt
text: Twelve flavors on tap, ridiculous selection of toppings, and waffle bowls make Nubi a great place to satisfy your froyo cravings.During my first visit, I took a purist approach and skipped all the toppings and sampled four different frozen yogurt flavors. The Wild Berry was berry, berry good; the flavor Force was berry strong with this one. The Vanilla also tasted strongly of vanilla bean. The Cake Batter's flavor was unfortunately too subtle and didn't fulfill my dreams of tasting like real cake batter. That said, the Birthday Cake flavor did a good job of covering Cake Batter's inadequacies!It'll take many, many visits to try everything, and I'm okay with that!

name: Tpumps - CLOSED
text: It's not just hype; Tpumps makes great bubble tea to your exact specification. The Black Milk Tea is more than a mixture of black tea and milk. With every sip, you taste each dimension of flavor of the tea: a taste of cool tea followed by a wave of sweet milk. We also got a Strawberry Tea with Milk and Popping Lychee Boba. I was expecting something akin to strawberry milk, but got a refreshing strawberry juice mixed with milk. Each popping boba added a burst of sweet, refreshing lychee. Although it wasn't what I was expecting, it was still quite enjoyable.If you're lucky and the line isn't out the door, you'll only need about 20 minutes to order and get your bubble tea. I'm no bubble tea connoisseur, but if the line is out the door, I'm not sure it's worth waiting.

name: Izakaya Mai
text: Oh my goodness... Their Fried Ahi is absolutely delicious! An order comes with two pieces of excellently seasoned, lightly fried, tender ahi.The Fried Oysters tasted fresh. The taste of the breading was more subdued compared to the Fried Ahi, but that let the wonderful taste of the oysters shine through. If you like salmon roe, the San Mateo Roll (shrimp tempura, salmon, salmon roe, tobiko) is a great deep-fried roll loaded with it. The Chicken Kara-age was average and didn't stand out. This place definitely impressed. We'll be back to get some more Fried Aji, and explore the rest of their offerings.

name: Fountain Garden Seafood Restaurant
text: Our party of eight ordered a feast: Pot Stickers, Fried Chicken, Combo Tofu Clay Pot, Deep Fried Flounder, Beef Rib with Black Pepper, Prawns with Walnuts, Sizzling Scallops, Sautéed Bok Choy, and Salt and Pepper Pork Chop. I was expecting a dud or two, but was pleasantly surprised to find that every dish was prepared well and enjoyed thoroughly by all.The Salt and Pepper Pork Chop was my favorite dish. The pork was tender, well-seasoned, and lightly fried. The thick-skinned Pot Stickers were unique: they looked baked instead of pan-fried, and the skin looked like bread. Although they were good, I was a little disappointed to find out they tasted no different from regular pot stickers.The service was great, and to my surprise, we didn't get dirty looks when we handed them multiple credit cards.

name: Chinese Bakery and Deli
text: This bakery has a diversified portfolio, doing many different things rather well. The Baked BBQ Pork Buns were nicely toasted, and filled with fluffy breading and tender meat, but were tainted with unnecessary food coloring. The comparatively smaller Steamed BBQ Pork Buns were morsels of soft, chewy bread and contained little chunks of pork -- without food coloring. The Egg Custard Tarts were excellent. The crust was soft, and broke apart into crumbs easily, facilitating the "melt in your mouth" experience. Unlike tarts at other bakeries, the creamy filling was not very runny, which I appreciated, given the crumble-prone crust.The Ham and Cheese Bun and Chinese Sausage Bun weren't that impressive; they didn't provide any compelling blend of the ingredients' flavors. The Chicken Bun had baking paper that insisted on sticking to the bun. To top off your experience with all these baked goods, be sure to grab a hot cup of the creamy Hong Kong Milk Tea!

name: Speisekammer
text: The Bread Basket comes with some truly magical Herb Infused Butter. If their menu wasn't filled with delicious items, I'd be tempted to just keep ordering basket after basket of bread!Our party shared an order of Reibekuchen (Potato Pancakes with Apple Compote). The pancakes were crispy on the outside, soft inside, and the apple compote was sweet with a subtle honey mustard kick to it.The Bratwurst Sandwich (Grilled Bratwurst, Sauerkraut, German Mustard on a Toasted Baguette) was excellent. The spicy German Mustard was a bit overpowering at times, making my sinuses flair, but it was so good, I didn't even mind! I devoured the sandwich and the side of Roasted Potatoes with Bacon.The worst part about Speisekammer was picking the one entree I wanted to eat! Fortunately, things like this can be remedied with future visits, which I definitely plan on making.

name: Honey Berry - CLOSED
text: Get me a Milk Tea and Roti Bun from Honey Berry and I'm one happy guy. The Milk Tea isn't too sweet, and has chewy tapioca. The Yogurt Chip Cream Cheese Roti Bun is a big, fluffy bun filled with warm cream cheese. The bun is bigger than the stuff inside, as it's filled with a good amount of air; it'd be nice to get some more bread or cream cheese inside. That said, the bun and tea are a match made in heaven!Also, people say I smile a lot, but I think the guy who works here smiles more than me and has the most infectious smile! It definitely motivates me to keep on smiling.

name: Palo Alto Shell
text: I avoid getting gas here because the price is higher than other stations in the area, but I can wholly recommend their service center. When air was leaking from one of my tires, they quickly diagnosed and fixed the issue. When I needed a smog check, I grabbed the coupon off their website, and paid only $37.

name: Box Kitchen
text: Although it's only a few blocks away from my favorite intersection in the city, 6th and Market, I'd definitely come back to this place for some late-night grub.My dining partner and I shared an order of Potato Skins, a Box Burger, and a Chicken in Waffles. Of these items, the Chicken in Waffles was the highlight of our meal. We thought the chicken was forgotten in our order, but the chicken is literally in the waffle! The blending of savory and sweet in this meal was executed extremely well: the waffle and chicken, and maple syrup mixed with Sriracha sauce all came together in a pleasantly novel way.

name: Ricardo Ferraz, MD
text: Any time there was a hiccup in my health, I could always count on Dr. Ferraz to see me through it. He was the pediatrician for me, my sister, and my extended family who lived in and around the Ironbound area. We have nothing but praise for Dr. Ferraz and his team.His office is ridiculously busy on most days. You can call for an appointment when they open at noon, but everything feels like it operates on a first-come, first-served basis. Your appointment is a guess of when things might be less busy. If your situation is not extremely urgent, your best bet is to call, ask for the latest available appointment, and drop by then.I relocated to California. I still see my dentist in Newark (Dr. Gultz), since I visit home roughly every 6 months. I really wish I could do the same with Dr. Ferraz, but -- for better or worse -- illness doesn't come on a regular schedule!

name: Yumi Yogurt
text: Dear God... Don't bring just a friend; bring your entire family because you'll need help getting through the ridiculously large portions here.I got a triple scoop of Vanilla Bean, Strawberry, and Blueberry Cheesecake. The cup was large, yet the vast amount of ice cream was still overflowing the edges; I had to rush to eat it so it didn't drop out. The three flavors were all good. But the Vanilla and Strawberry were exceptional, which was surprising given how good the Blueberry Cheesecake was!We didn't get frozen yogurt or soft serve, but don't worry. We'll definitely be coming back!

name: Sogo Bakery - CLOSED
text: Woah... Finally I, a Portuguese Custard Cup snob, found custard cups in the Bay Area that didn't disappoint me! Although the crust on the custard cups here isn't as flaky as traditional Portuguese ones, their creamy filling was spot on. While here, I picked up their Walnut Cookies, which I quickly devoured. I also grabbed a Pork Sung Bun (made by Suzanne's Bakery) and was disappointed with how little pork filling there was.

name: Buiphong Bakery
text: Man, their Croissants are large and in charge. I picked up a bag of them at Banh Mi Ba Le, located down the street from Biuphong. Banh Mi stocks their Croissants and Butter Biscuits and is open later, so don't fret if you need your fix after this bakery closes.The Croissants (at least the packaged ones I got) aren't crispy like traditional croissants, but they were definitely fresh and definitely amazing. Very soft, with just the right amount of that buttery taste you expect, their large Croissants beg to be pulled apart and enjoyed with a glass of coffee or milk.I definitely want to drop by and see what else they offer, and if the in-house Croissants are any different from the packaged ones I picked up at Banh Mi.

name: Banh Mi Ba Le
text: We came here to grab the amazing Croissants made by Buiphong Bakery. Buiphong closes at 1 PM on Saturday, but Banh Mi is open until 4 PM, so if you need to satisfy your Buiphong Croissant addiction, just come here. I'm a big fan of Chinese-style BBQ Porked Buns so when I saw a bunch of packaged Steam Buns, I jumped for joy and grabbed some. I got home, wrapped it in a moist paper towel, and threw it in the microwave for a minute. I opened the bun up to find a hard-boiled egg and Vietnamese-style meatball infused with carrots and peas. The bread was soft and proved to be a good vessel for the interesting mixture of ingredients inside. I also grabbed a Taro Jelly Drink. The accompanying "granola" was made of crushed peanuts and the bottom was filled with slices of banana. The jelly tasted very much like taro and I enjoyed the entire drink. We came here after eating lunch so we didn't have room to try the Bánh Mì (Vietnamese-style sandwiches) this place is known for. Don't worry... I'll be back!

name: Phnom Penh House Restaurant
text: We rolled into this place, ordered a bunch of appetizers and entrées, and ate it family style. Overall, my dining partners and I were very impressed with every item that came out.The Spicy Papaya Salad with Shrimp appetizer wasn't very spicy, but it was refreshing; even with a misleading name, this salad was great. It was topped with peanut crumbs, which added an extra dimension to the flavors and textures of the vegetables and shrimp. Although called Deep Fried Calamari, this appetizer didn't have an oily taste at all. The pieces of calamari were surprisingly large and the breading was well seasoned.The Kary Tia (Duck with Potatoes, Green Beans in Green Curry) features three large pieces of succulent duck in a light curry sauce. This entrée comes with a heaping serving of rice, which was more than enough to go with the curry. The Sautéed Eggplant and Chicken (Daily Special) had eggplant that wasn't soggy, as I'm usually used to. The Slaap Moarn Borg featured three boneless chicken wings stuffed with lots of vegetables and lemongrass spices. Both entrées were great. Even the Thai Iced Tea wasn't too sweet, which is par at most restaurants. In short, everything was great.

name: Creations Dessert Express - CLOSED
text: My first visit here yielded mixed results. The menu is eclectic: offering omelets, crepes, bubble, fruit juice, jelly drink, tea, ice cream, mochi, Asian-style desserts, and fried snacks like Popcorn Chicken and French Fries. During this visit, I tried the ice cream and bubble tea.Their ice cream was great. I got the Vanilla and Strawberry. Both flavors were true to their name, rich, and refreshing. My dining partner had the Chocolate Orange Chip and was really impressed it, remarking that it offered a great blend of textures. The bubble tea wasn't too impressive. It was made with powder and they put shaved ice in it. Shaved ice melts faster than ice cubes, so by the time I got to the end of my drink, a good amount of ice had already melted and it tasted watered down.The servers were personable and friendly, but seemed a bit disorganized; I'm not sure if they were flustered with the crowd that came in with me and just needed someone to help direct them. That said, the menu covers a ton of items so I'm planning to drop by again to try their crepes and fried snacks.

name: Triumph Brewing Company
text: Triumph played a formative part in my college life, since once a month, my roommates and I would come here for burgers and beer. Triumph also taught me that beer doesn't have to taste bad; beer can actually be really tasty!The Triumph Burger with grass-fed beef is pretty great, and they actually cook it as you request it. I always topped mine with Swiss Cheese, Grilled Onions, and Mushrooms. The best part of this entrée is the Chipotle Mayonnaise. This magical sauce goes well with everything: burger, fries, vegetables, and anything else you order here. I once even asked for a "tub of Chipotle Mayonnaise" and our server delivered by bringing out a large ramekin filled with this heavenly concoction!The beers are also great! My favorite beer there is the Amber Ale, which is normally available year-round. While all their beers are worth trying, the Honey Blonde reminded me too much of watered-down college beer. If it's your first time here, go with the Sampler to get a taste of all the beers they have on tap.Every time I find myself back in Princeton, especially when old friends are around, I always try to drop by Triumph for a great burger and beer.

name: Panaderia Guatemalteca Tikal
text: Like the Power Rangers say, "It's Morphin' Time" when they are ready to take on some bad guys, I excitedly proclaimed, "It's Carbo-Loadin' Time" as we stepped into this small Guatemalan bakery. We got some baked bread. Just a hint of sweetness, these firm panes would be great with a cup of milk or coffee. I made the mistake of eating the panes by themselves, which did not do them justice, as they tasted a bit dry.My favorite item was the mil hojas (thousand sheets): a delicious confectionery built with alternating layers of whipped cream and flaky pastry with powdered sugar on top. A bite of the light, fluffy cream and pastry flakes creates an amazing blend of textures in your mouth.We also tried the Pork and Chicken Tamales that were both good. They aren't huge so they can comfortably complement any other items you are interested in. They do come with bones so don't inhale your tamale! Piqued by how good everything was, we also wanted to try out the Chicken Quesadilla, Chicken Burrito, and Pan con Frijoles, Queso, Huevo (Bread with Beans, Cheese, Egg), but the server told us they only serve those items in the morning. I guess I'll have to make a stop here in the morning one day.

name: Whole Foods Market San Mateo
text: I do most of my grocery shopping at this Whole Foods. The produce is fresh, their inventory usually covers my needs, and the staff is friendly and always eager to help. They don't ever stock the large 64 ounce Eggology Egg Whites, so I pick these up at the San Francisco Whole Foods. There was a period when they did not have any Brat Hans Chicken Burgers. I asked about it and was told they were reorganizing their meats area and would have them in stock in a month; true to their word, they are now always in stock.The store has a lot of gluten-free options, which is great if you are buying for someone who has a gluten sensitivity.Also, some of the items from their Prepared Foods section are good. I really like the Tomato Basil Bisque and Cream of Mushroom soup, and their Teriyaki Tofu is delicious.

name: Eyeworks of San Mateo
text: This place is so popular. If you wanted to schedule an appointment today, you'd be lucky if you can get in within the month. This isn't hype; it's proof that Eyeworks of San Mateo provides excellent service.I came in with my friend to get a checkup and an update for my prescription. Dr. Lai not only took care of my eyes in a thorough and professional manner, he was extremely friendly and talked to my friend and I about all sorts of things. Afterwards, we picked out frames and just when you thought this place couldn't get better, you're proven wrong!! Mitch patiently guided us through the myriad of frames available at the store and was totally clutch in helping us pick out the perfect frame. With frame in hand, Mitch made some measurements, and a few days later I picked up glasses that fit me perfectly.Thanks Eyeworks! Very much looking forward to my next visit.

name: D20 Games - MOVED
text: I'm not a big fan of collectable card games (e.g. Magic, Pokémon), but I think that's because I didn't grow up in a neighborhood with a place like D20 Games.To satisfy my curiosity, I strolled into D20 on a Saturday afternoon. The place was bustling with a younger crowd playing games and checking out the cards for sale. Right next to the entrance is a calendar packed with events.The store owner, Ben, quickly introduced himself and asked what brought me in. When I told him I was more of a video gamer, he didn't shun me, but talked about how he was once a video game programmer. We had a pleasant chat about his past career and what card games were popular these days. He invited me to look around and holler at him with any questions. When someone wanted to buy a card I was surprised and happy to see that Ben looked up prices online (with the monitor facing both him and the customer) and gave them the average price he found online.More than just a store that sells cards, D20 Games seems like a great place for kids (and adults) to hang out and engage in some old-school face-to-face gaming. If that's your kind of thing, definitely check out D20.

name: Hoagie Haven
text: If there's one cuisine I haven't been able to find in the Bay Area, it's a "totally unhealthy, but so delicious" hoagie like those served at Hoagie Haven. During school, I had a love-hate relationship with the Phat Lady -- a cheese steak sandwich with mozzarella sticks and french fries. I loved how the layers of meat and fried goods blended in my mouth, but hated how it made my heart and arteries cry out in pain. That didn't stop me from eating this wonderful creation far more often than I should have.The bread -- vessel of goodness -- is a plain Italian white loaf. It's not bad, but I think there is some opportunity for improvement. I hope I can one day enjoy a Phat Lady on a loaf seasoned in garlic and covered in Asiago cheese.They also do build-to-order sandwiches. Once, I was craving hot dogs. When I walked into Hoagie Haven, I decided I didn't just want a plain old hotdog, but one with french fries, mozzarella sticks, and chicken nuggets. It was delicious!Since I graduated, it seems like they have done some culinary experiments and have discovered deep frying chunks of Mac n' Cheese. During a recent visit, I tried the Mac Daddy - a Bacon Cheeseburger with deep fried Mac n' Cheese wedges, french fries, and honey mustard. Let's just say the Phat Lady now has some serious competition for my favorite artery-clogging hoagie!My arteries don't miss you Hoagie Haven, but not a day (okay, maybe week) goes by that I don't think about biting into a delicious, greasy hoagie!

name: Douglas B Gultz, DMD
text: Dr. Gultz has a fantastic team: helpful, kind staff at the front desk; friendly, professional dentists; and even Dr. Gultz himself, who is a totally awesome, down-to-Earth guy who loves chatting up a storm. Everyone here is an absolute pleasure to interact with. My family has been going to his office for 20+ years and we have nothing but high praise for his team.I moved out to California in 2010, but conveniently find myself back in New Jersey every 6 months for college reunions and holidays with the family. Instead of searching for a dentist that would not live up to Dr. Gultz, I just make sure to schedule a visit when I'm back east.I'll have to ask during my next visit, but I think I have the longest commute to his office -- 6 hours on a plane!

name: Alameda Video Game Exchange - CLOSED
text: The variety and selection here is absolutely ridiculous, but there's a lot about this store that holds back its potential.Games are organized by console, but that's about it. The games on the shelves along the right-side of the store can be browsed up close, but it seems all the good games are on the left-side behind a counter. You'll need good eyesight, and hope that there aren't random item blocking the games. Fortunately, the lady working here didn't seem to mind grabbing games and checking prices for me.Speaking of prices, here are some examples of ridiculous prices:Valkyria Chronicles (PS3) - $20 NEW on Amazon, $38.99 USED here.Xenogears (PSX) - $40 on eBay, $99.99 here.Metal Gear Solid (PSX) - $10 on eBay, $26.99 here.That said, decent deals can be had here. Secret of Mana (SNES) for $59.99 and Skies of Arcadia (GCN) for $69.99 is very reasonable. I saw a sealed copy of ZHP Unlosing Ranger vs Darkdeath Evilman (PSP), which starts at $60 on eBay. The lady told me it normally cost $39.99, but she would give me a $10 discount. SOLD!Moral of the story: Bring a device to check prices, and come with plenty of time since you'll be searching through an unorganized trove for a potentially great deal!

name: Cafe Fudgelato - CLOSED
text: The service here is top notch: we were greeted by an enthusiastic server, who offered samples as soon as we muttered the name of any flavor. I got three scoops in a cup: Raspberry Cheesecake, Green Tea, and Vanilla Bean. The flavor that I usually use as a standard for measuring ice cream places -- Vanilla Bean -- didn't really impress me. But the Raspberry Cheesecake was so rich and flavorful that it made up for that.My dining partner enjoyed a double scoop of Mocha Almond Chips, which has slivers of almonds in it.

name: Ark Chinese Restaurant
text: Ark Restaurant has changed my opinion of noodles. I'm not a huge fan of noodles -- but only if the noodles aren't handmade and made-to-order, like they are at Ark. I had the Cold Noodles with Shredded Pork: a heaping amount of long, thin, soft noodles with shredded pork and noodled cucumber, covered in a vinegar-based sauce. Even though you get a large amount of noodles, the dish is amazingly light; I didn't feel the sluggishness I normally feel after consuming a bowl of noodles. Every ingredient played its part in making this dish great, especially the vinegar that gave every slurp and bite a tangy kick. My dining partners and I shared an order of Juicy Pork Steam Dumplings (xiao long bao). The skin of these dumplings was a little too thick, which overpowered the flavor of the pork inside. I love any dishes with pumpkin, so I'll be back to try their Pumpkin Porridge. The only problem is that I'll be too full to order their awesome noodles!

name: The Chairman Truck
text: Yum!!! This food truck magically produces some heavenly Taiwanese-style bun sandwiches (gua bao).We got the Steamed Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon and Steamed Coca-Cola Braised Pork. The bread on these sandwiches is so soft and fluffy, it looks like they pump them full of air before serving them! The meat packed within is absolutely top notch. You'll be paying a premium for each of these mini sandwiches, but you'll certainly get your money's worth.Follow them on Twitter (@chairmantruck) to know where the Chairman is giving its blessings.  They are part of Off the Grid: a posse of amazing food trucks that travel all over the Bay Area. Check out their schedule and hope that they come to a neighborhood near you!

name: Marco Polo Italian Ice Cream
text: If you want something like ice cream, but a bit lighter than ice cream, check out the gelato here! I got a triple scoop of Strawberry, Vanilla Bean, and Green Tea in a cup. I thought that after spending the day eating BBQ Pork Buns all around SF, I would regret this decision -- but I was wrong! The gelato was light and refreshing, and true to each of its flavors. I was particularly happy that the green tea wasn't bitter!My friend got a scoop of Sesame on a cone and said it was deliciously rich and just intense enough. Another friend got the Guava and Lychee. She particularly enjoyed the Lychee, which had little bits of lychee in it!

name: Let’s Roll - CLOSED
text: The Popcorn Chicken here gets you a large serving of beautifully seasoned, melt-in-your-mouth chicken. If you need more of a kick, add some pepper salt and chili powder. Grab a bubble tea next door, sit down, and enjoy some great chicken!The other items we got here couldn't compare to the Popcorn Chicken. The Gyoza had super thick skin, which seemed untraditional to me; I ate a few, but couldn't decide whether I liked it or not. The Takoyaki was tasty and had a mayonnaise-like sauce covering it. The Sweet Potato Fries were plentiful and long, but not crispy enough for me.

name: Tea Way - CLOSED
text: Good bubble tea, with your traditional boba and an assortment of other interesting toppings you can add. The boba was soft, with the perfect amount of chewiness.If you just want a simple bubble tea with boba -- instead of the plethora of other toppings you can get here (like pudding, jelly, etc.) -- check out the Tea Way Express next door to save yourself some money.If you order food, you'll need to pick it up at the restaurant next door: Let's Roll. Do yourself a favor and check out the Popcorn Chicken!

name: Victor’s Bakery
text: This is it! After visiting several bakeries in SF during a BBQ Pork Bun Crawl, Victor's Bakery emerged as the unanimous champion!This bun has the perfect amount of fluffy bread -- just enough to give you that softness you love, yet has enough room to allow for a generous serving of delicious, chunky meat. The subtle sauce coating the meat made this bun a real winner. We also had Hong Kong Milk Tea, which is like traditional milk tea, but made much heavier with lots of condensed milk. Served hot, this tea can complement any of the baked goods you can get here.This bakery also has Portuguese Custard Cups! Unfortunately, they sell out rather quickly -- the custard cups come out at 9:30 AM and are sold out by noon -- so come in early if you want to try them!This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-b….

name: Lung Fung Bakery
text: The Baked BBQ Pork Buns here are great! Packed in this perfectly toasted bun is a good amount of fluffy bread and a load of delicious meat. The meat is complemented by a sauce that isn't too sweet or overpowering.This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-b….

name: Wing Lee Bakery
text: The Steamed Pork Bun here features untraditional brownish bread, that looked like it was made with whole wheat. This departure from tradition for the bread, and the average tasting meat within, made for an unimpressive experience. That said, the other items we tried here were much better. The Savory Pork and Vegetable Buns provided a great combination of flavors, and the dim sum items we tried -- the Chive Dumpling and Bean Curd in Tofu Wrap -- were also great and definitely worth checking out.This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-b….

name: Good Mong Kok Bakery
text: It's hard to find a place that you can just walk into and get steamed pork buns. They are traditionally served at sit-down dim sum places. But not only does Good Mong Kok -- a walk in, order, walk out bakery -- have them, they're also amazing. Good Mong Kok has both Steamed and Baked BBQ Pork Buns, which come packed with tons of great-tasting meat in wonderfully soft bread. My pork-bun-hunting-party enjoyed their BBQ Pork Buns so much we even got one of their Savory Pork and Vegetable Buns, which was also incredibly delicious!If I lived near Good Mong Kok, I would DEFINITELY, GUARANTEED get a Steamed Pork Bun every single day for the rest of my life. Because I absolutely love good Steamed Pork Buns!This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-b….

name: Garden Bakery
text: The Baked BBQ Pork Buns here have meat with an interesting flavor: we suspect that the meat contains some sweet dessert wine. The bread is fluffy with a slightly hard outer skin. While the pieces of meat were big and chunky, there wasn't enough meat overall in each bun. Given their ridiculously low cost, this didn't come as a surprise!This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-b….

name: Red House Bakery
text: We got the Baked BBQ Pork Bun: a flat, sweet, chewy bun filled with sweet meat in a thick, glutinous sauce. A good balance of the salty and sweet ingredients made for a well-flavored bun. One complaint among our group was about the parchment paper that the bun was baked on; it was quite difficult to remove, and when removed, took a layer of the bun with it!This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-b….

name: Amber India Restaurant - MOVED
text: Amber India has helped me realize a sad truth: life is too short and you only have one stomach to fill. I love so many dishes here that my biggest problem is not stuffing myself!The Butter Chicken, made with shredded chicken in a savory sauce made with tomatoes and butter, is rich and delicious! I jokingly tell people it's called Butter Chicken because there is no way they can make it taste so good without mixing in an entire stick of butter! Compared to the Butter Chicken, the Chicken Tikka Masala has larger chunks of chicken in a lighter masala sauce.While I'm a big fan of their main chicken dishes, their vegetarian entrées shine as well. My favorite is the Navratan Korma, which features mixed vegetables and nuts cooked in a thick, creamy white sauce. The deep fried potato and cheese dumplings in tomato sauce -- the Malai Kofta -- is another great dish, although I wish each order contained more dumplings. The Kadhai Paneer -- which features cottage cheese, bell peppers, and onions cooked in a light tomato sauce -- is another personal favorite.The staff here is incredibly kind and helpful. I've called in large orders for lunches at my company -- an hour before lunch. The great team at Amber has never failed to magically prepare a feast for 40 people in a shockingly short amount of time.Given how many dishes I love here, the buffet is the most economical way to have a little bit of everything. It's always a little heartbreaking when I want just one more bite, but I realize that my body can't handle it... C'est la vie...

name: Grgich Hills Estate
text: I am no wine aficionado, but I love the wine tastings at Grgich. Anytime I bring friends and family to Napa, Grgich is always on our itinerary, because every visit there so far has been great.The staff at Grgich is awesome. Other wine tastings I've done have a server or two serving an entire hall of people, seemingly racing to get everyone to the last glass of wine and out the door. At Grgich, you'll be in groups of six to eight at most with a server who pours and talks you throughout the tasting. The servers are personable and are always eager to answer my questions. Linda is a shining example of Grgich's awesomeness. On my latest visit, when my group told her they loved the '09 Cabernet Sauvignon, Linda grabbed an '06 bottle for us to compare it with. The founder, Mike Grgich, who just celebrated his 90th birthday and still actively participates in winemaking, showed up during one wine tasting. This is the same guy who made a Chardonnay that won the Paris Wine Tasting of 1976, absolutely shocking the entire industry. Like a true European (he's Croatian), he paid special attention to the girls in our party.You can google for a 2-for-1 coupon for the wine tasting to save some money. You'll get to taste 5 different wines (whites and reds), hear all about winemaking, and you even get to keep your glass. Through all my visits to Grgich, I've already amassed a nice collection of wine glasses!

name: Classic Bowling Center
text: This place has 60 lanes so when a group of us came in on a Saturday afternoon, we didn't have to wait at all. That said, we bowled from 4 PM to 8 PM, and the place never got that busy.You can pay per person per game (between $5 and $6), or reserve a lane for an hour (between $24 and $27). With 5 of us, we were able to get 2 and a half games in, so the hourly rate was a much better deal: $27 vs ~$70.The gentleman at the front desk was helpful. When we told him another group of people were coming to join us, he reserved the lane next to ours. Later on when our lane suffered some technical issues, we asked for a few more minutes to be added to our game time, and he happily obliged.

name: Ayola
text: Ayola is Smule's go-to restaurant when we crave Mediterranean food. Ayola has consistently and punctually delivered great food to our office to feed 40+ hungry people.Their menu is filled with awesome pita sandwiches, salads, and various sides. I love their Troy Salad (gyros meat on a Greek salad). It comes with tons of long, thin strips of gyros meat that pack a ton of flavor. Even though the meat can be drier than usual gyros meat, I actually don't mind that; I eagerly devour the salad, usually with a side order of hummus.For very large orders, we place them the evening before the meal. The delivery guy is super friendly and even helps unpack and lay out our order on the table. Our orders cover their entire menu (it's all so good), and there are never any leftovers!

name: GameStop - CLOSED
text: When I had to pick up 40 copies of StarCraft 2: Heart of the Swarm for StarCraft 2 Day at Smule, I came to this GameStop to pre-order the copies. The incredibly friendly and talkative store manager, Roger, helped me out. You might think he's being friendly because I was making a rather large purchase, but no; he shared his bottomless enthusiasm with all the other customers in the store.This store opens at 11 AM, so I asked Roger if there was any way to pick up the copies earlier. He told me to pass by around 10 AM, and he'd be in early to give me the copies. Everything went according to plan, and Roger even threw in a huge StarCraft 2 promotional stand-up display! Thanks, Roger!

name: In-N-Out Burger
text: This restaurant, as well as the parking lot, was packed when we stopped by on a Saturday night. The friendly staff was able to quickly take orders and get our food out ridiculously fast. As I've come to expect at every In-N-Out, the Double-Double and Fries prepared a la Animal Style were delicious!Seating inside can seat up to 4 in booths. Outside, there are a few tables that can cozily seat 8 people!And if a meal at In-N-Out doesn't fill you up, you can always stroll over to the Krispy Kreme next door. Given their proximity, an In-N-Out burger with a Krispy Kreme donut bun mash-up might be worth exploring!

name: Bistro Sabor - CLOSED
text: Wow! This gem in the heart of downtown Napa provides an amazing meal, from the first bite to the last.My cousin and I shared a Salmon Ceviche Tostadas appetizer. The citric acid in ceviche denatures the salmon, giving it the appearance of being cooked -- but this salmon was so tender, I swear they must've cheated and cooked (and then chilled) the salmon! My cousin got the Skirt Steak Tacos, which were meaty and succulent, and -- surprisingly for a taco -- not a wet, sloppy mess of ingredients. I love sandwiches, so I went with the La Cubana Torta Plate which contains carnitas (pulled pork), ham, peruvian beans, swiss cheese, pickles, and mustard with a side of perfectly seasoned and spicy fries. This... This plate... Wow! With every bite of this masterpiece, the mixture of flavors blended in my mouth in perfect harmony! Each bite provided a chance to focus on a different piece of the torta.At this point, we were so completely satisfied with our meal that we were surprised when the server brought out the churros we'd ordered, but had forgotten about! These freshly made churros were very, very crispy on the outside, but SO soft on the inside. If I had a glass of warm soymilk with these churros, I'd definitely require a nap before leaving!

name: Tín Vietnamese Cuisine
text: This restaurant provides great bang-for-your-buck. I met a friend here for lunch. We shared an appetizer of minty fresh Spring Rolls with pork and shrimp wrapped in a soft vermicelli wrap. For the main course, we shared a Lemongrass Pork Shoulder Rice Plate and a Lemongrass Tofu Rice Plate. While I'm a huge fan of anything with pork, the Lemongrass Tofu dish with perfectly seasoned and crispy tofu absolutely blew me away! We also got a side of Grilled Eggplant with Garlic-Chili Fish Sauce, which was a surprising highlight of our meal. With tea for each of us, the entire meal cost $40 with tip. The decor and atmosphere of the restaurant give it an upscale feel. You'll get great food and service, all for a great price!

name: Safelite AutoGlass
text: 2011 was a rough year for my car.In July, my rear passenger window was broken into. I called Safelite the next morning and got an appointment for that afternoon. I dropped my car off and hung out for an hour while they cleaned up the shards of glass and replaced my window.Something went wrong during installation and the auto-up feature stopped working. The technician told me to get it fixed at a dealership, and then call Safelite to get reimbursed. I was a little suspicious since he made it sound like the reimbursement process was painless. Turns out, he was right! I called Safelite after getting it fixed and spoke with someone super helpful and courteous. After faxing them the receipt, I had a check a few weeks later.In October, a rock kicked up by a vehicle in front of me left a crack in my windshield. The next day I was at Safelite and my windshield was quickly patched up. The technician warned me that they can't make the crack completely disappear, but they can fill it in and prevent it from cracking more. The damage is now barely noticeable and the crack has not grown. You'll never be happy because going to Safelite means something has already gone wrong, but they resolved my problems in a reasonable manner.

name: Hi Lo BBQ - CLOSED
text: Finger lickin' good barbecue that delivers? Yes please!From their barbecue menu, my absolute favorite item is the always tender Beef Brisket. I also really like the succulent Jamaican Jerked Chicken as well as the St. Louis-Cut Spare Ribs, which are drenched in a not-too-spicy hot sauce.That said, I'm a not a huge fan of BBQ, but their sides are amazing; I wouldn't mind just eating from their sides menu for a meal. My favorite is the BBQ baked beans: ridiculously large beans from the Iacopi Farm in Half Moon Bay with chunks of brisket, simmered in a smoky sauce. The Pull-Apart Potato Rolls are also delicious, especially when dunked in the butter sauce that comes with the Grilled Asparagus. The Cheezy Grits are great and the Potlikker Collard Greens once again proves that bacon can make anything delicious.Like other SF restaurants that deliver, they use bike couriers, but they pack their items in sturdy plastic containers. This keeps your food safe as it tumbles around in the courier's backpack.

name: Mitchell’s Ice Cream
text: I didn't want a cone or waffle bowl to interfere with my ice cream so I went with a triple scoop of Strawberry, French Custard Vanilla, and Banana in a cup. Every flavor was rich and true to its name. Of these three, I enjoyed Strawberry and Banana the most. My sister got a sugar cone with Toasted Almond and Claire's Pie (coffee ice cream with fudge, almonds, chocolate chips, and graham crunch pieces) and thoroughly enjoyed it. My cousin got a waffle cone with White Pistachio and Toasted Almond. A fan of pistachios, she felt the ice cream did pistachios justice!We heard a lot of good things about the Ube (purple yam) flavor so we got a single scoop. The taste of their Ube is subtle and can be overpowered by stronger flavors, so cleanse your palate before diving into this unique flavor. They use a deli-style waiting system: you grab a numbered ticket when you come in and are served when your number is called. Even if you come in close to closing time, as long as you grab a ticket, you will be served -- so don't fret!My first taste of Mitchell's was very enjoyable, and I'm looking forward to returning to explore more of the 40+ flavors they offer.

name: The Refuge
text: One of our engineers, Steve, relocated to North Carolina, but still visits every so often, so we can "talk about serious engineering business." But the real reason behind his visits is the best pastrami place ever: The Refuge!Come with a voracious appetite because you're going to want to eat appetizers, a hearty entrée, and dessert! My favorite appetizer is the Goofy Fries: soft garlic fries covered in melted cheddar and chunks of pastrami. The Gratineed Macaroni & Cheese is good, but I've had better at other places. If you want to explore the hidden side of The Refuge, order the PASTRAMI STEAK from the SECRET MENU! Instead of getting your delicious pastrami chopped up in a sandwich, you'll enjoy a ridiculously large slab of pastrami so tender you can cut it with your fork. I always go with the Swiss & Mustard, which features huge chunks of pastrami, swiss, and mustard on toasted rye. If you like all that AND like sauerkraut, go with the popular Reuben. They also have ribeye cheesesteaks and burgers, supposedly... But I can't stop eating the pastrami, so I can't honestly say!The climax of your meal approaches: dessert. Order the Superlative Bread Pudding. It's so hard to put into words how delicious it is. The outside is perfectly crispy and the inside so sweet and soft, resulting in a gastronomic nirvana! The serving is large and you'll likely be stuffed by this point. So remember, boys and girls, this gift from the Gods should be shared with friends.

name: Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot
text: This place rocks! Arrive with an appetite -- as you cannot prepare yourself for the amount of food you will consume!We usually go with the half spicy, half original broth base; both are absolutely delicious. The broth here is really standout.The prime rib and Shiitake mushrooms are my favorite items from the meat and vegetable family. Aside from all the meat and vegetables you get to throw into your hot pot, I love the Mongolian beef pie. A pancake filled with ground beef pan-fried to absolute perfection, I might blasphemously believe this is the best thing on their entire menu. These also keep really well in the fridge and can be reheated in a toaster oven to near out-of-the-kitchen freshness.If you somehow have room in your stomach for dessert, their dessert items are pretty good! My favorite is the Phoenix Egg Yolk Bun (Lai Wong Bao): a egg yolk wrapped in a soft steamed bun.The staff is super friendly and down to earth. One time, my friend got pretty drunk, began claiming he was the most sober member of our group, and started walking around the restaurant looking for the restroom and eventually stumbled into the kitchen. The people in the back and the waiters laughed it off and sent him back to us. A few weeks later, I came in and our waiter from that night asked if my "super sober friend" was coming!

name: Jin Sho
text: Don't just take my word for it -- the entire Smule office loves Jin Sho! When we vote Jin Sho for dinner, it seems everyone suddenly becomes more inclined to stick around and work late!The rolls here cover a wide gamut from quirky and fried to more traditional rolls. While their traditional rolls are great, I'm a sucker for their more unique rolls. The Volcano Roll is a spicy tuna roll covered with salmon and spicy mayo, baked to perfection. The Sharks Roll is a spicy deep-fried roll that reminds me of my favorite comfort sushi restaurant: Cha Cha Sushi in San Jose. The Imperial Roll is a tangy fried roll with a bread crumb nori wrap. The Stanford Roll (you might've heard of this university) is an eel/avocado roll covered with spicy tuna. There is never much room left after I go through all of my favorite rolls, but coworkers who order entrées -- like the black cod -- always sing its high praises. My friend who is a lot better than me at discerning freshness always looks forward to their uni and sashimi.The chefs and staff are both extremely friendly. I got to know them well since I came in often to grab Smule's large dinner orders. At some point, I crossed "that threshold" and the chefs began offering me these unique, off-the-menu, complimentary hand rolls whenever I rolled in. When word of these legendary hand rolls spread, I got a lot more offers to help pick up the sushi!

name: Da Sichuan Bistro
text: This is my go-to Chinese spot when I'm down in Palo Alto.The lady who takes your order over the phone is hilarious. As she takes your order, she'll yell out the items in Chinese to the chef. This was a bit disconcerting at first because I thought she was yelling at me for ordering something wrong, but I quickly got used to the ad-hoc three-person conversation. Whenever I finished ordering, she always kindly recommended (pushed) another item or two to make sure I had the Chinese take-out food groups -- meat, fish, rice, and veggies -- covered.The menu is huge. While I try to avoid ordering like an American at Chinese restaurants, I can't help myself at Da Sichuan because the "American Chinese" dishes are so good.
